HEADLINE: The Bard of Omaha 

BYLINE:  By John Hodgman; John Hodgman is a writer in New York City.

 BODY:
Alexander Payne drives fast in Omaha, both because he knows it well and because he wants to show it off. He shows me Dundee, the tidy grove of modest two-story homes where he grew up and where his parents still live. He shows me the Dundee Theater, where he also grew up, in the dark, watching movies. 
 As we cruise through one of the city's growing Mexican-American neighborhoods, he merrily reads aloud the passing signs: " 'Salon Lecheria'!" he cries. "Over three movies, and having to scout so many locations, I have seen so much of Omaha, and I am constantly surprised by what I find, the people I meet -- 'La Carne Fresca'! -- so I love this." 
 Many people love their hometown, but when Payne talks about Omaha, he speaks with a vim and an earnestness that's occasionally disarming. Sometimes he is so eager to show me around that he takes a turn too fast and his Audi scoots up over the curb. "One great thing about this area is just how beautiful and treesy it is and just nice," he says as we swoop through a neighborhood known as Happy Hollow. Arbor Day was invented in Nebraska, he tells me, and though I am glad to know this, it is not the sort of thing I expected to learn from a man who made the abortion comedy "Citizen Ruth" in 1996 and who co-wrote and directed the gleefully blackhearted satire "Election" in 1999. 
Both films were set and shot here, as was his latest, "About Schmidt," which made the film-festival rounds and opens in New York and Los Angeles -- and Omaha -- this Friday. Originally based on a Louis Begley novel set in the Hamptons, under Payne's direction the story moved to Omaha, where it became a purely Nebraskan odyssey, with Jack Nicholson as a recent widower Winnebago-ing across the state to attend his daughter's wedding. 
But "About Schmidt" will be his last Midwestern film, at least for now. His errand this weekend: to start packing up the apartment he has lived in on and off since 1997 and send his things out to Hollywood.
"In a sense, 'Schmidt' is the most Omaha of my films," Payne says as we drive. "But have I gotten it right? I'm not sure. Did Fellini get Rome right? Did Ozu get Tokyo right?"
But we all understand Rome -- just as we all own a share of Woody Allen's Manhattan, or at least the versions of those cities conjured by cinema. No one owns Omaha the way Alexander Payne does, though. And few would know if he has really managed to get it right.
Then we come to the intersection of 50th and Underwood. "I try to get this intersection into every movie," he says. We slow to a crawl as we pass a small market, a tiny parking lot, some dumpsters. 
It's a surprising slice of Omaha to showcase: a little grungy and certainly untreesy. Here is where Nicholson's Schmidt throws away his dead wife's clothes in a rage, where Matthew Broderick's high-school civics teacher casually tosses the nominating signatures of the ambitious candidate he despises in "Election." It is the alley where Laura Dern's Ruth tosses herself out with an aerosol can of patio sealant to huff her way into oblivion in "Citizen Ruth."
In short, a dumping ground. Though Payne's affection for the city is genuine, here is where I first understand that he sees it with a kind of double vision. On the most painfully bright day, he cannot help but see the dark corners -- and what the Midwest might rather throw away.
'Citizen Ruth" follows an inhalant-loving deadbeat who, when she learns she is pregnant, pinballs between both sides of the abortion debate. Payne wrote it in 1992 with Jim Taylor, a non-Omahan who rented a room in Payne's apartment as Payne was finishing film school in 1990 and has since become his close collaborator on all three films. Ruth is sublimely self-involved yet completely un-self-aware; like all of Payne's protagonists, she is not easy to like. And unlike typical Hollywood antiheroes, she does not evolve in the third act into the huffer-with-a-heart-of-gold we halfway expect. The film ends with Ruth unchanged, sneaking down the road with a briefcase full of cash, having played both the pro-lifers and pro-choicers for fools.
"There's a bizarre insistence on how a story should be," Payne says. "The protagonist must be sympathetic!' they say. Whatever that means. I never engage in that discussion. I never use that word, 'sympathetic.' I just know 'interesting."'
If anything, Payne wishes "Citizen Ruth" had been more vicious. "I had in mind a certain ferocity when we were writing it that I associate with Billy Wilder's 'Ace in the Hole' or Bunuel's 'Viridiana."'
When it comes to movies, Payne is a passionate obscurist and something of a nostalgic. He is a devoted fan of silent comedy. When a Fox executive offered to do him a favor, any favor, Payne asked for a VHS dupe of Bertolucci's long-out-of-print "Luna." The Italian neo-realists -- Antonioni and, especially, Fellini -- loom high in his pantheon of what he calls "the film gods," and he playfully defies me to name four classic films released since 1980. "Raging Bull' doesn't count," he says, "because Scorsese was still making it in the 70's." 
Somehow I sense that my first thought, "The Empire Strikes Back," is not an acceptable answer. 
"We always made wonderful movies," he says, talking about Americans. "But in the 70's, it was suddenly real people up there. You saw your world on the screen, not some fake kind of thing. Even 'McCabe and Mrs. Miller,' one of my favorite 70's movies: those were real people out West. And we've come away from that."
"He's a true cinephile," says the director Jim Jarmusch, who got to know Payne this year at Cannes, where "About Schmidt" had its festival premiere. He knows his stuff, Jarmusch says, "unlike a lot of younger directors who turn out to be hustlers, just pretenders." 
Perhaps it is because he knows his stuff -- because there is a classicism to his work, its roots in high cinema more than low culture -- that he seems at once so sensitive and also vulnerable to studio interference. His colleagues sometimes speak of him as if he were an endangered animal.
"Black humor is a tough sell," Jack Nicholson says. "If you're not making essentially youthful films, you're taking chances. Alexander is a real throwback to the kinds of moviemakers I started with."
"Ruth" was followed by "Election," which earned Payne and Taylor an Oscar nomination for best adapted screenplay. "Election" follows a high-school civics teacher who ruins his career and marriage as he is drawn ever more deeply into a rigged high-school election. It is a carefully structured film, full of competing voice-overs, repeated visual motifs (almost every shot includes a garbage can) and clever grace notes. And if its formal inventiveness sometimes feels icily detached, it is paradoxically balanced by the warmth of a single mind at work. A sense of purpose looms in every frame, right next to the garbage can. Payne's films don't apologize for their smartness.
Or better, their smart aleckiness. It's a term that Payne uses twice when I'm with him, and it describes him well: a polite, well-raised, A-student kind of fellow who handwrites his thank-you notes but who just can't keep himself from swiping at the things he obviously loves -- whether it's pulling Jack Nicholson's pants down in "About Schmidt," giving Matthew Broderick a bee sting on the eye in "Election" or poking at Omaha itself.
Slim and good-looking, with dark eyes and a newly short haircut, Payne is a young-seeming 41, exuberant and restlessly curious, with an unashamed intelligence and a natural comedic brio. ("It is I, Alexander Payne," he says when calling me on the phone.) He has a habit of making scholarly-sounding pronouncements that, like his films, hover weirdly between joke and dead seriousness, such as "Omaha, like Rome, is built on seven hills." 
He always wanted to shoot in Omaha. When he graduated from U.C.L.A.'s film program in 1990, he was already something of a star: an intense, scholarly filmmaker who slept in his editing room. He quickly struck a deal with Universal, but turned down several commercial scripts and began work instead on a screenplay called "The Coward," the story of an aging Omaha man who leaves his wife suddenly to set out on a "futile journey of self-discovery." But Universal didn't want to make it.
"Nobody had done Omaha before," he told me as we strolled through Memorial Park, atop one of those seven hills. "I thought it would be fun."
That's one explanation. Payne's reason for making movies in America's anonymous middle is not something he's eager to pin down. He talks about wanting to "pour some money into the local economy," but that doesn't quite seem to nail it either. "If you're trying to recreate life, the life that you best know is the one you grew up with," he says. "I hadn't seen the Midwest in a movie. I'd never seen it. I wanted to see it. It was as simple as that. I hadn't seen it. I wanted to capture it. But it's elusive."
When I ask him what has eluded him, that's when he starts showing me statues. "Here," he says, "let me show you how ridiculous this memorial is." He walks me over to the city's Korean and Vietnam war memorial: a gargantuan American soldier, one hand outstretched to the horizon and the other on the shoulder of a child. "Here's the white guy showing the little Asian boy the way," Payne says. "It's a complete disaster. How tacky is that? But here it sits, kind of unquestioned."
There's a smile in his voice as he says it, an affection both for the failure of the image and for its good intentions. But most of all, he seems to love that, here in the middle of the park, it goes unseen. It is this strangeness-in-plain-sight that infects all of his films and crystallizes, for Payne, a distinct strain of American daily life -- one that is both actually and metaphorically central. 
"It's as if there's something slightly grotesque in the Midwest that appeals to him," explains Tom Perrotta, author of the novel "Election." "His movies are certainly not a paean to wholesome Midwestern values."
Verisimilitude is important to Payne. For Schmidt's home, he reproduced the interior of a Happy Hollow house, even down to the wallpaper (recreated at great expense by Hollywood specialists). In the end, Payne estimates it cost as much to build the house on stage as it would have to buy it. He regularly uses untrained actors. The countergirl at the Dairy Queen is the countergirl at the Dairy Queen -- her first movie, and she's doing lines with Jack Nicholson. 
Finding real locations, using the people you find there: these are the techniques of the Italian neo-realists adapted to the heartland. "While shooting 'Schmidt,' the costume people were going into the extra pool and lint-brushing them," Payne recalls. "I had to shoo them away. Why do you make people look unlike they would naturally occur, just because there's a camera there? Why do you have to make things more beautiful?" 
If Ruth was something of a lively scamp, there is little to lighten the grotesque sadness of Nicholson's Warren Schmidt. He is a weary, combed-over salary-man who, as an actuary, knows all too well that he's nearing the end of his useful days. Incapable of connecting with his family, his only confidant is the unanswering Ndugu, an African orphan Schmidt is inspired to sponsor by a late-night television pitch. In his letters to Ndugu, decades of simmering disappointment start to boil, and Schmidt tears apart his wife, his daughter's choice in men and his own failed fortunes. Yet even at his barest, he cannot help but pretty up the pain, referring to his daughter's shipping clerk job as a "position of some responsibility" with a "high-tech computer outfit." He is unable, finally, to express himself except in the aphorisms of business correspondence. "Here I am rambling on and on," he writes, "and you probably want to hurry on down, cash that check and get yourself something to eat. . . . Best of luck with all your endeavors. Yours, very truly, Warren Schmidt."
"The guy is kind of a miserable human being," Nicholson says. "He's an actuary, but he doesn't really observe his own life. He's dishonest even to a 6-year-old boy in a letter."
Says Payne: "That kind of denial is very Midwestern. To say, 'Oh, sure, I get a little down from time to time. But everything's fine!"'
If the Omaha of "Election" was simply a bland every-burb, in "About Schmidt" Omaha feels startlingly, painfully specific: an empty city of watery blues and grays, the blank spot at the center of the map. It's as affecting a picture of alienation as you'd find in, say, Antonioni's "L'Avventura" -- only with fewer beautiful Italian women and more stretch waistbands.
When I ask Nate Carlson, Payne's graphic designer and an Omaha native, if he thinks Payne got Omaha right, he replies: "Yes, but it's a rightness you don't think about. There's a lot of kindness on the surface here. And he shows that it's like that -- but that it's not like that. For the most part, he shows the city as being rather gloomy." 
Carlson thinks that Omaha audiences see Payne's films differently from the rest of the country. "I don't think the people in Omaha see the gloom in his movies," he says. "They see the Dairy Queen they used to work at. They don't see the thunderclouds behind it."
Payne, on the other hand, sees both the Happy and the Hollow and ends up articulating a distinctly Midwestern existentialism: deep ennui charmed by a paradoxical, unrelenting optimism. 
"About Schmidt" may be Payne's last Omaha movie. But it is also his first, in the sense that it largely revives "The Coward," the screenplay he abandoned almost a decade before. "I hadn't yet gotten that story out of my system," Payne says, and as he and Taylor worked to adapt Begley's book, he found himself borrowing elements from it, including Ndugu. From the novel he retained the plot of a man disapproving his daughter's wedding, but as Begley's Schmidt became Payne's, he no longer abhorred the fact that she was marrying into a Jewish family but instead abhorred the fact that she was marrying into a clan of Denver hippies. The world Begley had created retreated, and the Hamptons, somewhat improbably, became Omaha. 
When I reached Begley at his own home in the Hamptons, the graceful attorney-novelist of Polish birth confessed that he was "obviously, initially rocked" by the changes. To him, Nebraska embodies what he calls America's "somewhat crazy core." But since seeing the film, he has become more understanding. "I can sympathize," Begley says. "Omaha is a place that he knows, and he's wonderful about exploiting it."
Perrotta, whose own "Election" was moved to Omaha from New Jersey, is more sanguine. "It's a very literary decision, in a way, to bring his films to Omaha. He's claiming a kind of prerogative to be a regionalist -- which is unusual for a filmmaker, but for an American writer to do that is nothing at all. It puts him in the company of Sherwood Anderson, William Faulkner, William Kennedy." 
But now Payne is moving on. His next film, "Sideways," is based on a yet-unpublished novel that follows two oenophiles on a weeklong tasting binge through the vineyards of central California. It will be hard to find a place for 50th and Underwood there in the sunshine, but after three films of Dairy Queens and thunderclouds, that may be the point. 
Though "About Schmidt" is bleaker than your average Christmas movie, New Line, which is releasing it, is demonstrating faith in Payne's newfound stature as a filmmaker: the studio plans to expand the release to 2,000 screens by the end of January, compared with the roughly 800 on which "Election" was shown. The film has already met with critical enthusiasm, not only at Cannes in the spring but also in New York in September, where it was chosen to be the opening-night film at the New York Film Festival. 
If "About Schmidt" is his for-now farewell to the Midwest, it is something of an extravagant goodbye. After the critical success of "Election," when he might have gone anywhere, he gave Omaha his most expensive film ($30 million, compared with the $8 million he spent on "Election"), his biggest star (The Omaha World-Herald giddily charted Nicholson's movements in a frequent "Where's Jack?" column) and his first chance at final cut. If things go well, he may return to make his long-dreamed-about Nebraskan Western. But there is also the sense that he has done it now, because he knows he may not be able to do it again.
On my last night in Omaha, I head to the preserved downtown area known as the Old Market for a farewell drink with Payne, Nate Carlson and Payne's friend David Clark, an attorney who gave up San Francisco to come to Omaha and write books about Warren Buffet. After meeting him at a party, Payne cast him as a prosecutor in "Citizen Ruth." A few nights earlier, at a dinner with some local actors, Clark had explained to me rather intensely that Omaha is the new Bohemia, in part because it is so boring that people are forced to read. 
As Payne is joking with Carlson, Clark takes out a folded blue sheet of paper. He has been thinking, he says to me, about my questions on why Payne shoots in Omaha. "He's the favorite son," he explains. "He's a phone call away from the mayor, the governor. He goes to a cafe, and the crew gathers around him, and he holds court. Everyone loves him." Clark hands me the blue paper. "I photocopied this for you," he says, waiting as I read the highlighted passage. It's a page from Elia Kazan's autobiography, "A Life."
"The one time I met William Faulkner, I remember he wore rubber boots and they were covered with the mud of his Mississippi winter," the passage reads. "He never left his home in Oxford for very long. John Steinbeck left northern California and looked a fool in New York. . . . Saul Bellow is wise; he stays in Chicago. . . . And Proust: he lived in what he wrote about -- a life no one else could tolerate."
I look up, and Clark shakes his head a little sadly. "I don't know why he wants to leave," he says. As we finish our drink, I notice Payne standing, smiling. He is already saying goodbye.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY; 
Deals and Discounts

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH SIANO 

 BODY:
 Sometimes special offers come in numerical order.

ONE FREE AFTER TWO -- Two paid round trips or four one-way trips on an Acela Express or Metroliner train between Boston, New York or Washington before Feb. 28 will earn a free round trip. The free trips, available to Amtrak Guest Rewards members, may be taken between April 22 and Aug. 28 (some dates are blacked out), for travel in the same class as the two paid trips. There is no limit to the number of trips that can be earned, and the free trips can be transferred to others. There is no charge for membership in the Amtrak Guest Rewards program; call (800) 307-5000 or log on to www.amtrak.com to join. Information: (800) 872-7245.

THREE NIGHTS IN LONDON -- It's a short getaway, but after holiday shopping, a $279 package from British Airways with three nights in a London hotel may be closer to what most travelers can afford. Good through Jan. 15, for purchase by Jan. 12, it includes round-trip economy air fare from New York, three nights in the 1,630-room Royal National Hotel near Covent Garden, Continental breakfast and hotel taxes and tips. The price is per person, based on double occupancy, and there is a $20 weekend surcharge each way; the offer is not available Dec. 15 to 30. Airport fees and taxes are extra. For $339, the price includes the 401-room Plaza on Hyde Park; for $363, the hotel is the 188-room Gresham Hyde Park. For information, (877) 428-2228; www.britishairways.com/londonbreak.

FOUR HYATTS -- Hyatt hotels in the New York area are reducing rates in the holiday season. The Grand Hyatt, next to Grand Central Terminal, will have rooms for $179 a night Dec. 13 to Jan. 4. The Stanhope Park Hyatt , opposite the Metropolitan Museum of Art, has deluxe rooms for $219 a night Dec. 13 to Jan. 4, excluding Dec. 31. In Greenwich, Conn., the Hyatt Regency has rooms for $89 Dec. 19 to 30, and the Hyatt Regency Jersey City, on the Hudson River is charging $99 ($159 including breakfast for two and valet parking) Dec. 16 to 30. Reservations can be made at (800) 233-1234 or at www.hyatt.com.

MULTIPLY BY FIVE -- From March 30 to Oct. 26, French Country Waterways has discounts on its one-week barge cruises in Burgundy for couples celebrating wedding anniversaries in multiples of five -- 5 percent for a fifth anniversary up to 60 percent for a 60th anniversary. Savings will range from $160 to $2,577 a person on the cruises, which regularly cost $3,195 to $4,295 a person, double occupancy. Rates include six nights on the 18-passenger Esprit, 12-passenger Horizon II or 8-passenger Liberte; all meals and wine, sightseeing and transfers between the cruises and Paris. Couples must submit a copy of a wedding certificate; (800) 222-1236 or www.fcwl.com. JOSEPH SIANO

HEADLINE: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 12-8-02; 
The Healing Paradox

BYLINE:  By Abraham Verghese; Abraham Verghese is a professor of medicine and director of the Center for Medical Humanities and Ethics at the University of Texas Health Sciences Center, San Antonio. His latest book is "The Tennis Partner."

 BODY:
As a practicing physician, I confess that I learn about the latest medical breakthroughs while reading my morning paper. When my office mail eventually brings me the original study, my pleasure in the journal's pristine cover and untouched pages has been diminished because the tidings arrived before the messenger. But here is why I cannot complain: the science reported in my newspaper is genuinely newsworthy, deserving its place alongside matters of state and economy. For example, two weeks ago we learned of a promising approach to the prevention of cervical cancer -- a vaccine against one type of papilloma virus that is an antecedent to this malignancy. Imagine that. A vaccine for cancer! On the same day as that announcement came the first report of a vaccine that might prevent genital herpes. And then there's the ongoing news of the unraveling of the human genome in all its amazing complexity. History will draw a line here: Before Genome and After Genome. The Rosetta stone has been found and applied to the sacred scroll, and it promises important breakfast reading for years to come. 
 But my morning paper, laden with science, also carries evidence of our distrust of science and our search for another kind of healing. You've seen it: a full-page advertisement for a product that you know is too good to be true. The text has large type, a before-and-after picture, no listing of the contents of the product and a blizzard of endorsements from "scientists" and "patients" that take the place of data. These products are life extenders, fat fighters, growth-hormone releasers, relievers of limb pains, rebuilders of muscle and bone and sometimes all of the above together. I think of them as quark drugs, phantoms that if they could be studied in careful trials would soon lose the "r" for a "c" and be revealed for what they are. 
 But the market for such remedies is huge. Indeed, estimates are that nearly half of all adult Americans use some sort of dietary supplement, and the sales of these products in 2000 amounted to more than $15 billion! I plead guilty: echinacea and ginkgo have made appearances in my medicine cabinet, as I reached for magic for some ailment or other. I had no guidance, no data of the sort a scientist should accept, no package insert. I tried them on faith. Alas, they did nothing.
The good news is that many such treatments are being systematically and carefully studied through the aegis of the National Institutes of Health; what we know thus far is that few products live up to their claims, many have the potential for toxicity and the quality control on this stuff is awful. Here is the bad news: 70 percent of us would take these products anyway, even if they were shown to be no better than snake oil. Even as science measurably changes our life and extends our life spans, as a society we are suspicious of science.
I am not a crusader against alternative medicines or its practitioners. I am all for things that make us feel better and that don't hurt us. But I do wonder at the paradox of even the most rational of us being drawn to these bottles with pictures of ugly tubers and weedlike plants on them. Why do we become dreamy-eyed hearing the songs of the New Age pied pipers whose melodies interweave quantum physics and the workings of the colon in beautiful but completely fictional ways? Like revivalist preachers, they invite our faith, our willingness to search for magic in ancient, undecipherable Oriental practices (as opposed to the new, quite decipherable, Western practices). In return they offer nostrums, tonics, tapes, books, diets, retreats, mantras, votive candles and cruises; they bring color, fragrance and incense to an illness experience that otherwise plays out in black and white.
In this golden age of science, disease and treatment have become demystified. If you went to a doctor clutching your stomach in days of old, the doctor, after a good bit of probing and hemming and hawing, would retreat to the dispensary and with great ceremony compound a mistura carminativa, vividly colored in a medicinal bottle. Short of surgery or an autopsy, no one would be precisely certain what you had. But come clutching your stomach to a medical doctor these days, and after a careful history and exam, the doctor can "see" your gallbladder, measure the distress of your pancreas, examine the lining of your colon and much, much more if need be and then institute the precise cure. 
Therein lies the rub: we are perhaps in search of something more than a cure -- call it healing. If you were robbed one day, and if by the next day the robber was caught and all your goods returned to you, you would only feel partly restored; you would be "cured" but not "healed"; your sense of psychic violation would remain. Similarly with illness, a cure is good, but we want the healing as well, we want the magic that good physicians provide with their personality, their empathy and their reassurance. Perhaps these were qualities that existed in abundance in the prepenicillin days when there was little else to do. But in these days of gene therapy, increasing specialization, managed care and major time constraints, there is a tendency to focus on the illness, the cure, the magic of saving a life.
Science needs to be more cognizant of the other magic, the healing if you will, even as we reach for the proven cures. We need to develop and refine that magic of the physician-patient relationship that complements the precise pharmacologic interventions we may prescribe; we need to ensure the wholeness of our encounter with patients; we need to not lose sight of the word "caring" in our care of the patient. And doggedly, in this fashion, one patient at a time, we can restore faith in the fantastic advances of science we are privileged to witness. 

GRAPHIC: Photo (Hulton Archive/Getty Images) Chart: "BACK TO NATURE"* The prevalence of CAM complementary and alternative medicine use increased from 25 percent in 1990 to 42 percent in 1997. . . . HEADLINE: The View/From Waterford; 
Keeping Up With the Joneses And Their Water Runoff

BYLINE:  By JANE GORDON 

 BODY:
ON first glance, Giovanni Drive in Waterford looks like hundreds of other developments. Houses on half-acre lots, rolling green lawns, private driveways. Stroll down the street, though, and the pavement alters to cobblestone from asphalt, houses are clustered closer together, curbs are absent. Such small differences make Giovanni Drive unlike any development in the country.
 Water-quality specialists nationally are paying attention to what happens at the nearly completed 30-house development, an experiment in environmental planning. The thinking: Take a typical neighborhood, apply traditional building methods to one half, environmentally friendly building methods (known as "best-management practices") to the other. Monitor the runoff from each neighborhood over the years, with the hope that the environmentally friendly practices will decrease the amount of polluted runoff enough to make a difference to Long Island Sound. 
 "Even though most of our national problems are primarily agricultural, we also have urban water problems and we're not cleaning those up," said Jack Clausen, an associate professor of natural resources at the University of Connecticut and the project's leader. 
"New building is going on pretty much everywhere, we're spreading out more and more. The prognosis is that one would expect the problems to get worse, that we'll have impaired water quality.
"Excess bacteria in our estuaries closes shellfish beds and can also close beaches," Mr. Clausen continued about possible runoff problems. "So there's a whole host of problems, and it all relates to our desire for high-quality water."
The names of Giovanni's Drive's caretakers reads like a laundry list of bureaucracy: The Environmental Protection Agency, the state Department of Environmental Protection, various agencies connected to the Town of Waterford, the University of Connecticut, private consultants. The project even has an appropriately bureaucratic official name: the Jordan Cove Urban Watershed National Monitoring Project. 
But for the Waterford developer, John Lombardi, Giovanni Drive is the place where the chicken farm on which he had been born was, and where his father, Giovanni Lombardi, had worked since 1938. The Lombardi house still stands on its original site, a shingled farmhouse embraced by a front porch. The younger Mr. Lombardi started working the farm in 1962, then branched out into developing land for residential and commercial use. 
In the late 1980's, Waterford's town planner, Thomas Wagner, told Mr. Lombardi that the E.P.A. was seeking a site for a water-monitoring project. Mr. Lombardi inquired into it, then i had to wait one year before developing any of the former chicken farm while the agencies monitored existing runoff from the site.
"I was interested in doing a different project," Mr. Lombardi said. "I wanted to do something that was a landmark, because the road is named after my father. It was nostalgic."
Building began six years ago. Nnow the 70,000 chickens are gone, and the site has become one of two urban water-monitoring projects the E.P.A. is coordinating throughout the country -- the other is in Illinois -- and the only one that involves construction of an entire neighborhood. Another 21 projects are looking at agricultural runoff. 
"The point is to get the water back into the ground before it runs off," said Mel Cote, the manager of the water quality unit in the New England office of the E.P.A. 
In the environmentally friendly part of the neighborhood, retention basins are used to hold rainwater and runoff until it settles back into the ground. Small gardens, called rain gardens, containing shrubs and flowers in the yards are depressed rather than raised into the soil, which helps them retain water. The planners used plants that "like to get their feet wet," said Thomas Wagner, Waterford's town planner and its representative in the project. "Cattails, dogwoods, birches, they're all in there," he said.
A paver road, which costs five times as much as asphalt, according to Marc Geer, an assistant to Mr. Lombardi, was installed without curbs; both of these construction elements promote the absorption of water into the ground. The neighborhood starts with asphalt roads, and two-thirds of the way in, the appearance of pavers marks the beginning of the non-traditional neighborhood. And there is a secondary gain in the neighborhood: Drivers tend to slow down once their cars motor onto the pavers. 
The experimental neighborhood run-off is now one-third of that of the traditional neighborhood. 
Homeowners in the experimental neighborhood paid from $350,000 to $390,000 for their homes. Houses in the traditional neighborhood cost $240,000 to $350,000. 
Roger Nelson bought a house on the street two years ago, opting for the traditional side because he wanted a larger lot than the other part of the neighborhood could accommodate. He liked the idea of being in a test neighborhood, and has since become president of the street's neighborhood association.
"I'm a scientist myself, retired from Pfizer," he said, "and I'm certainly used to doing experiments where you have a control and an experimental. It's been pretty interesting to see the various tools that UConn has put in to measure water flow and other components."
Mr. Lombardi was enthusiastic about being a part of the experiment, but the expense and time he has spent prompts him to question whether any other developer would take on such a project. 
"There's just so much bureaucracy, sometimes wetlands, sometimes the town planner, sometimes the E.P.A. wanted something special," he said. "They were supposed to reimburse us for the differences, but the truth is we ended up funding it through our own pockets. I should have left it as a farm and remodeled it and sold organic eggs. Or I could have made a short road and six big building lots. Economically, our construction company would have been much better off."
Mr. Lombardi's reservations about the project are not new to Mr. Clausen, who regularly works with developers and homeowners to promote the practices. 
"I'm doing another project in Branford, a retrofit of a neighborhood," said Mr. Clausen. "I walk down the street and wonder if people aren't peering out the windows saying, 'Who is this weirdo from UConn?' It's hard to convince all these people to adopt these practices. The same holds true for convincing developers, planning commissions, wetlands commissions, that these are desirable and needed."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Two sides of Giovanni Drive: Traditional building methods are used for one half of the development, left, and environmentally friendly building methods (known as "best-management practices") for the other, above. The water runoff from each is monitored. (Photographs by C. M. Glover for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS; 
Japanese Presence Shrinks

BYLINE:  By YILU ZHAO 

 BODY:
A DECADE ago, the Scarsdale office of Furumoto Realty was buying mansions in Westchester for Japanese corporations to house their expatriate staff. Now, it is selling those properties for the same clients.
 Four years ago, Meidiya, a supermarket popular among the local Japanese, closed its Yonkers store, the bigger of the two it operated. 
 At the Greenwich Japanese School in Connecticut, which draws three-quarters of its students from Japanese families living in Westchester, enrollment has slid from 417 in 1992, to 314 before the World Trade Center attack, to 253 today. 
The Banbanka, the late summer festival with traditional dances and fragrant teas, put on in Eastchester by the local Japanese, is no longer held.
The ripples of the decade-long stagnation of the Japanese economy have unraveled the once-thriving Japanese enclaves in Westchester. The number of Japanese living in Westchester has dwindled, as cost-conscious Japanese companies trim their New York-based staff or eliminate their American branches.
In 1992, before the bubble economy burst in Japan, a total of 357 Japanese companies employed 6,048 Japanese citizens in the New York metropolitan area, according to the Japanese Chamber of Commerce and Industry of New York. Between one-quarter to one-third of the expatriates lived in Westchester with their families, and the Japanese population in the county was around 16,000, according to the Japanese consulate in New York.
Currently, 273 companies employ 2,528 Japanese citizens in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, a 58 percent decrease from 1992. Westchester's loss in Japanese population has declined accordingly. 
While many Japanese men -- the expatriate employees are almost entirely male, proud and reserved -- are unwilling to discuss their feelings about the shrinking Japanese community in the county, their wives are more open.
Keiko Onoda, whose family will return to Japan next month, would prefer to live in Scarsdale a little longer. Mrs. Onoda, 52, the wife of a Japanese executive with a publishing company, has lived in Westchester for six years.
Their son, Hayato, a 24-year-old psychology major at the City University of New York, loves the freedom that the American education system offers. He can pick his major when he is ready and change it if he wants to. He can transfer to another school if he chooses to. Mrs. Onoda would have liked to live near her son until he finishes college.
Mrs. Onoda loves the trees, the grass and the chirping birds in Westchester. She can also store as many gadgets, books and clothes as she would like to in her roomy, airy house on a quiet street in Scarsdale.
"There are so many people in Japan," she said recently, as she sorted through the family's belongings. "Every place is like Manhattan. We'll never get this much space again."
Because the family will live in a Tokyo apartment much smaller than their Scarsdale house, Mrs. Onoda has been choosing which household items to keep.
"And I like to play golf," Mrs. Onoda said, a little sad. "It's really cheap to play golf here. You can play as much as you want. Back in Japan, you cannot."
Most Japanese companies were generous with their expatriate employees until a few years ago, often covering housing expenses, children's tuition, memberships of golf clubs, subscriptions to magazines, and for senior staff members, cars with full-time chauffeurs. It could cost more than $50,000 a year beyond the basic salary to support even a mid-level employee in the United States.
Now, most companies have shrunk the benefits, and many are planning to shed more of their overseas staff. The Mizuho Corporate Bank, one of the largest in Japan, has already sold all of its properties in the New York area as well as its golf club memberships, said Osomu Ogura, its spokesman. The company is planning to cut half of its 300 Japanese employees in the United States.
Takuya Honjo, the president and chief executive of Mizuho Corporate Bank's American operations, is the one who decides which employees must return home. Also a Scarsdale resident, Mr. Honjo leaves home for his office in Midtown Manhattan at 6 a.m. and doesn't get home until 10 or 11 p.m. Trimming staff, he said, is necessary to revive the companies.
"It doesn't make a difference to me whether we have a big or small community," he said.
But the size of Westchester's Japanese community matters a lot to Ozao Shizue, the owner of Meidiya, the Japanese grocery -- now one store instead of two.
"The families go back to Japan and they don't come back," Mrs. Shizue said, drawing in the air the shape of a plummeting roller coaster. "The companies are not sending replacements." 
At her store on Central Park Avenue in Hartsdale, where packages of ramen noodles are neatly stacked on shelves and freshly cut fish are buried in ice, business is slower, Mrs. Shizue said.
The exodus of Japanese families from Westchester has also reduced enrollment at the Greenwich Japanese School, set up 27 years ago for the children of Japanese citizens. The school teaches subjects in Japanese, except for English, American social studies and art. 
"I used to have 30 kids in my class," said Kay Nitta, who has taught English as a second language there for more than 10 years. "Now I have 13." 
Administrators are worried about balancing the books. The school, though heavily subsidized by the Japanese government, needs tuition and fees ($7,000 a year per child) to pay the bills. When the school had between 400 and 500 students, paying the bills had been easy. This year, the school will run a big deficit, said Tomiko Okajima, the school's longtime office manager. When a new principal, Koji Yoshida, was brought in 18 months ago, one of his main missions was to attract more students. He reasons that if a larger percentage of Japanese expatriates send their children to his school instead of American schools, it can survive.
And for Tak Furumoto, the owner of Furumoto Realty, which has offices in Scarsdale, Fort Lee and Manhattan, to survive means to diversify its clientele. A decade ago, its Westchester clients were exclusively Japanese expatriates, and now, they are one-quarter local American families, Mr. Furumoto said. 
Mr. Furumoto's agents know how to sell properties for departing families and corporations eager to get rid of them. Mike Mikuni, the head agent in its Scarsdale office, just advised a Japanese family who left the country in July to price their house on a quiet road at $659,000, lower than the asking prices of many similar houses.
"It'll be an easy sell," Mr. Mikuni said.

Meidiya in Hartsdale, a grocery that closed its Yonkers store. (Above, George M. Gutierrez for The New York Times; photographs by Janet Durrans for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: $200 Million for an Underused Courthouse 

BYLINE:  By FAIZA AKHTAR 

DATELINE: CENTRAL ISLIP 

 BODY:
IT required more than a decade of planning and more than $200 million to build the new federal courthouse in Central Islip. Gleaming white and 11 stories tall, the building, which opened two years ago on 29 acres of land donated by Suffolk County, is visible for miles across the flat South Shore landscape. It was designed by the renowned architect Richard Maier to evoke a sense of awe and respect for the law.
 But it's largely an empty shell. Of 377,000 square feet of courtroom-related space, more than a third is vacant, and most of the 70,000 square feet designed as office space is also sitting idle. 
 "They put all this money into the building, but it's like no one took the time to think things through," said Don Porter, who works at the courthouse as a security officer for the United States Marshal Service. "If they did, it wouldn't be so empty. Vacant courts, vacant offices, there are even floors that are half vacant."
George Kuchek of the Spector Group, a North Hills firm that collaborated with Mr. Maier in the design of the building, said the need was there. "The federal courthouses on Long Island were overcrowded," he said.
But William Jenkins of the General Services Administration, the federal buildings superintendent and lead agency in the government's $9 billion nationwide courthouse building project, said that government officials proceeded with design and construction of the Central Islip building based not on current need but on projected demand in 2030.
"We wanted to combine all the courts of the Eastern District into one building," he said. "The size of it was determined by what the projected needs of the courts would be by 2030."
Mr. Kuchek said that some of the courtroom space and the 70,000 square feet designed as office space was supposed to be rented out, mainly to other federal agencies, such as the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms and the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
Mr. Jenkins said that "as the district's need for courtrooms would increase over the years, the plan was to build an annex or another building on the land and move the agencies there."
But for now, at least, the annex plan is moot. Only a handful of federal agencies occupy space in the courthouse.
The F.B.I. and the Drug Enforcement Administration continue to rent space on Pinelawn Road in Melville, and when the B.A.T.F. moved recently it was to the building next door to the F.B.I. and D.E.A., where the Federal Aviation Administration and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton already have offices. The Secret Service's lease on an office in Melville expires soon, but Jack Pratt, a spokesman for Representative Steve Israel, said the Secret Service was planning to stay in Melville, which is in Mr. Israel's district.
The G.S.A. says the federal government leases 35 parcels totalling 1,414,715 square feet of office space on Long Island, and could save money by renting to itself at the Central Islip building. But the G.S.A. cannot order the agencies to move.
"Things didn't go as planned and I suppose one of the main reasons is that nobody likes to move," Mr. Jenkins said. "Think about it -- it's bad enough when you have to move your house. Can you imagine what it must be like to move an entire agency?"
But government officials cited other reasons for not wanting to move. Federal agencies are under pressure from local governments to keep their offices, and the jobs and corollary economic activity that go with them, right where they are.
Central Islip's location is also an issue. "In the recent past G.S.A. has tried to convince the F.B.I. to move to the Central Islip building, but we never wanted to leave Melville," said Joseph Valiquette, an F.B.I. spokesman. "Unlike Central Islip, Melville is centrally located, enabling the F.B.I. to work with both the Suffolk County and Nassau County police."
Joe Green, a spokesman for the B.A.T.F., said the agency had recently signed a new lease and moved into the building in Melville and "at no time were we notified by G.S.A. about any available space in the Central Islip Federal Building."
Ken Trepeta, a spokesman for former Congressman Rick Lazio, said he was not surprised about the high vacancy rate since the G.S.A. was charging higher-than-usual rents for the courthouse. He said that Mr. Lazio, who while in office was instrumental in pushing the Central Islip project through, was offered office space but that the G.S.A. wasn't being reasonable.
"Their rent prices were outlandishly high," Mr. Trepeta said. "Frankly, I don't understand why. The land was donated, the building was completely paid for and here was G.S.A. charging somewhere around $37 per square foot."
G.S.A. officials still don't think it's a loss if agencies don't lease from them.
"It makes no difference whether the agency pays rent to a private landlord or to us," said Cassandra Henderson, a spokeswoman in Manhattan for the G.S.A. "Either way the agency does have to pay rent. If they have a lease with us the money goes back to the federal government, but sometimes that's only a savings of a few dollars. For these agencies to move over to the courthouse would be for the same reason President Clinton had to get commercial space in Harlem -- to make people feel better.
"We needed a courthouse this big," Ms. Henderson said. "Otherwise we wouldn't have built it."
Norman Rosenfeld, an architect in Manhattan, was skeptical. "I suspect that these courthouses are pork barrels probably negotiated by local politicos," he said. "They don't have appropriate context in mind. What they are thinking is monument."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Federal agencies rent 1.4 million square feet on the Island, but the Central Islip courthouse is largely empty. (Maxine Hicks for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Land Of Opportunity For Reverse Commuters 

BYLINE:  By R. S. FLINN 

 BODY:
BY the time Jean-Paul Cass, 29, a patent lawyer who works in Stamford, hits the road at 7:30 a.m., he knows his trip on the Cross-Island Parkway, over the Throgs Neck Bridge and up I-95 to Connecticut will be filled with traffic. The 35-mile ride from Douglaston, Queens, takes him at least an hour each way. Accidents, which seem to happen daily, often stop traffic for miles. Stressed-out drivers weave in and out of lanes. When the weekend comes, his commute doubles.
 "Friday night is god-awful," Mr. Cass said. "It's taken me two and a half hours to get home." 
 He could take mass transit, but because that would involve two trains, a subway and then a cab to the office, that trip would take two hours. Mr. Cass has thought about moving closer to work, but the high cost of housing in the area deterred him. The average single-family home in Stamford costs well over $500,000. Besides, he said, he finds Stamford's night life a bit boring. 
"There's not much going on," Mr. Cass said. "It seems like an older crowd."
Mr. Cass is one of the growing number of people who are commuting into the state. Indeed, the numbers have risen so much that a curious thing has happened: there are now more people from New York and Massachusetts driving on the major highways into Connecticut to work than there are people headed out.
"A lot of the time the road is open completely on the other side," Mr. Cass said, referring to the southbound lanes of I-95.
That road, for example, has the reputation of being clogged with New York-bound commuters in the morning, but the opposite is actually true. Statistics from the Connecticut Department of Transportation show that in June 2001, the latest period for which numbers are available, an average of 16,900 vehicles traveled south on I-95 into New York between 6 a.m. and 10 a.m., but an average of 22,200 vehicles traveled into Connecticut. During the afternoon and evening rush from 3 p.m. to 7 p.m., an average of 17,700 vehicles traveled into Connecticut on I-95, while 24,700 vehicles headed into New York.
David Schrank, a researcher at the Texas Traffic Institute, recently co-authored a study examining traffic congestion nationwide. He said in many parts of the country, reverse commuting has grown to a point where it is almost even with established commutes.
"Traditionally, 60 percent of traffic moves inbound, and 30 to 40 percent moves outbound," Mr. Schrank said. "Now, we are closer to 50 percent each way, due to the fact that people are working in nontraditional corporate centers."
Although the number of commuters traveling into Grand Central in the morning far outweighs the number traveling into Connecticut, reverse ridership on Metro-North is growing as well. Since 1985, the number of people traveling from New York to Connecticut has increased 192 percent. Dan Brucker, spokesman for Metro-North, said the terrorist attacks last year also had a big impact on reverse ridership.
"We had an increase of 20 percent literally overnight after the Sept. 11 attacks," Mr. Brucker said. "That number has softened up a bit to 10 percent over 2001 ridership, but it seems logical that what we have captured at this point will probably stay with us."
Economists said Sept. 11 seems to have accelerated a trend that has been building for decades as suburban office parks lured companies out of Manhattan. Jim Cameron, vice chairman of the Connecticut Metro-North Commuter Council, said he believed the traffic tide turned five years ago when Swiss Bank moved its offices from Manhattan to Stamford.
"They're one of the largest employers in the area," Mr. Cameron said. "There were people who didn't necessarily want to move up here, but could no longer take the train to work," so they commuted by car.
Peter Gioia, an economist at the Connecticut Business and Industry Association, also said many New York companies established offices in the state after the terrorist attacks.
"You see more reverse commuting in part because companies had to diversify the number of sites they had, and there were concerns about business being able to sustain operations if a loss happened," he said.
Experts said there are a number of other factors at work, but the main one, of course, is jobs. Connecticut has the lowest unemployment rate among its neighbors and, in Fairfield County, for example, there are not enough workers to fill the jobs available, even in the weakened economy.
Just over the border in Westchester County, the reverse is true, where there are more workers than jobs. That sends people not only into New York City, but also into Connecticut.
Although there are still not enough jobs in the state for all its workers, (the labor force in October was 1,723,900, but nonfarm employment was 1,669,100), a look at two areas of the state tells a different story.
According to the United States Department of Labor Statistics, the labor force in the Stamford-Norwalk area was 190,900 in October, but the total nonfarm employment was higher at 203,400. In the Hartford area, which includes the surrounding 55 towns and cities, the labor force was 584,600 as of October, with the total nonfarm employment at 604,700. Most of the layoffs of about 3,000 state workers announced last week are not expected to go into effect until January.
The state's neighbors do not have the same balance of jobs and workers. The Westchester County labor force was 452,994, while the total nonfarm employment was 426,300 in October. Springfield, Mass. had a work force of 294,900, but total nonfarm employment of 269,100 in October. In the Providence-Fall River-Warwick, R.I. area, the work force was 584,000, but nonfarm employment was 541,700.
Over all, as of October, Connecticut had an unemployment rate of 4.2 percent, Massachusetts and Rhode Island had rates of 5.2 percent and New York was at 5.7 percent. These numbers ranked Connecticut 13th in the nation for lowest unemployment.
Other factors fueling the reverse commute are lifestyle and the cost of housing in the state's suburbs, especially, again, in Fairfield County. The young people filling many of the state's jobs don't have the financial means, and often the desire, to live in the suburbs.
"Even though the dot-com bubble burst, a bunch of companies moved to the Norwalk area," said John Lyons, president of MetroPool, an organization that promotes mass transit and carpooling. "But the young, talented workers they employ are city-based.
"Sometimes they have a rent-controlled apartment they don't want to give up, but for a lot of people, it's a lifestyle choice. Manhattan has more night life and entertainment."
According to the Consolidated Multiple Listing Service of Connecticut, the average sale price of a single family home in Norwalk was $534,770 during the last six months. That is cheaper than Stamford, which averaged $643,683, and a bargain compared with the average $1.02 million that Westport homes commanded.
Renting an apartment is expensive as well. A worker needs to make at least $47,120 a year, or $22.65 a hour, to rent a one-bedroom apartment in the Norwalk-Stamford area, according to "Out of Reach 2002," a study put out by the National Low Income Housing Coalition. By comparison, a starting teacher in Norwalk with a bachelor's degree and no experience earns $37,000 a year, which is $10,000 less than the rate needed to afford an apartment.
The same study shows that an employee needs to make $40,800 a year to afford a one-bedroom apartment in Westchester County.
Raymond Caine, 46, of Warwick, R.I., a line-chef at the Mohegan Sun Casino, has been making the reverse commute for about 20 years when he worked for Electric Boat in Groton. He said he had no intention of moving to Connecticut because his family is in Warwick. He said he enjoys his hourlong commute.
"It's quite relaxing," he said. "Where I live is very congested, but when I drive to work, there's not much traffic on the road. It's very scenic."
A spokesman for the Mohegan Sun Casino said that of its 9,600 workers, only a small percentage commute from Rhode Island.
Employment numbers show that the New London and Norwich areas, despite the presence of the two casinos, had more workers than jobs. The labor force was 159,800, but nonfarm employment was 145,800 in October.
But of all the areas in Connecticut, the eastern region is expected to have the largest job growth over the next several years. The Connecticut Department of Labor predicted this part of the state, which includes the Danielson and New London labor market areas, will have a 13.6 percent increase in employment from 1998 to 2008.
On one particular day's traffic volume on I-95 last year, 6,765 vehicles came into Connecticut from Rhode Island between 6 a.m. and 10 a.m., while only 4,444 drove in the opposite direction. The number of vehicles coming into Connecticut from western Massachusetts on I-91 is more than 50 percent higher during the morning commute than leaving.
Traffic counts provided by the Connecticut transportation department show that during one week this September, an average of 19,311 vehicles came into the state from Massachusetts a day on I-91 between 6 a.m. and 10 a.m., compared with an average 12,483 vehicles traveling into Massachusetts.
Both Springfield, Mass., and Hartford, have similar unemployment rates, at about 4 percent, but Hartford has twice as many jobs as workers. According to the September edition of the "Connecticut Economic Digest," the city holds 121,533 jobs, but only 52,423 workers. The city fills that gap with workers from the suburbs and from Massachusetts.
"There has been massive growth along I-91 from Enfield to Hartford, particularly in office buildings," said Mr. Gioia, the economist. "One of the things that has attracted companies there are certain people with certain skill sets."
In other words, Connecticut's work force is highly skilled and educated. Clusters of companies chose to set up their operations near these employees, which in turn draws out-of-state workers with these skills to the area as well.
And Connecticut is not talking about imposing a commuter tax on its out-of-state workers, something New York City has proposed. Christopher Bruhl, president of the Southwestern Area Commerce and Industry Association, said having the reverse commuters here in the first place is beneficial to the state.
"To the extent that you pay taxes, but don't consume services, the state is a winner," Mr. Bruhl said, about the reverse commuters paying sales taxes while in the state.
Communities can make out as well, he said, if the tax on commercial real estate where these employees work is larger than the tax on the homes they would live in.
Allan Blair, president and chief executive of the Western Massachusetts Economic Development Council, said that states need to work together. He said, for example, that it is difficult to assess the economies of Hartford and Springfield as separate entities.
He characterized Hartford and Tolland Counties in Connecticut, along with Hampden, Hampshire and Franklin Counties in Massachusetts, as the true economic region. To strengthen it, both states formed a partnership two years ago to attract new businesses and industries.
But despite this characterization, he acknowledged that Hartford County draws more workers into Connecticut than Springfield County does into Massachusetts. He attributes the draw in part because the labor market area is larger in Hartford, and because the city has a greater cluster of industries.
"The state line is permeable; it does not represent a solid border to commerce," Mr. Blair said. "Public policy tends to follow arbitrary lines, but the economy does not."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester; 
Health Centers: Expansion Pressures, Budget Limits

BYLINE:  By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
WITH business brisker than ever and the demand for services expected to rise in the next few years, not-for-profit medical providers like Hudson River Community Health in Peekskill, one of the state's poorest cities, and the Open Door Family Medical Center in Ossining, one of its poorer villages, are struggling.
 "We're caught in a bind," said Anne K. Nolon, president and chief executive of the Peekskill organization. "Throughout the country, many health care centers are feeling the pressure to expand because we're serving 43 million uninsured Americans, but unfortunately, our budgets are not as large as our needs." 
 Unable to meet the costs of new construction, Hudson River Community Health -- which also has offices in Beacon, Amenia, Pine Plains, Dover Plains, Wallkill, Goshen, New Paltz and Poughkeepsie -- recently built a fence around a newly bought lot in Peekskill, placing on hold plans for a medical center serving women and children. 
Bids for new construction came in way over budget, Ms. Nolon said. The nonprofit health provider first opened 27 years ago in Peekskill in a three-story former department store and still has medical facilities there.
In Ossining, Open Door -- which is also in a former department store -- faces similar space limitations, and is grappling with the problem of a limited budget and pressure to expand as well.
Not only are such organizations experiencing a growing demand for services from potential patients, but they must also meet the demands of managed care, which often means providing more examination rooms, among other things, said Lindsay Farrell, president and chief executive of Open Door.
The Ossining nonprofit, which has been serving underinsured and uninsured clients for 30 years, began as a walk-in clinic in the basement of the First Baptist Church, across the street from its present headquarters on Main Street.
It at first occupied only the first floor of the vacant retail store, renting the top two stories for income. One of its tenants was the Westchester County Department of Planning's Office of Urban Renewal, which was working in the late 1970's to rejuvenate the struggling downtown of the Hudson River village.
As the community developed, Open Door's caseload increased -- growing tenfold in three decades to 200 patients a day from 20 in 1972. Over the years the organization took over not only the whole former store but also an adjacent building, a former men's store. That building was torn down in the late 1980's, rebuilt and connected to the first building. In all, Open Door now occupies 22,000 square feet in the village.
It has two other facilities: a 5,000-square-foot satellite office in Sleepy Hollow that was opened in 1986 and an 8,000-square-foot office in Rye Brook that opened seven years ago and serves the Port Chester area. Of the 20,367 clients treated in its three locations last year, 43 percent had no health insurance and paid on a sliding scale. Up to 90 percent of the patients had incomes at or below the poverty line.
Most recently, Open Door spent $1 million -- mostly from fund-raising -- to begin updating its facilities in Ossining. The renovations included adding four medical examination rooms so doctors could see more patients in a given time, as prescribed by managed care.
Worn carpeting was replaced with tile flooring, dental chairs were increased to eight from five, and a family practice-medical unit was created, as were new areas for podiatry and ophthalmology. Administrative and other nonpatient services were moved to the third floor of the building, where three rooms were added for mental health services.
The only public money, $125,000 from the county, was used toward a new elevator to accommodate the many strollers, wheelchairs and walkers coming through the front door every day.
"As a nonprofit, we couldn't afford to get extravagant, so everything had to be done as economically and creatively as possible," said Michael Molinelli, a Briarcliff Manor architect overseeing the project. He said that although more renovations were needed, budget constraints limited how much could be done at once.
Five more examination rooms are needed beyond the existing 12, he said. A laboratory is to be moved from the middle of the first floor, where a large reception area will be created. And medical records housed in part of the first floor -- which has been reinforced twice already to carry the heavy load of all the paperwork -- will be moved to another space.
"Even with a limited budget, we've tried to design a medical building from the patient's point of view," Mr. Molinelli said. "Often when we see clients, they're distressed. The idea is to make everything efficient as well as aesthetically pleasing for them." 
That has meant using natural window light when possible and creating some open spaces, he said. But waiting rooms have been designed to be "small and intimate," he added, "so patients don't feel like they're in a giant cattle pen."
"We certainly don't want to give our clients the feeling that because they're getting this free, they have to settle for less," he said.
Costs for the recent renovations ran about $100 a square foot, Mr. Molinelli said. "The idea," he said, "was to use simple materials cleverly, like laying down vinyl tile in colorful patterns to create visual interest without spending more."
BY comparison, construction costs for private medical practices and upscale finishes run up to $130 a square foot. And while the furniture and finishes may be less expensive, the medical equipment used by nonprofits is, in most instances, the same as that in private medical offices, Mr. Molinelli said.
Hudson River Community Health serves more than 35,000 patients -- including migrant and seasonal workers and immigrant day laborers -- in 100,000 square feet of medical office space in seven counties. About 65 percent of its users have incomes below the federal poverty level, and in 2001 more that 57 percent of its users were uninsured.
The three-story, 66,000-square-foot health center in Peekskill opened with a one-time federal grant of $250,000 and financing from the county. The nonprofit group recently bought a second site in Peekskill, a 24,000-square-foot abandoned gas station, for $350,000 and spent $375,000 more to renovate it, with part of the money paying for environmental remediation of the site. The building is now being used as a health education center.
Half of the center's annual $21 million budget comes from patients and insurance reimbursements. It raises about $100,000 a year in private money. Meanwhile, the federal government is expected to to increase financing for health care centers, but to be eligible for funds, centers like Hudson River Community Health need the space to handle an increased patient load, Ms. Nolon said.
"In more ways than one, we're caught in a bind," she said, describing the center's income as "woefully short" of our needs.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/New Jersey Retail Space; 
In the Market for Shopping Centers, Buyers Line Up

BYLINE:  By ANTOINETTE MARTIN

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH hopes are not very high for retail sales this holiday season, the retail real estate market in New Jersey is merry and bright, some market specialists say.
 "Investment capital is flocking to retail," said Andrew J. Merin, an executive vice president at Cushman & Wakefield, who heads its Metropolitan Area Financial Services Group. "Buyers may be wary of office vacancies and nervous about apartment buildings -- but retail property seems to have moved to the top of buyers' lists." 
 In August, Mr. Merin's group brokered the $53 million sale of the Essex Green Shopping Center in West Orange and the $25.5 million sale of the Village at Bedminster shopping center in Bedminster. "The market hasn't cooled a bit," Mr. Merin said this week. 
Currently, he said, his group is completing the sales of two large retail properties: the Plaza Square shopping center in Wayne and the Promenade retail center in Edgewater. In both cases, contracts have been signed, but the sales have not closed, so the buyers' identities have not yet been disclosed.
The buyers will pay something over $20 million for the 101,000-square-foot Plaza Square, Mr. Merin said. He said there had been 35 purchase offers for the property -- close to twice the number he would have expected a year ago. The 190,000-square-foot Promenade also fetched a price of more than $20 million, Mr. Merin said.
The capitalization rate, the rate of return a purchaser can expect to earn on a property given current interest rates on loans and rent levels, he said, "is only about 8.5 percent. That does not compare favorably with the past."
"And still," Mr. Merin said, "these big transactions keep occurring."
The Marcus & Millichap Real Estate Investment Brokerage Company, a national firm with offices in Fort Lee, reported last week that the median sales price for retail properties in northern New Jersey in the third quarter was $143.52 per square foot. The capitalization rate, which averaged 10.2 percent during 2001, according to Marcus & Millichap, is now below 10 percent as capital has flowed out of the stock market and into real estate investments, allowing sellers to hold prices firm.
Mr. Merin's group is about to begin the formal marketing of another 1 million square feet of retail property: the Starwood Heller portfolio of eight properties in northern New Jersey, among them Linden Plaza in Linden and 440 Commons in Jersey City. Mr. Merin said there had been 160 requests for the information books on the portfolio.
THE team founded by Mr. Merin along with David Bernhaut, who is the executive director, works with owners, developers, corporations, banks and other investors on acquisitions, sales and financing of investment properties. Based at Cushman's headquarters in East Rutherford, it operates in northern and central New Jersey, Fairfield County in Connecticut, Long Island and Westchester County.
A year ago, Mr. Merin said, the Northeast was "not viewed well" for economic growth potential. "In New Jersey," he said, "the office market was still high on the totem pole, then industrial, apartments, and retail was on the bottom."
Potential buyers had lingering concerns about the impact that online shopping would have on retailing, Mr. Merin recalled. "Now, they realize the Internet is not a concern, that people want to go pick out their own head of lettuce and buy their own sweaters," he said.
A year ago, there had also been a rash of bankruptcies by large discount chains that was unnerving to those shopping for shopping centers at the time, Mr. Merin said.
But the retail real estate market in northern New Jersey actually remained one of the strongest in the Northeast this year, according to Marcus & Millichap. Morris County posted a mere 4.2 percent vacancy rate for retail property at midyear. Hudson County had the highest vacancy rate in the state at 9.5 percent, but that was improved from the 13.5 percent at the end of 2001.
Overall vacancy for the northern New Jersey market is projected to be 7.1 percent at the end of 2002, Marcus & Millichap's report said.
Most of the vacancies created by the closing of large stores have been filled by the expansion of other chains, according to various market analysts. Chain stores like Target, Wal-Mart, Home Depot, Kohl's and Lowe's have added stores in New Jersey in the last year, Cushman's analysts said.
Now, there is concern over the potential closing of the Kmart chain, brokers say. Some describe it as inevitable and a bad omen for the future of retail in New Jersey. Others are less sure, or more sanguine.
Richard Brunelli, president of Brunelli & Company, a retail brokerage company in Old Bridge that produces a report on New Jersey retail real estate each spring, said: "One of the major unknowns is what's going to happen with Kmart. If it doesn't do well this season, then the management of Kmart knows it is perhaps the last season. We have projects affected by the prospects of Kmart -- for example, anchor tenants who don't want to commit to moving in or expanding to a location where Kmart might leave a big vacancy."
But Mr. Brunelli said: "People are going to both lose fortunes and make fortunes if Kmart goes out of business. A lot of landlords have Kmart in there, paying $1 to $2 per square foot for huge spaces that could go for way more than that."
Matthew K. Harding, president of the Levin Management Corporation, sees Kmart's possible demise as a chance to "take back" space and to update shopping centers.
"Renovations and upgrading are something any shopping center owner needs to address every 10 to 15 years," Mr. Harding said. "The demands of consumers change, and the requirements of retailers change."
For example, Mr. Harding said, at the North Village Shopping Center in North Brunswick, the former Bradlees store was bigger than other retailers wanted, so the building size was reduced and the remaining space was leased to a Barnes & Noble bookstore; a Bed, Bath, & Beyond, and a Chili's restaurant. In Bridgewater, Mr. Harding's company helped transform a shopping center anchored by a Grand Union supermarket, which is now closed, into a neighborhood center anchored by Barnes & Noble.
"In Woodbridge," Mr. Harding said, "it was being able to get back possession of the Caldor space that allowed us to change the tenor of the St. George Crossing shopping center." Building facades are being renovated and parking facilities redesigned in Woodbridge. ShopRite, PC Richard and a national chain store that Mr. Harding said he was not ready to identify have been recruited. ShopRite, which already had a store in Woodbridge, moved into the 91,000 square feet of the former Caldor space, becoming one of the largest supermarkets in the state, Mr. Harding said.
Community shopping centers anchored by supermarkets are the "best buy" right now for investors, a number of brokers said.
"Larger centers, power centers of 800,000 square feet or more, are also selling," Mr. Brunelli said, "but regional malls have fallen out of favor." 
Mr. Harding said: "I'm bullish on retail, but not power retail, or enclosed malls. At a strip mall, there are the things you have to do and want to do with a quick trip -- a place to get a haircut, a McDonald's, a dry cleaners, etc. If you go into a mall, there are inevitably the luxury items. Nordstrom's, Eddie Bauer, Abercrombie & Fitch -- these are the first guys to get hurt when the consumer is short on cash."
But, as Mr. Merin noted, "even in difficult times, the consumer has to eat."
THERE are thriving supermarkets involved in both the big retail centers that Mr. Merin's team sold a few months ago.
A ShopRite and a Macy's department store anchor Essex Green, which was bought by the Principal Life Insurance Company and is being managed by Levin Management.
The Village at Bedminster, a 110,000-square-foot strip center sold to the Crow Holdings Real Estate Fund, is anchored by a King's supermarket. The site "offers fantastic demographics," Mr. Merin said, "located in a densely populated area with a high average household income -- and limited competition from other food stores within five miles."
Jonathan B. Schultz, president of the Schultz Organization/TCN Worldwide, a real estate services firm in Woodbridge, said his company represented several food-related chains that wanted to expand in New Jersey. Baja Fresh, a high-end Mexican restaurant chain that is opening a new store in East Brunswick, is looking for other new locations in Union, Middlesex, Monmouth, Ocean and Somerset Counties, he said. 
Schultz also represents Save-A-Lot, a supermarket chain that wants to open five stores in Middlesex County.
"Things are cooking," Mr. Merin said of the overall prospects for the retail real estate market, "and I think the feast is going to last well into next year."
