HEADLINE: YOUR HOME; 
At Under 6%, What Do Sellers Get?

BYLINE:  By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
MOST home sellers know by now that the traditional 6 percent real estate commission has basically become the "suggested list price" for real estate listings. And while most brokerage firms still push for a 6 percent commission, the amount the seller and broker finally agree upon can end up being considerably less.
 Beyond the traditional, full-service brokerage firms, a number of companies now offer their services at a variety of commission levels, fixed charges or some combination of the two. The levels of service vary widely, and may or may not provide inclusion on the local multiple listing service. Competition for the home seller's business is taking many forms. 
 "Commission price wars between full-service brokerages have infiltrated real estate markets across the country," Julie Garton-Good, a Miami real estate consultant, wrote in Realty Times, an Internet-based real estate journal. "In an effort to garner a larger swath of market, attract attention and annihilate the competition, many brokerages are slashing fees by 25 percent or more." 
And that's just the "full-service" brokerages. There is also an increasing number of firms that promise sellers will pay less than 6 percent for sales services, including "discount brokers," who will accept flat fees or lower commissions while, they say, providing all or most of the services offered by full-service brokers; Internet-based brokers, who charge flat rates or monthly fees for posting and maintaining "for sale by owner" listings on the Internet; and even "fee for services" brokerages that allow customers to pay only for the services they use.
At one end of the spectrum, said Peter G. Miller, a real estate consultant and author in Silver Spring, Md., are the full-service real estate brokerage firms that would rather let a prospective customer walk out the door than agree to accept less than a 6 or 7 percent commission. At the other end, he said, are services that cater to homeowners who are looking for only a little help in selling their homes themselves.
ForSaleByOwner.com, an Internet-based company, is a good example of the "no frills" style of brokerage.
"We cater exclusively to the for-sale-by-owner market," said Colby Sambrotto, chief operating officer of the company. Mr. Sambrotto said that for $60 a month, homeowners with houses to sell can advertise their property on the company's Internet site. "You can post color photos, virtual tours, a mapping function and a 2,000-word description of your house," he said, adding that for $219 the company offers a six-month package that includes yard signs and directional signs that can be used to point prospective purchasers to the house.
For $699, the company provides the same services as the six-month plan and says it will have a listing placed on the multiple listing service -- though in that case the seller must agree to pay the buyer's agent the traditional 3 percent of the sale price. With agents in major markets in all 50 states, Mr. Sambrotto said, the company can usually place a listing in a local M.L.S.
Another company that charges a flat rate for its services is Assist-2-Sell, based in Reno, Nev. 
Ryan Elliott, franchise director for the company, said that for a flat fee of $2,995, paid when the house is sold, Assist-2-Sell customers get virtually all the services provided by a full-service broker except for a listing in the local M.L.S. 
"We advertise the property, we show the property, we negotiate with the buyer and we do all the other things that a normal realtor would do," Mr. Elliott said. He maintained that in areas where there is a strong seller's market, an M.L.S. listing is often unnecessary. 
Those who want an M.L.S. listing, he said, can have one. "We offer an M.L.S. program," Mr. Elliott said, explaining that while the company charges a 4 or 4.5 percent commission for that program instead of a flat rate, the agent who brings the buyer to the property will get his or her standard 3 percent share out of the commission.
"We're the ones working at a discount," he said. "So we're not going to ask the buyer's agent to work at a discount too."
A particularly active discount brokerage firm in the New York City area is YHD Foxtons, a company in West Long Branch, N.J., that has offices in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
Glenn E. Cohen, president and founder of YHD Foxtons, said that the company has services at various commission rates, with the most popular being the 2 percent level. For that, he said, homeowners who list their property get virtually all the marketing services typically offered by traditional brokers, with the exception of M.L.S. listings. "We advertise in every major newspaper; we're on billboards, buses and on the radio" and on the Internet, Mr. Cohen said.
He explained that once a homeowner contacts YHD Foxtons, a local agent visits the home, provides a market analysis and agrees on services and pricing. Once the property is listed, a "property coordinator" is sent to the home to take pictures, put up signs, and create the "virtual tour" of the house that buyers will see on the company's Internet site. "When a buyer calls up and wants to see the house, we make sure that they've taken the virtual tour before we have the owner show the home," he said, adding that by having the owner show the home, YHD Foxtons has eliminated one of the most expensive aspects of traditional brokerage.
"Anybody can show a house," he said. "So we've eliminated the one job that's both labor intensive and unnecessary. Buyers know what they want, and nobody can convince someone to buy a house he doesn't want." 
Mr. Cohen added that if the homeowner does not feel comfortable showing the home, YHD Foxtons will do so for an additional commission of 1 percent. And if the seller wants the home in the local multiple listing system, he said, the company charges 4 percent and splits the commission with the broker who brings the buyer to the property.
Another low-cost brokerage is Help-U-Sell, a national company based in Syosset on Long Island.
"We're within the discount realm, but we're not a discount broker," said Rick O'Neil, president of the company. "We can charge less because we unbundle our services."
For example, Mr. O'Neil said, sellers who are willing to show their home themselves -- and let Help-U-Sell negotiate with prospective buyers and then shepherd the deal through to closing -- can sign up for a $2,950 package.
"And if you don't want to show the house yourself, we will charge you the flat fee plus a showing fee," he said, adding that the showing fee in the New York City area runs about 1.5 percent of the sale price. Inclusion in the local multiple listing system, Mr. O'Neil said, can also be arranged, with the understanding that the buyer's agent ends up with the standard 3 percent share.
Jack Hopkins, an associate broker with Century 21 Family Realty in East Northport, said that it is probably a good idea for discount brokers to ensure that when a home is put into the M.L.S., the buyer's agents get the commissions they are accustomed to.
"When you're looking at a listing, and you see that the buyer's agent's share of the commission is 2 percent, you're more likely to show another house that brings you 3 percent," Mr. Hopkins said. He added that it was also unlikely that a seller's agent who is working for 1 percent or less was going to work as hard -- or spend as much on advertising -- as an agent working for more. "It's economics, and it's human nature," he said. 
Dexter Guerrieri, president of Vandenberg Real Estate in Manhattan, said that while the low commissions offered by discount brokers may be attractive to some sellers, most of his clients seem to understand that a reduced commission often results in reduced service. "Out of my 13 current listings, nine are at 6 percent," Mr. Guerrieri said. "So even with the intense competition in Manhattan, most of our clients are not prepared to sacrifice quality service for a low commission." 
Reflecting on the variety of choices available to home sellers, Mr. Miller, the real estate consultant, said: "It has long been understood that there is no such thing as a standard commission. So if you're a consumer, the real question is what package of services you will be getting for a given number of dollars."

HEADLINE: The Paper Mill May Be Singing A Different Tune 

BYLINE:  By JILL P. CAPUZZO

DATELINE: MILLBURN 

 BODY:
MOVE aside "South Pacific." "Waiting for Godot" is coming to town.
 Maybe the shift will not be that dramatic, but if the leading contender for the top job at the Paper Mill gets it, there could be big changes in the kinds of productions put on at New Jersey's state theater, long renowned for its lavish musical revivals, but also criticized for its emphasis on the tried-and-true. 
 Paper Mill board officers and theater management met last week with Michael Gennaro, a former Broadway actor, entertainment lawyer and currently the executive director of the Steppenwolf Theater Company in Chicago, to sound him out for the job of chief executive and president. He would replace Angelo Del Rossi, 69, who is to become an executive producer focusing on fund raising. Despite a recent announcement that Paper Mill would conduct a national search for Mr. Del Rossi's successor, Mr. Gennaro appears to be the only candidate in serious contention. 
"For the moment, there is no one else we're talking to," said Mr. Del Rossi, predicting that it would take three to six months before his replacement is hired.
Mr. Gennaro, who his assistant said was traveling, did not return telephone calls.
Founded 63 years ago, Paper Mill has 1,200 seats and is one of the largest theaters in the state. Mr. Del Rossi has spent 40 years there, the last 27 at the helm. His departure from the top job is part of a series of recent changes as the theater tries to attract new, younger audiences and corporate sponsors, and to cope with sour economic times.
This summer, the theater considered restructuring its management, and Mr. Gennaro met with its leaders then, but no changes were made. This spring, Robert Johanson, the artistic director, resigned after his elaborate productions were blamed by some for the theater's financial woes.
Paper Mill has had financial difficulties for awhile; for much of the past year, it has been trying to get its financial house in order by co-producing shows with other theaters, eliminating high-salaried staff and cutting production costs. The result was a profitable season last year and a chipping away at substantial debt. 
"The process we have been through in the last six months has been very cathartic," said Kenneth Thorn, the board's vice chairman.
Mr. Thorn described this as the most significant turning point for the theater since Paper Mill had to rebuild after a fire nearly destroyed it in 1980.
"The fire created a break from the Carrington years," he said, referring to Mr. Del Rossi's predecessor, Frank Carrington, the theater's founder. "Now we've reached the point where we have to have a new vision."
If Mr. Gennaro is the chosen one, that vision could be very different, based on his experience at Steppenwolf, where he oversaw the production of 12 major world premieres, some of which moved to theaters in London, Ireland and Australia.
Founded in 1976 by the actors Gary Sinese, Terry Kinney and Jeff Perry, the ensemble-driven Steppenwolf has developed a reputation for introducing world premieres and riskier interpretations of classics. This season's line-up, for instance, includes William Saroyan's "The Time of Your Life," and Tony Kushner's "Homebody/Kabul," among other productions, on its Mainstage, and three world premieres on the smaller Studio stage. This is a far cry from the traditional formula of Paper Mill.
Mr. Del Rossi acknowledged that the two companies are different. As to how Mr. Gennaro would fit into the Paper Mill mold, Mr. Del Rossi responded: "Producing is producing. It's just on what scale you do it."
New Jersey's tight-knit theater community has been abuzz with the prospects of Mr. Gennaro's returning here. The son of the Broadway choreographer Peter Gennaro, Mr. Gennaro was a manager at George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick and executive director of Pennsylvania Ballet before going to Chicago. Jeffrey Woodward, managing director at Princeton's McCarter Theater, called Mr. Gennaro a "smart manager" who would be a "great addition to the Paper Mill team." Regarding the potential competition from someone used to staging the kinds of avant-garde productions typically associated with McCarter, Mr. Woodward saw it as no threat to his theater.
"We're about 40 to 50 miles apart," he said. "Our programming is very different. We're not competing for individual donors or foundation giving. It's really better if everybody's healthy. It only makes it better for us."
When Mr. Gennaro met with Paper Mill executives this summer, he was part of a team put together by the Broadway producer Marty Bell, who was considered for a new position of managing producer. Despite a strong push from Mr. Thorn and Edward Marlowe, the board's chairman, Mr. Bell did not get the job.
"He has a terrific vision, but it's pointed more toward Broadway than the theater wants to be at this point," said Mr. Thorn of Mr. Bell.
A Broadway producer with successes that include "Kiss of the Spider Woman," "Ragtime" and "Fosse," Mr. Bell said he had a two-year plan for Paper Mill, centering around the theme of "an American century of shows."
"There's a strong contingent that really likes the Paper Mill and doesn't have a sense of where it stands in the national picture," Mr. Bell said. "But if they want to clean up their fiscal problems and be attractive to funders, the place has to change its image. If it doesn't, it will continue to be seen as a glorified summer stock theater."
Mr. Del Rossi, though, said he expected the formula of four musicals and two plays per season to continue.
"I don't think there should be any drastic change," Mr. Del Rossi said. "As the state theater of New Jersey, we have a certain responsibility to bring entertainment and pleasure to our audiences."

HEADLINE: When a Job Hunt Is Measured In Seasons or Even a Year 

BYLINE:  By ANNE FIELD 

 BODY:
FOR eight months now, Laurie Windrow has spent 50 hours a week in the dogged pursuit of one goal: finding a job. And no one is more surprised than Ms. Windrow, 40, at her predicament. With a high-powered resume, including stints as director of sales administration at MGM and vice president for international sales, marketing and business development at the Discovery Channel, she never dreamed her search would take so long.
 Laid off in the aftermath of Sept. 11 from a job as a senior vice president of Razorfish Studios, a small Manhattan media company, Ms. Windrow spent her first three months of unemployment just trying to get people to return her calls. Since then, she has met with perhaps 200 people, written hundreds of letters and come close to landing four jobs; in every case, the companies suspended their hiring plans at the last minute. 
 "In the past, I just went from one job to the next," she said. She takes cold comfort in the fact that half her friends are also unemployed.
Ms. Windrow's frustration is understandable. It used to be that laid-off professionals had an easier time of finding jobs, even in rough economic times, than less-skilled blue-collar workers, but that is changing. In October, white-collar workers -- defined as managers and professionals as well as technical, sales and administrative support -- made up about 49 percent of people who have been unemployed for six months or longer, up from 39 percent five years ago and the highest proportion since the federal government began tracking the groups in 1982, according to an analysis of Bureau of Labor Statistics numbers by the Chicago outplacement firm Challenger, Gray & Christmas.
Similarly, for the first nine months of the year, the portion of unemployed professionals and managers who have been "between jobs" for half a year or more grew to an average of 16.6 percent, a record, up from 11.6 percent in 1997.
And while no separate figures for the New York City metropolitan area exist, employment experts say the problem may be even worse here. "People who come to me are unemployed for longer periods of time than I've ever seen," said Alexandra Duran, a business coach who has been counseling clients since the early 1990's. That is partly because so many New York area industries, from financial services to media and publishing, have been hit particularly hard in the wobbly economy.
Furthermore, with so many job seekers out there, it is taking employers longer to sift through the avalanche of job applications they get. Jeff Heath, president of the Landstone Group/MRI, an executive recruiter in New York, estimates it takes employers 30 percent longer to make hires than it did two years ago. He advises clients to expect their job search to last a year, instead of the three to six months that was the rule of thumb for the last 20 years. And, as Ms. Windrow has discovered, budget-conscious employers often wind up not filling the job at all.
For people armed with impressive resumes and letters of recommendation, the endless waiting can come as a shock. "When you're used to being highly successful, this is an unusual and difficult experience," said Kaarli Tasso, who was laid off from a senior management job at an Internet consulting company in the summer of 2001 and is still unemployed.
As a morale booster, in the fall of 2001, she joined the Five O'Clock Club, a career-counseling network in New York. Once a week, she meets with a counselor and a group of other unemployed professionals to share job-hunting techniques, give one another advice and moral support and just spend time with people who are in the same boat.
Many people in that boat are discovering that the job hunt can test their resourcefulness every bit as much as their old jobs did. Perseverance paid off for Leonard Salis, a 32-year-old lawyer who lost his job with a small firm in November 2001 after just three months. At the time, he was determined to limit his search to corporate work instead of his old specialty, litigation, no matter how long it took.
Nine months later, Mr. Salis saw an ad for a job at a law firm that described the firm's areas of specialty, but did not give its name. However, the ad offered some clues, like the initials of a contact and a fax number, and after a few hours of sleuthing on the Web, he figured out the firm's identity. In reading up on it, he learned that it did a fair amount of franchising law, an area he knew nothing about.
Mr. Salis landed an interview and spent the day before reading everything he could about franchise law. The next morning, when his interviewer asked him for his relevant experience, he confessed he had none, but recounted what had happened and talked knowledgeably about the cases he had just studied. Thanks in part to his initiative, he got the job.
No display of ingenuity can guarantee a happy outcome, of course. Ms. Windrow, for example, has taken to scouring the Web for news of job changes; when she learns of something promising, she writes the departed employee's boss. Thus far, however, it has not paid off.
For many people, desperation can lead to compromise. Increasingly, professionals and managers are accepting salaries that are 15 percent to 20 percent below what their previous job paid, according to Tony Lee, editor in chief of CareerJournal.com, a Web site of The Wall Street Journal. They are also becoming more open to the idea of relocating. Mr. Lee cites the case of a computer industry executive he knows who swore when he was laid off 11 months ago that he would not leave the New York area. Now, he says he would be happy to move anywhere in the United States.
Likewise, after yet another promising job lead turned sour a few months ago, Ms. Windrow reluctantly decided to start looking in California and is even considering moving overseas.
The long-term unemployed are also showing more willingness than before to accept short-term stints. After she lost her Internet job last year, Ms. Tasso took the summer off, figuring that with her physics degree from Harvard, study program at the Yale University School of Engineering and experience in running technology projects, she would find a job quickly. Then came Sept. 11, and unable to find employment, she started looking for project work.
The Enron debacle spelled an opportunity for her to use her mathematical and computer skills to do risk-management analysis for companies looking to avoid being audited, and she is now on her second long-term project.
Paradoxically, the very grind of an extended job hunt can have a therapeutic effect on people whose lives are thrown into turmoil by the uncertainty of their prospects.
"You begin to feel that your whole life is arbitrary, out of control," said one 57-year-old executive who has been out of work since June and who insisted on anonymity. "The only control you have is the ability to maintain the discipline of the search."

HEADLINE: POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; 
A Political Quake In Bergen County

BYLINE:  By GEORGE JAMES

DATELINE: HACKENSACK 

 BODY:
THE gray sameness of the county building looming over the frayed downtown here masks the churning these days within its hallways, ground zero in a demographic shift.
 For the first time in the 16-year existence of the post of county executive, a Democrat is about to take the reins. And for only the second time in 20 years, Democrats will also dominate the freeholder board in the state's most populous county and one long considered a bastion of Republicanism. 
 The numbers tell part of the story. Bergen County is now home to 108,477 registered Democrats as against 102,217 Republicans. And in the November election, Democrats outspent Republicans $3 million to $1 million in the most expensive set of races the county had ever witnessed. 
Several weeks ago, one department head tried to ease the concerns among some staff members who are about to face the harsh reality of politics: to the victims go the spoils.
"I told them: 'Be proud. Show people what you do. They'll want more of it,' " he recalled.
But when someone asked what would happen if that did not work, he had no answer. Still, the department head, who requested anonymity, tried to be upbeat.
"This is called democracy," he said. "In Latin America, they shoot each other."
Although none of the county's 2,300 workers face that fate, their tight little world, centered in the county administration building at One Bergen Plaza here, has sustained a seismic shock.
The fact that Dennis McNerney -- the 35-year-old municipal finance banker and two-term freeholder who is about to take over as county executive -- campaigned on the promise of cutting the county payroll by 10 percent has only served to increase the anxiety .
"The basic mood in the immediate aftermath of the election was shock and depression," said Thom Ammirato, press secretary for William Schuber, who is stepping down as county executive after 12 years. "For people who had been there a long time, the prospect of losing really didn't seem very real, and with the suddenness of the loss, it immediately started dawning on everyone, 'What do I do now?' "
Mr. Ammirato went on: "Now suddenly you're watching every dollar; the economy is not great; the job prospects are not as good as they could be. Now you have to go through this sudden change and you've got less than two months to do it, and that's during the holiday season."
Like many county employees, the 46-year-old Mr. Ammirato, a former newspaper reporter and father of three, will lose his medical benefits along with his job with the change of administration in January.
"My son was hospitalized for a kidney ailment earlier this year for four days that cost $8,000," he said. "If that happens again, that's going to be a blow."
To be sure, not every county employee is facing dismissal. But for about 60 to 70 employees who have what is known as "unprotected positions" not covered by civil service or unions -- a group that includes department heads and deputies -- life could change drastically.
A spokesman for Mr. McNerney, Bill Maer, declined to comment on how many employees faced the loss of their jobs.
A transition team assembled by Mr. McNerney after the election and headed by Valerie Vainieri Huttle, a freeholder, is expected to submit a report by Friday with recommendations on the structure and duties of the various county departments.
"We do not anticipate massive layoffs," said Mr. Maer. "At some point, there will be job reductions, which will hopefully be done through attrition and early retirement buyouts."
Yet those assurances offered little comfort. Even those in protected positions are feeling a bit unnerved by the knowledge that they could be transferred or relegated to lower-paying positions.
"There is a feeling of sadness among many people," said Leonard P. Kaiser, who was Mr. Schuber's assistant for municipal and labor relations and chief of staff for his predecessor, William McDowell, for two years. "You run the emotional gamut: you're scared; you're unhappy. You just have to keep faith and go about taking care of business."
For the 54-year old Mr. Kaiser, Election Day was what he termed "black Tuesday." With the loss of Henry P. McNamara, 67, an assemblyman, to Mr. McNerney, Mr. Kaiser faces not only the loss of his job, but that of his wife as well. Barbara Kaiser serves as director of special events for the county.
To make matters worse for Mr. Kaiser, who has served as mayor of North Arlington for 20 years, he lost that race as well.
As for Adam L. Strobel, 37, chief of staff for policy for Mr. Schuber for the last 12 years, he said he was sorry that he would not be around to take on such projects as creating an open space trust fund, modernizing the county jail and building a permanent county building that the current administration had completed.
But for all of that, Mr. Strobel, who has two daughters, 6 and 3, must get another job quickly.
"I'm looking and trying to network with as many people as possible," he said. "I spent all my professional career in government and I'm trying to understand how to take all those years of experience and transfer that to either a private entity or governmental agency."
The Republican Party has been wrestling to put up a safety net.
"I've tried to help people with different agencies and authorities to get them spots in different areas with the same pension plan," said James J. Sheehan, chairman of the Bergen County Republican Party. "Some have severe medical situations in their families."
Now it is up to Mr. McNerney, who vowed to cut patronage, to fill county jobs. "Mr. McNerney is looking to fill Bergen County government with the brightest, most talented individuals to serve the needs of the citizens of the county," Mr. Maer said.
Mr. Kaiser -- who has no doubt regarded himself that way -- said without rancor that losing a job was just a fact of political life.
"You have to be a realist," he observed. "Sometimes you get the bear, and sometimes the bear gets you."

Strobel, a county policy chief, is among those looking for work. (Photographs by John W. Wheeler for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COPING; 
Vast Possibilities, and a Buck Tip

BYLINE:  By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS 

 BODY:
IN the year 1993, a man named John, then in his early 20's, went to the opening of a film at Planet Hollywood on West 57th Street. He noticed that the coat checkers seemed to be doing O.K. As an artist, John had been hired and fired from his share of jobs. So he thought to himself: "When I get fired from my next job, I guess I'll be a coat checker."
 To John, the overcoats represented a financial future. Not long after, he got his first coat-checking job. He acquired a good idea of the true value of such a concession through his experience. Over time, he became the lessee of several coat-check concessions in New York. By supplying these establishments with coat-check boys and girls distinguished by their helpful dispositions, he supported himself handsomely while still engaging in art, his true metier. Only an experienced hat-check boy could understand the vastness of the possibilities. 
 If elements of John's story sound vaguely familiar, that's because I plagiarized them, with modifications, from A. J. Liebling's New Yorker article, "Your Hat, Sir?" in The New Yorker of April 16, 1938.
Herewith, slightly abbreviated, the original, better-written version: "In the year 1904, a man named Harry Susskind, then in his early 20's, looked through a window of Captain Jim Churchill's crowded restaurant at 46th Street and Broadway. He noticed that the male patrons laid their overcoats and hats on chairs and balanced their walking sticks precariously against tables. . . . To Susskind, the overcoats represented a financial future. He went in and proposed that Captain Churchill set aside a corner of the vestibule for coat racks. . . . Churchill accepted Susskind's offer on the spot, and the young man became the first lessee of a hat-check concession in New York. . . . Susskind had a good idea of the true value of such a concession because he had worked as a hat-check boy, in pea jacket and tight pants, at the Cafe Martin on Fifth Avenue . . . . "Only an experienced hat-check boy could understand the vastness of the possibilities."
What is remarkable about Liebling's story is that in 100 years, not much has changed. John, presumably like Harry Susskind, is a real person, a kind of Deep Throat of the coat-check industry. I consulted him by cellphone last week, as the city was engulfed in a deep freeze. I had spent the previous night on the town, the kind of debauchery that reporters like me, with husbands, children and much more puritanical mores than were common in "The Front Page" days, rarely if ever indulge in. 
Liebling, I'm sure, had the advantage of copious first-hand experience. I avoid checking my coat at all times. My excuse is that I have to be able to retrieve it quickly, so I can dash off to the next fire. Arriving at Guastavino's, a modern restaurant under the 59th Street Bridge, I did not check my North Face parka (warm at fires and funerals). But the coat-check boy, in tight black T-shirt and matching pants, slipped it out of my hand before I could protest. 
For the first time, I took a close look at the checkers and realized that unlike the women hawking cigarettes and gardenias in 40's movies, who looked like Hollywood starlets, the coat-check crew all appeared to have arrived the night before from very far away. 
Young Doung Topgyal, the head checker, is a 29-year-old Tibetan who came to New York via Nepal five years ago and worked in a chair factory. The scars on his face, he said, are from beatings by Nepalese police. His all-female crew was Ecuadorean and Mexican. 
They were unfailingly polite. In return, as Liebling observed, less than 1 percent of the people who used the checkroom omitted the tip. The ones who didn't tip were women who had neglected to bring their wallets. The standard tip has been $1 for 20 years, despite inflation, up from a dime or quarter in Liebling's day. "It's not much, but I guess all the dollars are going to add up -- that's what people figure," John said. High tippers still give $5, as they did in 1938, and one satisfied customer dropped $13 into the bowl the other night.
By the evening's end, the crew of five had checked 179 coats. Split five ways, the tips came to $48 each. How John profits is a mystery. In the old days, the concessionaire typically paid the restaurant and kept a percentage of the tips. Sometimes, he paid a salary to his workers. "Go work as a coat-check and figure it out," said John, loath to divulge his secrets.
At midnight, Mr. Topgyal rode the R train home to his wife and baby in Woodside, Queens. But first, he handed me my coat. I did not tip. He was as sweet as could be about it. Next time I go to a restaurant, I will check my coat. And leave a tip.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
If Tax History Is a Guide, The Poor Are in Trouble

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
THE road to tax policy reform is paved with good intentions, or so it seems. Republicans in Congress and the White House are proposing changes to the income tax that could indeed lead to a more productive economy. The resulting tax code could also be more slanted against the poor than at any time in history. And judging by the Republicans' record, there's not much hope that they will address those crushing side effects.
 Most of the Republicans' proposals aim to improve incentives for working and saving. A flat rate for the personal income tax, for example, might be set somewhere between the current lowest and highest rates. The change would make it more attractive for high-earning -- and presumably highly skilled -- people to work more. 
 Another idea -- abolishing the tax on earned income and replacing it with a national sales tax -- could also lead people to work harder. It would almost certainly make collections easier, because tax returns would become much simpler and most retailers already collect sales tax.
Republicans are also talking about doing away with three taxes that affect the return on investments: the tax on corporate profits, the double tax on dividends and the tax on capital gains.
No one really knows who bears the burden of the tax on profits, but economists are pretty sure that it makes investing in companies less attractive. After companies pay the tax on their profits, many give investors part of the remainder as dividends. When investors receive the dividends, the money is taxed again. The total tax rate on dividends can amount to about 60 percent, shrinking the return for saving and investing.
The other part of most investors' return -- how much their stocks increase in value -- is cut by 20 percent by the tax on capital gains. By taking a share of gains and giving credits for losses, the tax also guards speculators from stocks' full riskiness. Ending it could encourage saving and help expose investors to the market's true fluctuations.
To achieve the most efficient of all possible economic worlds, all of these ideas would probably be good ones. Yet all of them would also shift the burden of taxation toward the poor and away from the wealthy.
Thanks to personal income tax rates that rise with incomes, many Americans may have the impression that the United States has an extremely progressive tax system. That is not the case.
In fact, the last comprehensive study of the ultimate burdens of taxation, completed in 1985, showed that the entire tax and transfer system, including personal and corporate taxes and government subsidies and entitlements, had virtually no effect on the distribution of income in the United States. In the years since that study, completed by Joseph A. Pechman, who spent 22 years directing the Brookings Institution's program for economic studies, tax rates applying to the wealthy have fallen substantially.
If anything, the current tax system is one tipped in favor of those happy few who already control most of the nation's income. Only during part of President Dwight D. Eisenhower's term, in the mid-1950's, was the tax system ever as unfavorable to the disadvantaged as it might be in the Republicans' ideal future.
SOME in the Republican leadership appear willing to consider ways to ensure that the rich would not get richer at the expense of the poor. More changes, including exemptions from a national sales tax (as suggested by the retiring House majority leader, Representative Dick Armey of Texas) or enhancing Medicaid and the earned-income tax credit, could help to level the playing field.
If history is any gauge, though, it's unlikely that these considerations will dominate the Republican agenda. Since the individual income tax began in 1913, the top marginal tax rate has risen only once under a Republican president (who was the current president's father). The rate has fallen seven times under Republicans and twice under Democrats, who also raised it six times. If someone is to come to the rescue of the poor, it probably won't be President Bush.
This history makes plenty of sense. Republican voters are generally better off than Democrats. They are less likely to receive Medicaid or the earned-income tax credit and more likely to collect dividends and pay top marginal tax rates. Moreover, people usually underestimate the chances that they'll ever need public assistance. And the poorest people are the least likely of all Americans to vote.
The current tax system is far from perfect, from an economist's point of view, but it is not patently unfair. Can the Republican leadership be trusted to balance useful changes with concerns about inequality? Stay tuned.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 15, 2002

 CORRECTION:
The Economic View column last Sunday about the possible impact of Republican tax proposals misstated one by Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the retiring House majority leader. He proposed exempting portions of certain individuals' income from a flat tax, not exempting their purchases from a national sales tax.

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.; 
Success Stories in Places Where Few Funds Dare to Go

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
THE best-performing emerging stock market so far this year is Pakistan's, up 82.3 percent. Filling out the top four are Argentina, up 57.2 percent; Venezuela, 49.1 percent; and Colombia, 44.7 percent.
 Considering the circumstances, that is some performance. Pakistan is in the middle of the war against terrorism as an ally of the United States. Argentina has had five presidents in the last year and is in its fourth year of recession. In Venezuela, President Hugo Chavez was ousted temporarily earlier this year and faced strikes against his government last week. 
 Participating in those countries' markets has not been easy for most American investors. But that turns out to be a lucky break for Americans who might have been interested in buying stocks in two of them -- Argentina and Venezuela.
When these markets' gains, in local currencies, are translated back into dollars, they become losses of 56 percent for Argentina and 14.2 percent for Venezuela, through Thursday, according to country indexes of Morgan Stanley Capital International.
In Colombia, the market is still up 18.6 percent in dollar terms, even though a decline of 18.1 percent in the peso reduced stock gains there by more than half. But even that return looks good compared with the 21.6 percent decline in the MSCI index for the United States. In Pakistan, the rupee rose 2.7 percent against the dollar, pushing the market's return to 87.1 percent.
Two ways to play such markets disappeared in 2001 with the shuttering of closed-end mutual funds for Pakistan and Argentina. And while investors can buy some stocks in all four countries through American depository receipts, picking stocks in emerging markets is always difficult.
Gaining exposure though open-end mutual funds is difficult, too, because big funds do not dabble much in these countries.
"If you can play these markets, with their high volatility, for a bounce, that is one thing," said Gary P. Motyl, chief investment officer at the Templeton Institutional Group. "To find a stock with a longer-term outlook is another." Because Templeton wants that longer-term view, Mr. Motyl said its institutional funds own no stocks in Pakistan, Colombia and Venezuela and have minimal exposure in Argentina.
The Templeton Developing Markets Trust, a $1.5 billion fund available to individual investors and led by Mark Mobius, who has proselytized for emerging markets, had no holdings in Pakistan, Colombia or Venezuela at the end of October. Its Argentine exposure was less than 1 percent.
According to the most recent data from Morningstar Inc., only one mutual fund has any investments in Pakistan and only five own stocks in Colombia. Even regional funds focusing on Latin America pay little attention to Colombia: of the 10 regional funds, only three have investments there. 
More funds are invested in the bigger Argentine and Venezuelan markets, but even those numbers have dwindled. Of the 83 funds that can choose these markets, only 23 are in Venezuela and 37 in Argentina.
Then there is the Acadian Emerging Markets fund, which Morningstar says is the only fund to own stocks in Pakistan; it also has investments in Colombia, Venezuela and Argentina. "We are looking for markets where there is potential for changes in the fundamentals and low valuations," said John Chisholm, co-chief investment officer of Acadian Asset Management.
Acadian owns one stock in Pakistan, Pakistan Telecommunication; four in Colombia, including Banco de Bogota and the brewer Bavaria; three in Venezuela, including the telecommunications company known as CANTV; and three in Argentina, including the pipe maker Siderca.
The fund, with $43 million in assets, is up 4.9 percent for the year and has done better than 98 percent of its emerging-markets competitors. The fund has placed a big bet on Colombia, with 4 percent of the fund's assets there, far above Colombia's weighting of 0.10 percent in the MSCI emerging market index. About 1 percent of its assets are in Pakistan, compared with the MSCI weighting of 0.22 percent.
Those two bets have been good for investors, providing one-quarter of the year-to-date return.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS: DIARY; 
A Bumper Crop For Tree Sales?

BYLINE:  By Vivian Marino 

 BODY:
After a strong start, many retailers have turned cautiously optimistic about the holiday shopping season. But they're not the only ones feeling hopeful these days: sellers of natural Christmas trees are also predicting healthy sales. 
 The National Christmas Tree Association in St. Louis estimates that 33 million to 35 million real trees will be sold around the country this year, based on a poll of about 1,000 consumers conducted in late November. About 28 million trees were sold last year, it said. 
 Jim Corliss, the trade group's president and the owner of a tree farm in Newburgh, Me., said that while the weak economy had caused many people to cut back on big expenses, like travel or dining out, they were turning toward more traditional holiday activities. 
The poll found that 82 percent of Americans planned to display a Christmas tree this year, up from 76 percent last year.
Of course, some homes will have more than one tree -- like the White House. Last week, George and Laura Bush were presented with an 18-foot noble fir that was grown by a family in Washington State and chosen with the help of the association. That tree stands in the Blue Room. Vivian Marino

HEADLINE: Fighting an Old Fight 

BYLINE:  By DENNY LEE 

 BODY:
WEDGED between the Columbia, a luxury high-rise, and the Royal York, a rundown single-room-occupancy hotel, is a flower and fruit garden. This little patch, known as the Lotus Garden, is perched atop a parking garage on West 97th Street near Broadway, and although the soil is less than four feet deep, it supports two koi ponds, a handsome peach tree, a spray of rose bushes and herbs, and some Boston ivy.
 But not everything in this community garden is so lovely. On a recent visit, its president, Mary Sherman Parsons, rattled off a list of items she has found there in recent months: hypodermic needles, crack vials, razor blades, dirty toilet paper. Earlier this year, she said, a 4-year-old boy stepped on one of the needles and had to undergo a month of debilitating treatment to stave off H.I.V. infection. 
 "It's disgusting," Ms. Parsons said as she reached into a garbage can labeled Dangerous Trash and removed a plastic Baggie containing a rotting condom. "The bathrooms don't work," she added, pointing to windows of the Royal York that overlook a quince tree. "So they throw it out the window." 
The Lotus Garden is a symbol of a profound change roiling the Upper West Side: the re-emergence of the single-room occupancy hotel, or S.R.O. 
In the 1960's and 70's, the Upper West Side had perhaps the city's largest concentration of S.R.O.'s, occupied largely by a poor, troubled and sometimes violent population. Growing frustration with the problems these buildings engendered, combined with an increasingly robust economy, helped reduce their numbers sharply. But in the last year, faced with a mushrooming homeless population, the city has resumed placing homeless people, many of them single people with AIDS, in these buildings. 
Although S.R.O.'s are found throughout the city, residents here contend that an unfair number are clustered in their neighborhood. The police in the 24th Precinct, which includes the Upper West Side between 86th and 110th Streets, report that some two dozen S.R.O. shelters fall within the precinct's boundaries, more than in any other in the city. Upper West Siders say they must dodge not baby strollers but aggressive panhandlers, strung-out prostitutes and combative drug dealers.
There is another issue. With the deep tradition of liberalism and social activism on the Upper West Side, S.R.O.'s present a special problem. This recent chapter has sparked a hard look at the community's current character.
"The neighborhood has become very upscale and whiter and less tolerant," said Councilman Philip Reed, who represents the area. "There's a younger generation of people who didn't fight the old fights. And it doesn't sound like there's a lot of tolerance in their voices."

Two Residents, Two Worlds
Tom Sunderland and Mildred Ortega live on either side of the Lotus Garden, but they might as well come from different planets.
Mr. Sunderland, a criminal justice professor who owns a co-op in the Columbia, lives in a building with a concierge, a health club and other trappings of prosperity. A three-bedroom unit with a sweeping view of the Hudson can fetch nearly $1 million. 
Ms. Ortega, a Venezuelan immigrant who lives in the Royal York, makes her home in a structure with dingy linoleum floors, broken windows and cockroaches. Her apartment, no bigger than a laundry room, costs $150 a week.
For years, such contrasts have coexisted on the Upper West Side with relatively little friction. "We have public housing here, and we have no problems with that," said Mr. Sunderland, who has a ponytail and volunteers as an auxiliary police officer. "Things were great."
Ms. Ortega also feels at home, even if she can't afford the $3 lattes at the dozen Starbucks nearby. "I'm a housekeeper," she said proudly, as she eyed the bigger apartments across the street. "I work for them, and they work for Wall Street."
But this balance has been shifting.
For about a year, the city's HIV/AIDS Services Administration has taken over 35 rooms at the Royal York and filled them with homeless AIDS patients. Many have histories of drug abuse and prostitution. Some are frail and nearly bedridden. All are left to their own devices for most of the day, and are wholly unsupervised at night. The 60 permanent residents complain of noise and chaos and say the ruckus is especially bad after 2 a.m., when drug dealers and prostitutes roam the hallways looking for customers, money and a good time. The most that Ms. Ortega and others can do is tack a handwritten notice to the door, declaring, "I do not buy or sell drugs, thanks."
Six blocks north, at the Malibu Hotel on West 103rd Street, the city has taken over about 100 rooms for homeless adults with AIDS since last April. Ever since, neighbors there say, the Malibu has been a mecca for drug dealers and prostitutes. Gangs of young men and women have been seen loitering outside the Malibu and along the Broadway mall, asking for money and harassing passers-by. 
"There's feces in the gutter," said Marlene Lee, a court reporter who lives across the street. "My doorman has seen guys urinating against our building and lighting up crack pipes. Then there was a mugging that I personally heard at 1:30 in the morning. Terrible, terrible screams. It was a delivery guy who was beaten in the face with a battery held in a sock. His screams were like an animal in agony."
Complaints have also been directed at the Frant Hotel on West 101st Street and two other S.R.O.'s where the city's Department of Homeless Services has quietly set up shelters with beds for 88 homeless people. The problems there appear minor compared with those at the AIDS shelters, in part because these buildings house families, not single adults. Still, the rooms are tiny and there are no common areas. 
Neighborhood residents are also angry because of what they see as an issue of equity. The Upper West Side, they feel, is again being asked to bear a disproportionate share of the city's homeless burden. 
"We get all the S.R.O.'s," said Lisa Lehr, co-chairwoman of the West 90's and West 100's Neighborhood Coalition. "You won't find them in the Silk Stocking district."
Figures from the city show a more complex picture. Only 8 of the 199 S.R.O. shelters used by the homeless services agency -- just 4 percent -- are on the Upper West Side. And of the 54 S.R.O. shelters used by the AIDS services agency, only 9 -- 17 percent -- are there. But because those nine AIDS sites are so large, they house 28 percent of the 2,266 AIDS patients currently in S.R.O. shelters. These figures do not include more than 10 S.R.O.'s for the homeless, run by nonprofit agencies, between West 72nd and West 111th Streets. (The total number of sites is hard to ascertain because of confidentially rules, overlap among city agencies and the number of groups and agencies involved in running sites.)

Evolution of a Troubled Place
Paradoxically, many Upper West Side S.R.O.'s were once reputable, even glamorous apartment houses with evocative names, like the Royal York. During and after World War II, these buildings were carved into single rooms to accommodate the single men who flooded into the city. 
For low-income New Yorkers, S.R.O.'s were often the best alternative to homelessness. By the late 60's and into the 1970's, however, increasing crime, much of it drug-related, led to a worsening of conditions inside these buildings. In response, the city encouraged landlords to reconvert more than 100,000 S.R.O. units to full-service apartments, a policy that has haunted the city ever since. The move aggravated a homeless crisis that forced the city to reverse course in 1985 and impose a moratorium on conversions. 
The city put the newly homeless in the leftover S.R.O.'s, using them as welfare hotels. With the crack cocaine epidemic in full swing, these buildings became places of destitution and danger, with drug addicts mingling with the elderly and the mentally unstable. By the late 1980's, AIDS had created another housing crisis, and the city responded by placing homeless AIDS patients in these buildings, creating daunting health and safety issues that the city and the S.R.O.'s were ill equipped to handle.
Upper West Siders were outraged. According to a 1995 report by Community Board 7, which covers the neighborhood, the city squeezed nearly 45 percent of the homeless AIDS population into the blocks between West 92nd and West 112th Streets. When Deputy Mayor Fran Reiter toured the Riverside Hotel on West 109th Street during this period, the police made her wear a bulletproof vest. 
"The conditions were horrible, filthy and infested, not the kind of environment a healthy person should be in, let alone a sick person," Ms. Reiter recalled recently. Soon after her visit, the city imposed a cap on the number of homeless AIDS patients on the Upper West Side.
The image of S.R.O.'s changed yet again during the recent economic boom. Cushioned by a budget surplus, the city began reinventing the S.R.O. by joining with nonprofit groups to build and renovate units that offered more comprehensive services. Instead of "welfare hotels," the buildings would be called "supportive" S.R.O.'s. The concept proved popular. Euclid Hall, for example, a 292-room hotel on West 86th Street that is run by the nonprofit West Side Federation for Senior Housing and includes a drug treatment center, is widely regarded as a neighborhood amenity.
At the same time, a tourist boom was creating a new market for midpriced boutique hotels. Landlords of S.R.O.'s quickly retiled moldy bathrooms, installed air-conditioners and replaced long-term tenants with backpackers willing to pay $150 a night for a room that had netted $10 a day. By 1996, more than half of the Upper West Side's 21 privately owned S.R.O.'s had been converted to tourist hotels or student hostels. The Malibu, once reviled for its drug-infested squalor, was promoted online as a "stylish and comfortable" budget hotel on the "trendy Upper West Side."
Within the last year, the pendulum has swung back once more. The owners of at least seven of these S.R.O.'s, including the Malibu and the Royal York, have asked the city to fill their empty beds with homeless people. While supportive S.R.O.'s remain, there is nothing about the new institutions that echoes that older model.
"After Sept. 11, the whole hotel market collapsed," said Alan Lapes, who owns six S.R.O.'s that have been turned into homeless shelters. "Occupancy was down to 20 to 30 percent. You need at least 65 to 70 percent to break even. I was losing money like crazy." 
At one of his S.R.O.'s, the Ellington Hotel on West 111th Street, the city pays up to $85 a night -- more than $2,500 a month -- to place a homeless family in a cubicle-size room containing three beds, a closet-size bathroom and a one-piece kitchen unit. 
"This is my new business," Mr. Lapes said. "I'm looking for more locations."
Fueling that business is a swelling homeless population. The homeless services agency now works with some 37,000 people, the highest in three years, said Linda I. Gibbs, the agency's commissioner. Her office receives 100 new requests for housing every day. 

The Liberal Dilemma
On the Upper West Side, where a person can make a career out of attending community meetings, the debate about S.R.O.'s has returned to center stage. There are endless town hall gatherings, detailed position papers and new task forces, all devoted to the issue. Community Board 7, which disbanded its S.R.O. Task Force seven years ago, is considering reactivating it.
A typical discussion took place a few weeks ago at a meeting of the community board's Health and Human Services Committee. The two dozen residents who gathered in the board's offices on West 87th Street seemed on edge, unsure whether the city officials who had been invited would actually show up.
"Who wants to buy in a neighborhood with all these S.R.O.'s?" one middle-aged woman demanded. "My property value is possibly and probably being lowered." 
Another person chimed in: "The Upper West Side has been too accepting. We can be liberal, but we don't have to be stupid."
Half the audience nodded in agreement. The other half, including many longtime S.R.O. residents, sat quietly on their hands. 
The tone of the meeting was evidence that in a subtle but significant way, the debate over S.R.O.'s has shifted. 
"Nimbyism on the West Side is a fairly recent phenomenon," said Terry Poe, a tenant organizer at the West Side S.R.O. Law Project, run by the Goddard-Riverside Community Center. "Before, the concern was about driving out long-term, permanent S.R.O. residents. The feeling now is that their neighborhood is being ruined by a high concentration of problematic people."
Part of the change springs from the community's good fortune during the recent economic boom. Luxury housing, upscale restaurants and chain stores pushed north of 96th Street, a traditional dividing line. Stockbrokers joined teachers and writers on co-op boards and in block associations. 
The return of S.R.O.'s also magnified existing worries when the economy turned down. Residents already sensed a rise in panhandling, homelessness and drug dealing. At the same time, the number of officers in the 24th Precinct has shrunk to 140, down from 240 several years ago. 
"What you have is more of a dichotomy," said Kate Krusko, a real estate broker who has lived on West 97th Street for two decades. "The housing stock has improved, and now you have this other layer of homeless shelters coming in. The contrast is greater."
A vocal minority at the community meeting sought to remind their fellow residents of the neighborhood's compassionate roots. This group sees no conflict between wanting a better quality of life for oneself and the same for S.R.O. residents. The real issue, they assert, is not the S.R.O.'s but the lack of social services.
Daniel O'Donnell, the area's incoming state assemblyman, is among those trying to reframe the debate. 
"My major concern has to do with the quality of social services being provided," said Mr. O'Donnell, who lives across the street from the Ellington. "It's noisier at night than it used to be. But when there's no communal space, or a place for kids to play, that tends to spill out onto the street."
When Maryanne Schretzman, a deputy commissioner at the city's homeless services agency, finally arrived, she sought to assure residents that the city did not regard the Upper West Side as a dumping ground for S.R.O. shelters. "Every community is dealing with this," she said at the meeting. "We have record numbers of homeless people entering the system."
The audience was skeptical. "Why not put them where the rich people live?" demanded Luba Tcheresky of West End Avenue, who says she has never felt less safe. "Why not the Upper East Side?"

HEADLINE: A New Eurofestation 

BYLINE:  By JULIA CHAPLIN 

 BODY:
THERE were no celebrities on Wednesday night at Pangaea, a nightclub in downtown Manhattan with African safari decor. Instead, at 2 a.m. the reserved V.I.P. tables were teeming with Europeans drinking bottles of Moet and Ketel One.
 "Look, there's that beautiful girl I met in Monaco last summer," said Jean Bernard Fernandez-Versini, 21, a New York University student from France, who summers on the Riviera, spends winter vacations in St. Barts and took last year off just to party. 
 Mr. Fernandez-Versini's evening had gotten off to a bumpy start. He had canceled his usual 10:30 p.m. dinner with an entourage of models and European friends at Downtown because Giuseppe Cipriani, one of the owners, was in Italy. "It's not the same energy when Giuseppe's not there," Mr. Fernandez-Versini said in a thick French accent. Instead, he rerouted to Serafina on Lafayette Street. 
There he spied a stunning young woman at a long table for 20, and jumped up to whisper to one of the restaurant's promoters, "Can you ask her to come over to my table when I'm finished eating?"
She joined Mr. Fernandez-Versini as soon as he'd washed his last bite down with a Red Bull and vodka. "Come to St. Barts for New Year's!" he proposed.
Yes, those hard-partying jet-setters known to American wags as Eurotrash, who flocked to New York City by the Concordeload in the 1980's sporting black mock turtlenecks, leather pants and sometimes dubious aristocratic titles, are back on the town.
They can be found shelling out $350 for a bottle of Ketel One at reserved tables every Wednesday after midnight at Pangaea, at a party given by Carmen D'Alessio, a Peruvian-born promoter who brought some of the first Europeans to Studio 54 in the late 70's. Elsewhere on Wednesday nights, French, Italians and a few Middle Easterners groove at Lotus, which imports their favorite D.J.'s like Stephane Pompougnac from the Hotel Costes in Paris, and Jack E from the Caves du Roy in St.-Tropez.
A Euro scene also flourishes at Bungalow 8 after 1 a.m. most nights, and at Powder, a new club in the meatpacking district with D.J.'s who spin deafening techno. Later this month Cielo is scheduled to open in the West Village; a dance club, it is inspired by the Pacha club on Ibiza and decorated by the same designer who did the Nikki Beach Club in St.-Tropez. In March, a branch of Buddha Bar, a popular restaurant and lounge in Paris, is to open in the meatpacking district with an Asian jungle theme. (Eurotrash hangouts, apparently, favor a motif of grass huts and tribal masks.)
"This crowd is recession-proof," said Amy Sacco, the owner of Bungalow 8, who said she considers her customers "international," not Eurotrash.
"They're super-high-end, well traveled and don't think twice about spending a lot of money to have a good time," she said. Marc Biron, a member of the first Euro wave, who has resurfaced promoting Euro parties at Estate and Lotus, struck a variation on this theme. "Europeans love to party," he said. "It doesn't matter if they have money or not -- they will always manage to buy a bottle and go out dancing."
The original crowd of up-all-night, no-office-to-go-to Europeans arrived in New York in the late 1970's, fleeing high taxes, unstable economies and kidnappings. Taki Theodoracopulos, the Greek shipping heir-turned-society writer who wrote the "Eurotrash" column in The East Side Express in the early 80's, explained the origin of his tribe.
"The Americans have this rather obscene habit of working," he said. "So when the Europeans came over, you'd look around at a nightclub at 3 a.m., and there'd be 40 Euros hanging around while the Americans had gone to bed at 11:30 p.m. because they had to get up the next morning and go to Wall Street. The term was a little pejorative, but we had a sense of humor about it."
In the early 80's Mr. Biron helped found the Junior International Club, in part to help Europeans vault over the velvet ropes defending clubs.
"There was a whole group of privileged kids coming to New York," he recalled. "Albert of Monaco, Prince Dimitri of Yugoslavia. They wanted to get into all the private and exclusive clubs, and Americans had this reaction.
"Not all the Europeans had money, but it appeared that they all did, because they had brilliant titles and great clothes. So I started holding parties at Regine's and Studio 54, and it was the first time any of them had been allowed in."
After the 1987 stock market plunge, many of the Europeans went home. The scene fizzled. They began trickling back during the 90's go-go years. With the collapse of Silicon Alley and the waves of Wall Street layoffs, New Yorkers have receded from the nightclub world, leaving the Europeans, like pilings at low tide, all the more visible.
"They're partying on as if the Dow was at 11,000," said Serge Becker, a founder of Joe's Pub, who retains some of the love-hate that New Yorkers feel for such out-of-towners in their nightspots.
"It's a totally uninspired, boring crowd," he added. "Yeah, they might pick up the tab, but you still have to hang out with them."
That is a minority report. Regarding the old Eurotrash and the new Eurotrash, the biggest change in perception seems to be that most New Yorkers no longer turn up their noses at them. At a time when Americans including Sean Combs and Jenna Bush have discovered the retro chic of St.-Tropez, many New Yorkers are dropping in on the Euro-flavored club nights, nostalgic for their last beach vacation.
"The stigma of Eurotrash has disappeared," said Mark Baker, an owner of Lotus. "In the last few years it's become cool to associate with Europeans on their turf and be able to drop names of the coolest club in St. Barts. New York went to St.-Tropez last summer, and now St.-Tropez has come to New York."
In the spring, Smirnoff Ice introduced a television commercial in which two American guys hook up with a rich European and end up partying in a limousine and on a yacht and a private plane. As Beth Davies, director of brand public relations for Diageo, the company that owns Smirnoff Ice, explained, "It's timely because the Euro jet-set life has become so prevalent in the media that Americans feel that it's attainable."
Giampiero Rispo, 43, an Italian who was dancing to the French house music at Lotus on a recent Wednesday night in a blue cashmere jacket, said: "Today to be called Eurotrash is not negative. Americans have realized that the lifestyle is a lot of fun and they can be part of it."
Joseph Dahan, 22, who was born in Morocco and raised in France, works in New York in his father's international children's clothing business. Almost every day he goes home from the office, takes a disco nap from 7 to midnight and then goes to Lotus or Powder or Pangaea until 5 in the morning. In the wee hours on Thursday, he sat at Pangaea amid the gazelle antlers, African spears and bongo drummers with several friends he had met in St.-Tropez. A thin blonde in low-waisted jeans and a partly exposed thong walked past.
"How about a glass of Champagne?" he asked, jumping up.
Mr. Fernandez-Versini, who was at a table nearby, said that one of his favorite things about New York is American women. "French girls are better dressed, but they are like Upper East Side girls," he said. "You know: long dates and complicated relationships."
Mr. Fernandez-Versini, who began studying business administration at N.Y.U. this fall, divides his summers between Morocco and St.-Tropez. In the fall he goes to Florence to buy clothes, he said, then to Monaco and to the fashion shows in New York and Paris. His parents own a house in St. Barts, which he visits every year from Christmas through early January. He said he's able to afford the travel and the hard partying thanks to an allowance from his parents.
Nina Nikpour, a 21-year-old New Yorker in a fuzzy white sweater, sat at Mr. Fernandez-Versini's reserved table. "I just love European men in leather pants," Ms. Nikpour said. "American men always talk about how much stuff costs. European men just pay."
Although the stereotype of the party-hearty young European in New York has some truth to it, looks can sometimes deceive. At an art opening on Wednesday in a space in Chelsea Market that is the future site of Zukabar, a tribal theme bar and restaurant to be operated by the owners of Buddha Bar, Aymeric Lombard, a French-Italian investment banker, took in an exhibition called "Lost Worlds." A mostly European crowd made dinner plans on cellphones below the new agey photomontages of Buddhas, glaciers and landmarks like the Eiffel Tower and the Tower of Pisa.
"The big trick about Europeans is that we look like we have more money than we do," said Mr. Lombard, 31, who was neatly dressed in a collared shirt and a crew neck sweater. "You can get very nice, cheap clothes in Naples and look better than Americans who spent thousands on an outfit at Gucci or John Varvatos."
Noni Helms, 26, a German investment banker who moved to New York last year, dresses every evening in a suit, puts his tie in his pocket and heads for the clubs around midnight. He leaves them at about 3:30, pausing to attach his tie, and arrives at work by 4, when the European markets have opened.
"New York is great fun," said Mr. Helms on a recent Wednesday at Lotus, where he was slumped against a modelesque brunette in the back room. "Except I always feel jet-lagged."

To Rub Shoulders With a Euro

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
Online Shopping Is Up, and Prices Can Still Be Down

BYLINE:  By BARBARA WHITAKER 

 BODY:
IN recent years, Internet merchants bent over backward to persuade people to shop online, with many offering deep discounts or promotional gifts like T-shirts and electronic gadgets. While these deals may no longer be necessary -- as shown in the robust online sales figures issued last week -- shoppers can still find Internet bargains this season. They may just have to look a little harder for them.
 "There are deals to be had; they're just not at the price, velocity and depth that they used to be," said Elaine Rubin, the chairwoman of Shop.org, an association of online retailers that is part of the National Retail Federation. 
 Online shoppers are now more likely to find coupons, rebates or free shipping -- deals often resembling what many retailers have been offering offline, industry experts say. While there have also been sales promotions, some have already come and gone: many merchants offered early-bird holiday specials, beginning in November and ending early this month. 
Shoppers who missed these sales, or have neither the time nor inclination to search for bargains, may want to visit one of a growing number of Web sites that do the work for them. These include price-comparison sites, like BizRate.com and MySimon.com, along with a growing number of sites, like Amazing-Bargains.com, FatWallet.com, eDealFinder.com and DealNews.com, that publish information about online discounts and post coupons and rebate information.
Ken Cassar, a retail analyst at Jupiter Research, which tracks Internet sales, says some merchants are choosing to distribute coupons on sites featuring deals, instead of on their own home pages. "The consumer has to work a little bit harder, which is exactly how the retailer wants it," Mr. Cassar said. 
Bargain hunters can also visit one of several Web sites that sell liquidated goods and excess inventory at deep discounts, like Overstock.com and SmartBargains.com. 
"What I think is happening is that the Internet is evolving away from these dramatic discounts across all items into what is amounting to an inventory-clearing mechanism, particularly for clothing," said Joseph T. Abate, an economist at Lehman Brothers who tracks Internet commerce. "Where things are odd-sized or out of season, you're seeing very big discounting."
According to an annual survey that Lehman Brothers conducted in August, prices for merchandise sold online rose 6 percent this year, compared with an increase of 0.8 percent last year. Prices were essentially unchanged for merchandise sold in brick-and-mortar stores. The survey, which has been conducted since 1999, compares prices at online sites, including shipping charges, with prices at traditional stores in New York City. It looks at more than 100 products, from toothpaste to videocassette recorders.
Some of the best online discounts can be found on toys and prescription drugs, according to the survey. Savings were small or nonexistent for products like televisions and VCR's, it found.
ONLINE merchants may be cutting back on sales promotions and discounts simply because they can. Consumers looking for a convenient way to shop, or at least to compare prices, have been flocking to the Internet, and concern about Internet security is declining because many merchants have instituted safeguards to protect credit cards and other personal data.
Over the three-day Thanksgiving shopping weekend, consumers spent $453.4 million online, excluding spending on travel, a 67 percent gain over the period last year, according to a report by comScore Media Metrix, which measures buying from a cross section of 1.5 million Internet users.E-commerce continued to gather momentum on the Monday after Thanksgiving, with sales totaling $231.5 million, up 37 percent from the corresponding day last year. "Black Monday," as that day is known in the retail industry, is the busiest online shopping day of the year, because it is the first day back at work, where many people do their online buying.
Like many other people, Alexander M. Drosin, 33, the president of a New York company that distributes television programs, says he likes to shop wherever he can get the best deal. Mr. Drosin said he found a $300 Ralph Lauren jacket marked down to $100 in a traditional store last weekend.
After spotting many other bargains in stores, he said, "the online retailers are going to have to be a lot more aggressive" to attract customers.
He says he has found a few deals online lately. He bought a Malo cashmere sweater at BlueFly.com, a site that specializes in discount luxury goods. The price was $299, a 62 percent discount from the original price of $795.
Mr. Drosin, who lives in Manhattan, said the best thing about online shopping is its convenience. He says online customer service has been improving, especially when it comes to returns. 
Convenience and low prices may mean little, however, if shipping costs are high. Many online merchants have reduced or waived shipping fees to keep customers from going offline. Amazon.com led the way last summer by reducing the minimum purchase for free shipping to $49 from $99. It later lowered it again, to $25 for certain products. Buy.com offers free shipping with no minimum. BarnesandNoble.com has free shipping with the purchase of two products going to the same location. Target.com has free shipping on its "Gifts from 1 to 92" promotion. And from Tuesday through Dec. 21, Macys.com will offer free shipping for a specific category of gifts each day, like fragrances or cookware.
The Internet also helps people to research and compare prices. Studies show that more than 80 percent of consumers online are using the Internet for that purpose. 
Although the gap between online and offline prices is narrowing, it may still be worth checking the Internet first. Savings on big-ticket products, which can be easily identified through comparison shopping sites, can be extreme. Jeffrey O'Brien, a senior editor at Wired magazine, cited a Pioneer 50-inch plasma television, which, according to PriceGrabber.com, was being sold at prices ranging from $7,029, with about $200 for shipping, to more than $13,000.
Sometimes, retailers offer a better price online than in their stores. For example, a traditional Barnes & Noble store in Los Angeles was selling the DVD boxed set of "Band of Brothers" the weekend before Thanksgiving for $119.95, while the online store was selling it for $71.99, plus about $4 in shipping charges. A quick check of BizRate listed online prices of $72.95 to $98.65, including tax and shipping.
At BlueFly.com, an Autumn Cashmere V-neck sweater was selling for $79.95, about $160 below its price in an upscale department store. Armani five-pocket jeans were selling for $59.95, about $60 below the manufacturer's suggested retail price, and a Prada messenger bag with a manufacturer's suggested retail price of $550 was selling for $299. Shipping is set at $5.95 an order.
THE products are all first quality, said Ken Seiff, chief executive of BlueFly. But he said they are available typically six to eight weeks after retailers like Neiman Marcus and Saks Fifth Avenue have them in stock. 
Liquidation sites like Overstock and SmartBargains are heavily discounting products like down comforters, DVD players, Burberry scarves and Nicole Miller jackets. 
Because of the bounty of deals to consider, shoppers should look beyond price, said Chuck Davis, president and chief executive of BizRate.com.
Three years ago, consumers could generally sort out reputable Internet retailers simply by how they operated, Mr. Davis said. Hard-to-use sites that were slow to provide information often meant poor service, he added. But these days, it is easy to make a site look great and work fast.
"There are thousands of merchants, and in a bumpy economy they are fighting for consumers more than ever," he said. "The key is to find a good deal and make sure it's a good merchant."
