HEADLINE: Austin Journal; 
A Slogan Battle Keeps Austin Weird

BYLINE:  By JIM YARDLEY 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 4 

 BODY:
Red Wassenich is sure he coined the phrase "Keep Austin Weird" on a Saturday morning because he was listening to "The Lounge Show." The show, a weekly radio program, plays offbeat music -- Bing Crosby crooning "Hey, Jude" -- and Mr. Wassenich likes it so much he made a donation.
 "Whoever answered the phone said, 'Why did you support the show?' " Mr. Wassenich recalled. "I said, 'I don't know. It helps keep Austin weird.' " 
 The moment a few years ago that those words left his mouth, Mr. Wassenich said, he felt the jolt of inspiration. He had watched unhappily as Austin, his funky, once affordable hometown, had been transformed into a high-tech boomtown. Suddenly, people in expensive clothes driving expensive cars were buying houses at ridiculously expensive prices. Restaurants held wine-tasting parties at $50 a glass.
Mr. Wassenich, 52, decided something needed to be said.
If not quite "Remember the Alamo," "Keep Austin Weird" worked well enough. He and his wife, Karen Pavelka, printed bumper stickers, and the phrase soon began popping up around town. College students wore "Keep Austin Weird" T-shirts. Web sites sprang up. Weirdness seemed to be making a comeback.
All of which makes the latest development perhaps the weirdest of all: a trademark dispute has broken out over the rights to "Keep Austin Weird." A local company that began printing the phrase on T-shirts and hats last year wants to make it a trademark. Mr. Wassenich has filed a challenge with the Patent and Trademark Office.
"It's a perfect illustration of what is unweird about Austin," Mr. Wassenich said of the trademark application. "Somebody's trying to make a buck off of everything."
Mr. Wassenich has asked for an extension of the public comment period on the trademark application as he considers how to make a more formal challenge. Meanwhile, the apparel company, The Outhouse Designs, is trying to counter any impression that it is some profit-obsessed corporate monster.
"There shouldn't be a feud here," said Scott Jackson, 39, the owner. "We should be getting on the same page."
Mr. Jackson and Brian Riebe, president of The Outhouse, said they were unaware that anyone had claimed authorship of "Keep Austin Weird" until they read about Mr. Wassenich this week in an Austin American Statesman article by a humor columnist, John Kelso. Mr. Jackson, an artist, said he had started the T-shirt line last year after hearing the phrase around town.
"We have no way to refute that," Mr. Riebe said of Mr. Wassenich's claim on the phrase. "He may have been the one to come up with it."
The Outhouse Designs hardly evokes the corporate shadow of, say, I.B.M. It has a wooden outhouse in its lobby. One of its most popular T-shirts celebrates a local club, Lucy's Retired Surfer Bar.
Mr. Riebe said that seeking a trademark was just basic business and that the company's application was only for apparel. He said Mr. Wassenich's proposal to leave the phrase in the public domain was "honorable but a bit idealistic."
Mr. Wassenich, a librarian at Austin Community College, has made weirdness an avocation. He fancies black velvet depictions of Elvis and has a collection of smashed cutlery and teapots hanging in his kitchen.
Ms. Pavelka said: "The weird thing is before I met Red, I had a collection of melted things on the wall of my apartment. It was a match made in heaven."
In July 2000, the couple began printing "Keep Austin Weird" bumper stickers and made certain it was a money-losing proposition. Proceeds went to help abandoned dogs.
Mr. Riebe said he planned to call Mr. Wassenich in hope of finding a compromise. Mr. Wassenich, who concedes that his salary will probably not support a long trademark battle, says he nonetheless believes he has found a worthwhile fight.
"They can come pry our cold, dead hands off our bumper stickers," he said, then he started laughing at the thought.

HEADLINE: Union Vote Authorizes Transit Strike 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Increasing the chances of a transit shutdown next weekend, the union representing 34,000 New York City subway and bus workers voted overwhelmingly yesterday to authorize a strike.
 The president of Transport Workers Union Local 100, Roger Toussaint, said that the vote did not necessarily mean there would be a walkout, adding that it depended on whether a contract was reached by next Sunday, when the current one expires. 
 Thousands of transit workers attended two meetings yesterday at the Javits Convention Center, where many of them called management's offer insulting and said they would be willing to strike if that was what it took to obtain a fair contract. New York State's Taylor Law prohibits strikes by the city's transit workers. 
"Their contract offer is terrible, it's disrespectful," said Jose Rondon, a bus driver in Upper Manhattan. "I will do whatever has to be done to get what we deserve."
On Thursday, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced a contract offer calling for a wage freeze in the first year and raises in the second and third years but only if the union agreed to productivity increases. The union, whose members' salaries average $44,000 a year, has called for a 24 percent raise over three years.
Mr. Toussaint said that more than 5,000 transit workers attended each meeting yesterday and that the strike authorization votes were unanimous. Clearly fearing a contempt citation for inciting an illegal walkout, Mr. Toussaint said he did not propose the strike authorization, noting that it was proposed by workers from the floor.
In an interview, he called the strike vote appropriate and denounced the authority's offer, saying: "It's a ridiculous offer and we reject it completely. It's not even a starting point. The worst part is it came so late, just 10 days before the contract expires."
Last night, the transportation authority's chief negotiator, Gary Dellaverson, criticized the decision to authorize a strike, saying threats of illegal action would not make reaching a settlement any more likely.
He said the authority could not afford much in the way of raises because it faces a $2.7 billion deficit and is contemplating sizable fare increases.
"No responsible person has questioned the state of the M.T.A.'s finances," he said. "The union simply ignores the reality of the economy of this city, and indeed the entire state of New York. The M.T.A. does not have that luxury."
On Friday, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg warned that a transit strike could paralyze the city and could contribute to deaths because emergency vehicles would be forced to a crawl in the gridlocked streets. He warned of bringing the full force of the law against those who strike.
Gov. George E. Pataki has also warned against a walkout, saying, "A strike would be an illegal act with very grave consequences to those who break the law."
Three years ago, when the union and the authority were approaching the last contract deadline, the union threatened to strike and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani warned of contempt citations and huge fines if the transit workers walked out. The two sides averted a strike by reaching an agreement several hours after the contract expired.
Mr. Toussaint said he was concerned about the possibility of going to jail if there were a strike. At a news conference last night, he criticized the Taylor Law, saying it favored management by not pressuring management to negotiate in good faith. He faulted Mayor Bloomberg for repeatedly criticizing the union without urging the authority to bargain harder.
The union asserted that the authority's proposal would reduce workers' take-home pay by 2.3 percent by requiring them to divert that percentage toward pension contributions. When the current contract was negotiated in 1999, the stock market was booming and management agreed that the workers could stop making that contribution. With stocks sliding since then, the authority said the workers should resume making that contribution to assure adequate funding of their pensions.
"We're looking for more, and they're talking about cutting," said David Straker, a motorman on the A and C trains. "This is ridiculous. If we have to strike, we will, but I don't think anyone wants a strike. We should try to exhaust all other options first."
Mr. Dellaverson proposed several productivity steps that could free up money for raises, among them ending the rule that bars subway cleaners from changing light bulbs or painting over graffiti. He said management had agreed to pay $60 million more to the health plan, a 22 percent increase, but the union complained that management was proposing higher co-payments for drugs and doctor visits.
Mr. Dellaverson said management's offer "strikes a careful balance between the needs of our customers, who are facing significant fare increases as well as possible service reductions, and our workforce."
But A. Ali, a train operator, said the authority's offer was unreasonable. "They can't ask us for three zeroes and to pay more money for pensions and health coverage, especially when the mayor is telling us we have to pay higher property taxes. What do they want us to do, live in the trains?"

GRAPHIC: Photos: Jose Rondon, a bus driver, called a contract offer "terrible."; Roger Toussaint, president of Transport Workers Union Local 100, said a job action would depend on whether a pact was reached by next Sunday. (Photographs by Frances Roberts for The New York Times)(pg. 51)

HEADLINE: American Policies and Presence Are Under Fire in South Korea, Straining an Alliance 

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH with DON KIRK 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 5 

 BODY:
Buddhist monks and Christian groups have held hunger strikes near the hulking United States Embassy here all week, and while the riot police keep the demonstrators from the gates, they cannot stop the taxi drivers from honking their horns in protest. 
 In even angrier demonstrations, students have thrown firebombs at American military bases here. During a recent music award show, meanwhile, a pop star smashed a model of an American tank on live television, drawing a rousing cheer. Foreign diplomats say universities have withdrawn speaking invitations to the American ambassador, for fear of trouble if he appeared on campus. 
 South Korea and the United States have long been the closest of trans-Pacific friends, but the recent turbulence goes well beyond youthful fashion or passing unrest in a country with a long tradition of protest. The growing estrangement has been evident in the race for president, to be decided in an election on Dec. 19, and many here are warning that the relationship is undergoing fundamental changes, with even more difficult times ahead. 
Roh Moo Hyun, the candidate who holds a narrow lead according to opinion polls, has repeatedly criticized Washington's Korean policies as "hard-line," and he boldly said that if elected he would "guarantee the security of North Korea." The 37,000 American troops here are committed to protecting South Korea from any attack by North Korea, and President Bush has said the North is a member of an "axis of evil." 
The immediate source of anti-American sentiment was an incident in June in which two 14-year-old girls were crushed by an American armored vehicle as they walked to a birthday party on a narrow road north of Seoul. Simmering anger has flared into outrage with the acquittal last month of two United States Army sergeants by an American panel in a military trial. 
But many authorities say the divide has deeper roots, involving this country's rapid passage to affluence and its perception that its distant ally is heavy handed and insensitive, particularly with regard to North Korea. 
Relations are worse than they have been in about 25 years, said Shim Jae Hoon, an expert on Korean affairs. Others say even longer. 
"The main issue then was human rights," said Mr. Shim. "Today the main issue is North-South relations. The two countries don't see eye to eye on foreign policy, and neither of them is handling the worsening relationship very well." 
The widening gulf between the two allies, and in their perceptions of North Korea, is reflected in numerous public opinion polls. In September, a Gallup Korea poll found that a majority of 1,056 South Koreans surveyed felt there was little or no chance of an attack by North Korea. After a disputed call during the 2002 Winter Olympics, when a jostled South Korean skater lost the gold medal to an American rival, another Gallup poll here reported that nearly 60 percent of respondents "disliked" the United States. 
Another poll taken before the deaths of the schoolgirls, which was published in November 2000 by The Dong-A Ilbo newspaper, found that only 42 percent of respondents supported maintaining the current number of American troops in South Korea, while 15 percent supported withdrawing them altogether. 
Mr. Roh, a labor lawyer and a former legislator and cabinet member with a background in social activism who has never visited the United States, also once said that American troops were not needed in South Korea. Nowadays he calls the military alliance vital. 
But he routinely emphasizes that the alliance is badly in need of revision, and the popular anger toward the United States has even forced his main rival, Lee Hoi Chang, a conservative whose international views are generally more in line with those of the Bush administration, to campaign for major changes. 
For a half century, the alliance has been the bedrock of South Korea's prosperity and of Washington's security planning in Asia. 
Few countries have made the economic strides that South Korea has made in recent decades. It leads the world in broadband Internet access, and it is second in shipbuilding; it is also the third-leading producer of semiconductors and fifth in automobile manufacturing. 
An important psychological lift came in June when South Korea served as a co-host, with Japan, for the World Cup soccer tournament, and its team made it to the semifinals. For the first time in the modern era, Koreans feel a swaggering sense of self-assurance. 
Yet daily life still serves up rude collisions between this newfound confidence and the country's dependence on what many Koreans now consider an ally that sometimes seems overbearing. 
For travelers, a bracing dose of this comes upon arrival at South Korea's dazzling new airport, just outside Seoul, where often the first thing passengers may see are American sergeants in combat fatigues barking orders to arriving American servicemembers. 
Also jarring is the gigantic Yongsan Army Garrison, covering 630 acres in the heart of this crowded city. The location of the post, in the center of the capital, is often justified by the nearness of the demilitarized zone between North and South Korea -- 40 miles away -- but it is still something that other countries with American bases, like Japan and Germany, do not have to endure. 
"We have a joint working group with our Korean partners to study ways to move this out of the central city," said the American ambassador, Thomas C. Hubbard. "We recognize the imposition that having a command headquarters in the middle of Seoul causes for many Koreans." 
Diplomatically, on both sides of the Pacific, many people say things began to go wrong at the first meeting between the freshly inaugurated President Bush and President Kim Dae Jung at the White House in March 2001. Mr. Kim went to Washington hoping to maintain the momentum of the last months of the Clinton administration, when it appeared that a historic security agreement with North Korea was in reach. 
Instead of an endorsement, many South Koreans, including some who are not partisans of Mr. Kim, felt that Mr. Bush showed insufficient deference to their president and was dismissive of Mr. Kim's policy of reconciliation with North Korea. 
For his part, Mr. Kim failed to understand how much Washington's outlook had shifted with the change in administrations, his critics say. "The perception is that the U.S. has been vacillating, but over the years, the Koreans have vacillated at least as much as the U.S. has," said one Western diplomat. 
Things have only grown worse since then, with Washington leading a campaign to force North Korea to abandon a nuclear weapons program whose existence, secret until recently, violates many arms control agreements. South Korean officials say their country's intelligence agencies, and not the United States as is commonly believed, first detected the existence of the North Korean nuclear program. Yet Mr. Kim, in the waning months of his presidency, has continued to press for engagement with the North. Mr. Kim is barred by the Constitution from seeking a second five-year term. 
With their overwhelming economic superiority and vastly better weaponry compared with their neighbor, South Koreans increasingly regard an unprovoked attack by North Korea as unimaginable, and public opinion has largely followed Mr. Kim. More than 62 percent of 1,013 respondents in a Sisa Journal-Media Research survey earlier this year called Mr. Bush's approach toward North Korea unhelpful.
"The Bush administration looked at the political calendar and made a calculation that they would be in office after Kim Dae Jung, and have given the appearance of just trying to wait him out," said Scott Snyder, the Korea representative of the Asia Foundation. "The unintended consequence is that Koreans have been getting the impression that their country isn't taken seriously. 
"Depending on what happens with North Korea," Mr. Snyder said, "I think the entire relationship could be on the table." 
Western diplomats deny there has ever been a strategy to simply await the end of Mr. Kim's term to reactivate diplomacy concerning North Korea. In any event, today the payoff of such an approach looks uncertain at best. 
Until less than a month ago, Mr. Lee, the conservative opposition leader, looked like a shoo-in for the presidency, but the merger of Mr. Roh's campaign with that of a third-party candidate and the uproar over the American acquittals in the deaths of the two girls have transformed the tenor of the race. The changes helped make a favorite out of Mr. Roh, whose diffidence toward Washington would almost certainly make for a pricklier relationship. 
Some experts say the biggest challenge to the South Korean-American alliance may be generational. Since the division of the Korean Peninsula was solidified after the Korean War, South Koreans have felt an ache from the separation of tens of thousands of families. Despite this country's prosperity, there is a deep anger over having been victimized by outside powers. 
"For Koreans, it is very ironic that we were divided by World War II, and Japan, your defeated enemy, was not," said Chung Mong Joon, the scion of the Hyundai industrial empire, and the unsuccessful candidate who merged his campaign with Mr. Roh's. "In Europe, Germany was defeated and divided, but Japan was aided by the Korean War, which left us divided. This is very unfair." 
As the generations age, fewer people have memories of the horrors of the Korean War, and of the poverty that South Korea overcame, and that benefits North Korea. 
"There are perfectly sound arguments that can be made for the U.S. presence, but they are less clear now that they have been in some time," said Nicholas Eberstadt, a Korea expert at the American Enterprise Institute in Washington. "In the meantime, U.S. forces are making sonic booms over people's houses, causing environmental damage and doing the unpleasant things that unattached men all over the world sometimes do. 
"If the alliance has a purpose that is spelled out, then people can tolerate these sorts of things," Mr. Eberstadt added. "If not, we will have problems."

HEADLINE: At Deficit Time, the Stealth Pataki; 
He Leaves Backers on All Sides Guessing Who Will Suffer

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 7 

 BODY:
Throughout his campaign for re-election, Gov. George E. Pataki answered questions about the state's looming financial crisis with an optimistic confidence worthy of Winston Churchill. Again and again, he assured voters that he had steered the state through a similar crisis in 1995 and would do so again, although he did not say how. 
 Yet Mr. Pataki, a Republican, is in a very different political position than he was in 1995, after he was elected as a fiscal conservative who had vowed to cut taxes and owed nothing to organized labor. 
 This time, Mr. Pataki ran a nonpartisan campaign tailored to appeal to everyone, including labor leaders and business executives. Unions and traditional Democrats flocked to his side. He spent as much time on the campaign trail talking up expensive health care programs for the poor as he did promising tax cuts. 
The governor's efforts to be all things to all people won him the election, but how he chooses to balance the state's books will speak volumes about his core political principles, campaign strategists and budget experts say. In recent days, he has closeted himself with his budget officials, looking for a way to close a potential $2 billion gap in this year's budget and a gap of as much as $10 billion in the budget for the fiscal year that begins in April.
"They don't know which way to turn in terms of how to do it, and whose ox is gored," one Republican strategist said. "There is not any easy way out of this thing."
Yet in contrast to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York, another Republican who has the burden of stretching dwindling revenues to cover a budget shortfall, Mr. Pataki is not likely to search for a solution on a public stage or to issue dire warnings that everyone must make sacrifices. If history serves as a guide, he will work out a plan behind closed doors, continue to sound optimistic about the future in public and remain silent about the details of his proposal until he presents it to the Legislature, perhaps as late as Feb. 1, when his executive budget is due.
Mr. Pataki's sunny but reticent style has left his supporters on both sides of the political spectrum guessing about his intentions. Union leaders are hoping that their support for the governor in the last election will persuade him to limit cuts to the state work force and to programs like Medicaid, which pays for health care for the poor. Business leaders and Republican luminaries are determined to hold him to his promise not to raise taxes.
It may be impossible for Mr. Pataki to satisfy both demands at once, budget analysts said. The state budget this year is about $89.6 billion, of which about $58.6 billion is paid through state taxes and fees. The state's portion of Medicaid is about $8.2 billion. State aid to local schools accounts for about $14 billion. 
Few budget analysts believe that Mr. Pataki can close the yawning chasm between revenues and expenses in the next fiscal year without touching either the health care or the education budgets. Both are not only sacred cows for the Democrats who control the Assembly, but are also important to some of Mr. Pataki's supporters in the labor movement, among them the heads of the largest hospital workers' union and the union of New York City teachers.
"People who were made promises that they wouldn't be hurt are now going to be hurt," said Brian D. Backstrom, the president of Change New York, a conservative group that has criticized Mr. Pataki's budgets in recent years. "There are a lot of chits out there. There are people waiting to cash in, with huge price tags."
One of those people is Dennis Rivera, the powerful president of the hospital workers' union, known as 1199/S.E.I.U. Though a Democrat, Mr. Rivera backed Mr. Pataki in this year's election, despite having gone to war with him in 1995 and 1996 when the governor first proposed cutting back the state's generous Medicaid benefits.
Since that initial conflict, the two men have made peace. They have joined forces to push through health care bills that expanded Medicaid to pay for insurance for the poor and to provide raises for health care workers. Steep cuts to Medicaid would meet with resistance from Mr. Rivera, unless they were balanced by tax increases on corporations and the rich, union officials said. Such a move would signal that the governor was returning to his political roots and forsaking some of his new allies. "The pivotal issue and the defining issue will be Medicaid," said E. J. McMahon, an analyst with the Manhattan Institute, a conservative group.
Similar pitfalls await the governor if he decides to freeze or cut back school aid. As usual, the Assembly Democrats can be expected to fight such measures. But so will the teachers who supported him in the last election. Mayors and county executives, meanwhile, are groaning about the burden the state has placed on them with new Medicaid programs. They are already lobbying the Legislature and Mr. Pataki to rein in health care spending. 
A desire for higher office may also color Mr. Pataki's decisions. He is a long shot within the Republican Party for the vice presidential or presidential candidacy because of his support for abortion rights and gun control. If he harbors any hope of higher office, he cannot afford to raise taxes and may want to reinforce his credentials as a fiscal conservative. 
"George Pataki has run so far to the left that he is now out of the mainstream of Republicans, and he did not start that way," said Josh Isay, a Democratic political consultant.
The governor's critics on the right say his current predicament is partly of his own making. Though he held the line on spending in his first two years in office, he and the Legislature let spending grow at nearly twice the rate of inflation over the last six years. The economic boom and the overheated stock market made it possible to do so without raising taxes.
Now, the stock market bubble has burst and income tax collections have plummeted, by $1.5 billion in the first six months of the fiscal year, or 7.5 percent. New York is not alone in this predicament. Most large, rich states face similar straits.
Critics say, however, that when faced with a competitive re-election battle, Mr. Pataki did not cut spending in this year's budget, as other states did. Instead, he balanced the budget with about $4 billion in one-time revenues that will evaporate next year, according to the state comptroller's office.
"The boom created such a huge revenue surge that this feels very painful coming down, but the fact is we have reverted to a more normal growth pattern," said Robert A. Kurtter, an analyst for Moody's Investors Service. 
Mr. Pataki still has a few options that may cushion the state's fall. He could borrow against the $1 billion that the state receives each year as part of a court settlement with tobacco companies, a tactic that would bring in $5 billion to $6 billion right away. He could save at least $700 million through accounting maneuvers like postponing the payment of bills and tax refunds until the next fiscal year. 
The governor might also cap the state subsidies to school districts that are intended to keep local property taxes down. He could also cut the state's 230,000-strong payroll through attrition, saving $1 billion for every 20,000 jobs, analysts say.
So far, Mr. Pataki has not given a hint of which way he will go. At a public appearance on Thursday, he said the state faced a potential $2 billion shortfall this fiscal year. When asked about possible Medicaid cuts, he said with characteristic finality, "I'm not going to get into the specific budget proposals I'll be making." 
Everyone is waiting to see what he does next.

HEADLINE: FILM; 
That Mythic American Hero: The Regular Guy

BYLINE:  By A. O. SCOTT 

 BODY:
ALBERT SCHMIDT, the hero of Louis Begley's 1996 novel, "About Schmidt," is a man of privilege and position. Not that he doesn't have his troubles. Recently widowed and reluctantly retired as a partner in a top New York law firm, he endures the snakebite of filial ingratitude and the drift toward old age with grumpy stoicism in his luxurious house in the Hamptons. Schmidt's pension from the firm, supplemented by income from his tax-free municipal bonds, is sufficient to keep him comfortable, though not to dispel his temperamental inclination to worry about money.
 "It occurred to Schmidt," Mr. Begley writes, "that, to the average American, this would seem a pretty good deal for a single 60-year-old codger with no dependents, but was the average American accustomed to living as Schmidt lived? Had he worked as hard?" 
 These questions may display a regrettable lack of knowledge or curiosity on Schmidt's part about the lives of his fellow citizens, but on Friday, when Alexander Payne's screen adaptation of Mr. Begley's book is released in New York, Los Angeles and, fittingly, Omaha, Schmidt will receive an exquisite comeuppance. In transferring his story to film, Mr. Payne and Jim Taylor, his screenwriting partner, have exacted a karmic payback for the character's snobbery and insularity. Albert Schmidt has been reincarnated as Warren Schmidt, a newly retired executive at a medium-size insurance company in Omaha. His daughter (played by Hope Davis) is betrothed not to an ambitious junior partner at the old firm, as in the book, but to an unambitious Denver water-bed salesman (Dermot Mulroney). Schmidt's beloved Saab has been replaced by a Winnebago, in which he undertakes a meandering odyssey from Omaha to Denver. Yes, there may be some mitigation in being played by Jack Nicholson, but make no mistake. Schmidt has been reborn as something very much like the average American.
It is both curious and obvious that a simple change of geography and profession would have such a transformative effect. (And while many other details of the story have been changed, the novel's themes of parental disappointment, spousal bereavement and late-mid-life restlessness resonate with force and subtlety in the movie.) Mr. Payne, a native Nebraskan, and Mr. Begley, a Manhattan lawyer, have placed Schmidt in familiar milieus, drawing moral and aesthetic details according to what they know. But in transplanting Schmidt from the Northeast to the Middle West, Mr. Payne has not simply subjected him to a change of climate, topography and regional mores; he has plucked the unsuspecting Schmidt out of one literary tradition and inserted him into another.
Schmidt has migrated from the Ivy League, Episcopal world of Louis Auchincloss (and, behind him, Henry James) into the broad Rotarian heartland of Sinclair Lewis. And he has thus, perhaps even in his own estimation, gone from being a person of distinction to being a regular guy. He is the latest in a long line of sad, comical and heroic embodiments of the ordinary man that have, in loneliness, defeat and occasional glory, populated American novels, plays, movies and television shows for much of the past century. They include Clifford Odets's and Arthur Miller's histrionic heroes, John Updike's lusty, lucky Rabbit Angstrom, the haunted statistical strivers of 1950's critical sociology and, at a stretch, just about every movie cop and sitcom dad. They are embodied, characteristically, by the likes of Jimmy Stewart, Fred MacMurray, Jack Lemmon and Gene Hackman. They work, marry, divorce, get fired, complain and persevere. (There is a parallel tradition, stretching from Stella Dallas to Roseanne and beyond, devoted to the ordinary woman, but that is a subject for another essay.)
F. Scott Fitzgerald's observation that "the very rich" are "different from you and me" is usually taken as a statement about the very rich, who have always exerted a certain fascination on even the most democratic-minded writers and moviemakers. But more revealing, perhaps, is Fitzgerald's implicit assumption that the salient division in American life is between them and us. You and I, in other words, are not very different from each other. We must belong to the default category of the not-very-rich, a generality that, at least in the abstract, transcends region and background or washes them away in the solvent of averageness. Politicians increasingly pander to the middle class -- a group of people that is at once universally inclusive (something like 90 percent of us claim to belong to it) and perpetually forgotten, vanishing or neglected.
Culturemongers, in the meantime, both mock and celebrate the ordinary guy, the average American, who is at once an allegorical figment and a person who lives at a specific address, holds a particular job and drives a readily identifiable kind of car. He is both scapegoat and tragic hero, martyr and buffoon -- an archetype whose manifestations include Willy Loman and Homer Simpson. He struggles and strives, but he can never win: when he is happy, his contentment reflects the lamentable (and often laughable) constriction of his soul; when he is sad, his suffering indicts the cruelty and materialism of the social order.
This mythic figure is with us -- he is us -- in bad times and good. In 1922, the same year that James Joyce, in "Ulysses," turned an ordinary Dubliner named Leopold Bloom into a mythic hero, Sinclair Lewis introduced George Babbitt, an Ohio real estate salesman whose name quickly entered the vernacular. The American Heritage dictionary defines a Babbitt as "a member of the middle class whose attachment to its business and social ideals is such as to make that person a model of narrow-mindedness and self-satisfaction." But the original Babbitt is, by the novel's end, a victim as well as an embodiment of the cautiousness and conformity that surrounds him. He is unable to escape his family, his town and his fraternal association even as he is dimly aware of deeper meanings and higher values beyond their ken.
Babbitt carries out his failed revolt -- and Lewis advanced his enormously successful critique -- in the name of individualism. In "Babbitt," the regimentation of small town civic life, the tyranny of consumerism and the passionless routines of marriage all conspire to stultify every creative, rebellious or original impulse. "I've never done a single thing I've wanted to in my whole life!" Babbitt tells his son, Ted, at the novel's end. "I don't know's I've accomplished anything except just get along. I figure out I've made about a quarter of an inch out of a possible hundred rods." Perhaps the son, who forsakes college to pursue his dream of being an inventor, will redeem his father's compromised existence. "Well," Babbitt continues, "maybe you'll carry things on further. I don't know. But I do get a kind of sneaking pleasure out of the fact that you knew what you wanted to do and did it. Well, those folks in there will try to bully you, and tame you down. Tell 'em to go to the devil!"
These words are moving but also strangely self-canceling. Even as he rails against the oppressive power of "those folks" and everything they stand for, Babbitt remains, to the last, one of them. His energetic dissent is, in some ways, a restatement of their governing values. If the ideologies of American business and consumerism can be imagined as the slow poison that asphyxiates our fantasies of heroic self-fulfillment, they can also -- if anything, more plausibly -- be viewed as the oxygen that feeds such vague, vain dreams as George and Teddy Babbitt's. If towns like the fictitious Zenith, Ohio, were, in the decades from the end of the Civil War to the start of the cold war, graveyards of ambition, they were also its seedbeds, spawning more than their share of architects, industrialists, philosophers and, not incidentally, novelists like Fitzgerald and Lewis.
The broad concept of Babbittry -- the idea that the average American lives in a benighted, blinkered spiritual state -- has been both popular and durable. Lewis's novel was an immediate best seller, on a scale that suggests that many of its potential targets must also have been readers. With some important alterations in political tone and moral attitude, Lewis's central idea, like the name of his hero, has survived depression, war, the rise of the suburbs, the revolt of the cities, feminism, the sexual revolution, the counterculture, multiculturalism and the Internet. The 1930's added a dimension of economic desperation and political radicalism to the literary plight of the average American, who began to speak in urban accents that reflected, at least implicitly, backgrounds more exotic than Babbitt's native-born Protestantism.
He also began to speak, increasingly, from the stage and the screen, his speeches ringing with the populist rhetoric of Clifford Odets, Frank Capra and their followers. In 1948, Henry Wallace, the presidential candidate of the Progressive Party, proclaimed "the century of the common man," and for at least a decade, on Broadway and on television, that seemed to be so. This was the era of Arthur Miller's Willy Loman, Paddy Chayefsky's "Marty" and Jackie Gleason's Ralph Kramden.
"Attention must be paid to such a person" was Linda Loman's lament, in "Death of a Salesman," about her husband, and looking back over the decades you wonder when it has ever not been paid. The gentle, sentimental realism of "Marty" survives in Terrence McNally's "Frankie and Johnny," in its current revival one of the hottest tickets in New York theater. ("Marty" itself was recently tried out, in Boston, as a musical starring John C. Reilly, a rising Everyman of American cinema). "Death of a Salesman" is by now a staple of high school English classes, and the buffoonery and nobility of Gleason in "The Honeymooners" has endured through Archie Bunker, Homer Simpson, "Roseanne" and Hank Hill.
ALL of this may suggest a strain of masochism in the makeup of the average Americans who, however else we may think of ourselves, have been among the most loyal audiences for these representations. Or, as has sometimes been suggested, the popularity of satirical and quasi-tragic depictions of ordinary folk may be a reflection of the contempt in which they are held by the coastal Albert Schmidts who make the movies and write the novels and the plays. More than this, though, the durability of these figures suggests that, along with work, family and shopping, self-criticism may be a major American pastime.
Consider Warren Schmidt himself. In one of Mr. Payne's suggestive motifs, Schmidt keeps running into cows: photographs of prize steers adorn the walls of the steakhouse where his retirement dinner is held. Later, on the highway in his R.V., he passes a truckful of the beasts, bound, no doubt, for slaughter. And at his daughter's wedding, he takes the floor in a room dominated by an enormous joint of roast beef. And this, the film suggests, is the mirror of his own life cycle, in which he is used up, consumed and discarded in a carnivorous variation on Willy Loman's metaphor of himself as an orange whose peel is bound for the trash.
But if "About Schimdt" is a story of frustration and futility, it is also a comedy of unexpected fulfillment, about the serendipitous ways that life can be given meaning. In the end, there is nothing extraordinary about Schimdt except "About Schmidt."

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK 

BYLINE:  Compiled by Warren Strugatch; E-mail: libiz@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Police Returning Vests Made by L.I. Subsidiary
 The New York City Police Department said Tuesday that it had begun returning more than 6,400 bullet-resistant vests for replacement. The new vests will offer "a higher level of protection," says the maker, a subsidiary of DHB Industries of Carle Place. 
 Tests done in September by the state's Labor Department showed that the vests failed to stop bullets, said Eric Gioia, a New York city councilman who is calling for an investigation into the DHB subsidiary, Point Blank Body Armor, based in Oakland Park, Fla. 
 Sandra Hatfield, the chief operating officer of DHB, said, "I'm not aware of any tests we failed." Asked why the company had agreed to replace the vests, she said, "I don't know." 
Point Blank is currently involved in a labor dispute with Unite, a needleworkers' union, and has hired replacements for workers who are on strike. The number of workers involved is unclear. In a news release, Councilman Gioia said it was 200. Ms. Hatfield said it was only 30. 
Ms. Hatfield said that the basis of the Point Blank problems was "unfounded and unfavorable stories" circulated by striking workers and union leaders. In October, the company filed lawsuits against officials from Unite and other unions and against the International Union of Police Associations, accusing them of defamation, conspiracy and interference with business relationships.
Other Point Blank customers include the four branches of the United States armed forces, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Immigration and Naturalization Service and other federal, state and local police departments.

$16 Million Write-Down
The Standard Microsystems Corporation (Nasdaq: SMSC) of Hauppauge said Monday that it would write down more than $16.3 million in its fiscal third quarter, which ended Nov 30. The move reflects market devaluations of two technology companies in which it holds minority stakes.
Standard Microsystems said it would write down roughly equal amounts on SMC Networks of Hauppauge, which it spun off as a separate company, and on Chartered Semiconductor Manufacturing of Singapore. Standard Microsystems attributed the companies' decline in value to "the prolonged economic slump in the technology marketplace." Compiled by Warren Strugatch

HEADLINE: CULTURAL STUDIES; 
My Big Fat Palace Wedding

BYLINE:  By GINIA BELLAFANTE 

 BODY:
IN "The Uses of Enchantment," Bruno Bettelheim's 1976 book on the psychological resonance of fairy tales, he contends that "Cinderella" appeals to young children because it validates their feelings of sibling rivalry. It maintains, he argues, the fattened hope in boys and girls that one fine day they will succeed in vanquishing the evildoer in Raggedy Ann pajamas occupying so much psychic space in the top bunk.
 Versions of the Cinderella story date back to ninth-century China. The latest will arrive in theaters on Friday in the form of "Maid in Manhattan," a movie starring Jennifer Lopez and Ralph Fiennes that presumably will draw from a broader demographic than America's micro-population of 9-year-old girls. 
 The film's plot doesn't deviate much from the archetype: as a chambermaid of unshakeable rectitude, Ms. Lopez wins the heart of Mr. Fiennes's well-to-do politician simply by crossing his sightline while wearing very expensive clothes that do not belong to her. In this instance the magnetic ensemble is a white, double-face cashmere Dolce & Gabbana pantsuit, the borrowed property of a hotel guest, who one is instantly meant to believe, doesn't deserve it in the first place.
I went to see "Maid in Manhattan" on my own volition with a friend a week ago at a sneak preview. We had intended to go see "Solaris," but ultimately we could not help ourselves. It is the same kind of helplessness that befalls so many women I know, who submit, without internal dispute, to watching "Pretty Woman" or "Sabrina" for the 16th time on television, invariably at an hour they had otherwise reserved for making their way through another chapter of another volume of an L.B.J. biography.
Mr. Bettelheim's theories about "Cinderella," however elaborately detailed, do not explain why the narrative could trigger a response in anyone who had grown out of her bunk bed -- in, say, a woman old enough to be reading Bruno Bettelheim.
Of course, one might argue that all women really want to be swooped up by a genteel public servant who not only looks like Ralph Fiennes but who also maintains a focus on them so intense he barely makes the time to flip through the latest issue of Roll Call. But fantasies are webbed more intricately than that.
Cinematic renderings of "Cinderella" enchant grown-ups for the same reason that the tease of the Internet economy kept us going against all reason -- they allow us to indulge in the cherished myth of class mobility and all its attendant promises of instant and effortless transformation.
"Sweet Home Alabama" is a rare recent example of a romantic comedy -- or of any kind of pop cultural product, in fact -- aimed at puncturing that delusion, creating as it did a character who exfoliated away her layers of urbane self-invention to find a truer happiness within her tribe of origin. 
The fictional Melanie Carmichael realizes what readers of real-life newspaper wedding announcements know well, that hotel maids don't happily wed the sons of political dynasties; the daughters of chauffeurs, accountants or dentists rarely meet fourth-generation titans of industry; that people from Fifth Avenue and 66th Street are unlikely to marry people from Astoria Boulevard.
Less outwardly derivative of something from the Brothers Grimm, "My Big Fat Greek Wedding," which recently surpassed "Pretty Woman" as the highest-grossing romantic comedy of all time, also lures the viewer in, conflating fantasies of romantic deliverance and social ascension. Nia Vardalos's frumpish diner hostess is rescued from her boisterous and stifling immigrant family when she bumps up against a bohemian schoolteacher who also happens to be a son of soft-spoken privilege. 
Seminal to the power of these stories is that the heroine merely bumps up against the man of means, which is to say that she is not actively working to marry up. She is never saving diligently to pay for the $600 ticket to the charity event that will afford her access to the sort of men who might spirit her away from the tiny apartment with a bathtub three inches away from the toaster oven.
Sabrina, one is reminded, doesn't actually do anything to land Linus Larrabee; she hardly even notices him.
To pursue is vulgar, to be chosen ennobling, the message suggests. Pointedly, no character in "Maid in Manhattan" is depicted quite so unpalatably and pathetically as the actual owner of the Dolce suit, a Sotheby's executive played by Natasha Richardson, who, jilted by her fiance, makes an unambiguous play for Mr. Fiennes. Ms. Lopez the domestic, convinced of her fixed place in the social order, does almost nothing but deflect his advances.
The drug disseminated to the audience here, and in every movie like this one, is the precept that no matter what your costume -- maid's uniform, streetwalker's stiletto vinyl boots or tailored corporate suit -- someone will eventually emerge from the ether to recognize that you are a creature like no other. And you, already so uniquely pure of heart, will rise even further. A photo montage at the end of "Maid in Manhattan" indicates that Ms. Lopez's character, now entwined with Mr. Fiennes's and freed from the tyranny of soiled linens and dirty grout, spends her days advancing the cause of the underclass. 
And wouldn't we all choose such a course if it were handed to us? The instinct that keeps many women infatuated with the "Cinderella" myth is the same one, curiously, that has driven them to make a best-selling book out of "The Bitch in the House," a compilation of essays, many by prominent writers, about love, marriage, work and motherhood that, taken together, make a very strong argument for the fact that women are tired. They are tired of laboring to find men and keep them, of ministering to careers, children, aging parents and their own bodies, all the while remaining responsible for ensuring that there is always 2 percent low-fat milk in the fridge.
They know better than to subscribe to antiquated notions of perfect solutions, but sometimes they can't help feeling like chambermaids. And it is at moments like this when it is too hard to relinquish the prospect of a Ralph Fiennes facsimile materializing to take care of the mess.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
Out With the Old, and Waiting for the New (Tax Cuts)

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
WHAT do the defenestrations of Paul H. O'Neill, the Treasury secretary, and Lawrence B. Lindsey, the president's top economic adviser, reveal about the economy now, its future and that of the stock market? 
 About the economy now, the moves show how worried President Bush is that the nation will slip back into recession. "The economy is perceived to be a serious problem," said Jan Hatzius, senior economist at Goldman, Sachs. "You wouldn't need to change the team if there wasn't a problem." Nor would you change the team if you weren't worried about being re-elected in 2004. 
 Clearly, the White House understands that the economy needs strong medicine if it is to stay on its feet and become ambulatory. That medicine, administered heretofore and only somewhat successfully by Alan Greenspan, will soon be augmented by new tax cuts, if Mr. Bush has his way.
Neither Mr. O'Neill nor Mr. Lindsey had the ideas, or the credibility, to fix the problems. So both had to go.
Many economists agree that tax cuts are exactly what the doctor ordered, largely because consumer spending, the engine of economic growth in recent years, is imperiled by excessive borrowing.
"This economy is really laboring under a tremendous debt load," said Paul Kasriel, director of economic research at Northern Trust in Chicago. "The corporate sector has made great strides in slowing down its borrowing, but the private sector hasn't even started."
Sure enough, debt as a percentage of assets among households has reached new highs, consumer borrowing was very strong in the third quarter and equity extraction from homes has been enormous. 
The household net worth figures released last week by the Federal Reserve, showing the latest in a string of declines, were also ominous. "Prior to 2000, there had never been a year-on-year decline in household net worth in the postwar period," Mr. Kasriel noted. "It happened in 2000 and 2001 and now 2002. People are going to have to start saving more."
But increased saving means reduced spending, which would in turn drag down the economy. So tax cuts are a way to give consumers the cushion they need to save a bit even as they keep spending. 
The problem for Mr. Bush is that his tax cuts -- of whatever sort -- are not likely to be enough to counterbalance increased taxes that most consumers will face from their state and local governments, which are struggling mightily. And because spending at state and local levels is almost double that of federal spending, restraint there could damage the economy significantly. 
"If you take all levels of government together, it is unlikely that the federal government's stimulus can outweigh the state and local governments' restraint," Mr. Hatzius said. So even if Mr. Bush succeeds in pushing tax cuts through, they may not be that effective in propelling the economy. 
As a result, Mr. Hatzius and Mr. Kasriel both expect the economy to sputter along next year. Mr. Hatzius projects gross domestic product growth of around 2 percent for 2003, while Mr. Kasriel forecasts around 3 percent.
So where does that leave the stock market? Stable, perhaps, but not strapping.
"Sluggish gross domestic product growth usually means corporate profits aren't much better than flat," Mr. Hatzius said. And if corporate profits stagnate, stock indexes may, too. What has gone on in the past two years may well continue: individual stocks do well but the indexes disappoint.
"This economy is in hock," Mr. Kasriel said. "It has come off 20 years of extreme leveraging. It's going to take time to work through these things. And it won't be pleasant."

HEADLINE: The Envelope, Please: Those Bonuses Come Crawling Back 

BYLINE:  By PATRICK McGEEHAN; Additional reporting for this article was provided by Reed Abelson, David Carr, Danny Hakim, Laura M. Holson and Steve Lohr.

 BODY:
LAYOFFS, bankruptcies and falling stock prices: 2002 has been full of them, along with other corporate troubles. This is not likely to be a good year for bonuses. Or is it?
 Company executives, union officials and compensation consultants say that when millions of American workers receive bonuses -- or word about their bonuses -- in the next several weeks, some will be pleasantly surprised. From top executives like Douglas R. Conant, the chief executive of Campbell Soup, to auto workers, magazine editors and pharmaceutical employees, many people will actually receive bigger bonus checks than they did last year. 
 The outlook, though, varies widely from industry to industry, and sometimes from company to company within an industry. 
And, obviously, in only a very few cases will those payments measure up to the boom-time bonuses before the stock market went bust. In most sectors and regions, including Wall Street and Silicon Valley, the supersized pay packages of the late 1990's look like mirages that may not reappear for years.
Bonuses have an immediate economic impact that is often felt even before the checks are cashed. Some companies that pay them early in the new year inform employees in advance so they can plan their holiday spending. The effect reverberates most in the New York metropolitan area, and in states like Michigan, with its concentration of auto workers who traditionally receive bonuses.
"It's immediate and it's continuous," said Frank Fernandez, the chief economist of the Securities Industry Association. "You're already seeing this weakness in the real estate market in New York." Sales of some luxury goods have remained strong, he said, because people seem to be having "one last fling" at conspicuous consumption.
On Wall Street, investment bankers and traders at firms like the Goldman Sachs Group and Morgan Stanley are bracing for thinner envelopes. On average, the 2002 payouts, which account for the bulk of annual compensation, will be down at least 35 percent, Wall Street executives and pay consultants said. But that means only that a typical managing director at a major investment bank will earn about $1 million for 2002, down from $1.6 million last year and $2.1 million two years ago, they said.
Although the raw numbers may not compare, the bonus picture looks better in other industries. Microsoft, which has suffered relatively little in the technology slump, has not shrunk its bonus pool. Nearly all of its 50,000 full-time workers are eligible for cash bonuses of up to 15 percent of salary.
For auto workers, everything depends on the nationality of their employer. Those who assemble cars for the Big Three are steeling for a second consecutive bleak year, while their counterparts at Honda Motor recently received year-end bonuses of almost $5,000 each.
"There are many out in the marketplace who would have thought that bonuses would have been way off, given the type of conditions we've been seeing," said Ken Abosch, a senior consultant at Hewitt Associates in Lincolnshire, Ill.
But so far, he said, companies have been paying bonuses at just a slightly lower rate than last year. Bonuses based on performance will amount to about 10.5 percent of total compensation in 2002, down from 10.8 percent last year, according to Hewitt's survey.
"That confirms to us that companies are pretty much planning to hold the line and spend what they went into the year planning to spend on bonuses," Mr. Abosch said. Hewitt expects bonuses to rise again in 2003, to almost 11 percent of total pay.
Bonuses do not make or break the family budget for most American workers. About a third of companies still hand out small amounts of cash, $25 gift certificates or even turkeys or hams, Mr. Abosch said. Though most managers consider such gestures ineffective, he said, they are hard to eliminate once people have come to expect them.
Many companies were surprised last year by how poorly they did, said Jannice L. Koors, a vice president at Pearl Meyer & Partners, an executive pay consulting firm in New York. As a result, about 40 of the 200 biggest corporations in the United States eliminated bonuses for their chief executives in 2001, compared with 10 to 20 in a normal year, Ms. Koors said. As the bosses' bonuses go, so go those of the rank and file, she said.
By the end of last year, chastened managers had become much more conservative in budgeting and planning, Ms. Koors said. So the performance targets they set for this year were easier to meet.
"Most bonuses are paid out relative to budget, so you could actually see bonuses go up," she said, but she added that it was too soon to get a good read for most major companies because bonuses will not be determined until January or February.
Doling out bonuses will be especially sensitive at companies that have had one or more rounds of layoffs. The Charles Schwab Corporation, which has eliminated more than a third of its jobs in the last two years, reinstated quarterly bonuses for its rank-and-file employees this year after suspending the payments in 2001. Although it has not met its profit and revenue targets, Schwab has paid workers 25 percent of what they would have received if it had.
Greg Gable, a spokesman at Schwab's headquarters in San Francisco, said the company decided to pay bonuses "in recognition that they were working really, really hard in a really hard situation." Schwab has not decided whether to pay them again for the fourth quarter or whether to pay annual bonuses to its co-chief executives, Charles R. Schwab and David S. Pottruck.
"I would think that for the survivors, compared to last year there will be more happy campers," Ms. Koors said of all workers who are receiving bonuses for this year. "I don't think that even the happy campers will be getting bonuses as big as they once got."
Here is a look at the bonus picture in various industries.

A Bonus Pipeline Dries Up
Known for their generosity, drug companies paid lavish bonuses to senior executives, researchers and sales representatives in recent years as they rang up fast growth and strong profits. But 2002 has been tough as many companies struggle with relatively arid pipelines of new drugs and fierce competition from generics.
"There may not be this orgy of cash being tossed around," said Deborah Seltzer, a vice president for Ray & Berndtson, an executive recruiting firm. Bonuses are still being paid, she said, but they are not as hefty.
"Companies are being far more conservative," agreed Cheryl Buxton, a managing director at Korn/Ferry International, an executive recruiting firm. Investors and others are demanding that companies more closely tie the compensation of senior executives to corporate performance. "That feeling is escalating across the industry," she said.
When GlaxoSmithKline, the British drug company, proposed a pay package for its chief executive, Jean-Pierre Garnier, valued at roughly $18 million, for example, there was an outcry from shareholders. The stock, which trades on the London Stock Exchange, has lost about a third of its value this year. A few weeks ago, Glaxo backed down, saying it would postpone its decision on Mr. Garnier's compensation.
At Bristol-Myers Squibb, which has also had its share of troubles, top executives are being held accountable. Peter R. Dolan, the chief executive, and executives who reported to him over the last year will receive no increases in salary, or any bonus, said Bonnie Jacobs, a company spokeswoman. Bristol-Myers' shares have lost almost half their value this year as the company dealt with excess inventory that had built up because it had encouraged wholesalers to buy too much of its products. Bristol has had to restate its earnings, and the Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether it improperly inflated its revenue.
Other Bristol-Myers employees will fare better, because the goals that allow them to receive bonuses were changed, Ms. Jacobs said. Bristol-Myers typically pays bonuses in two parts, she said, with the first already disbursed and the second installment due in February.
Some employees are getting bonuses early this time. At Pharmacia, which plans to merge soon with Pfizer, employees will get their bonuses in January rather than March, a Pharmacia spokesman said. But the celebration may be muted: layoffs are expected at the combined company.

Magazine World Celebrates
The recession cut deep into the revenue and profits of magazine publishers, but you would not know it from looking at the bonuses that some are paying. Because publishing lost steam early in 2000 and was hurt more than most industries in 2001, the financial plans for 2002 set relatively low hurdles.
Hearst Magazines is expecting a record year because of stellar results from Cosmopolitan and O, the Oprah Magazine, and a cost-cutting initiative, an executive there said. High-ranking executives, including editors in chief, at the more profitable magazines will receive bonuses of at least $100,000, this executive said. They will also accrue longer-term bonuses based on the overall performance of the company and the businesses they run.
Conde Nast Publications, a unit of Advance Publications that is known for its executive perks and salaries, is also in the bonus game. When Steven T. Florio became president in 1994, he instituted a bonus plan for the first time at the company and included caps of $250,000 for the awards. S. I. Newhouse Jr., the chairman, met with publishers at a lunch last week and listened as Mr. Florio said 8 of the company's 16 magazines had met or exceeded their goals. Bonuses of $100,000 or a bit more are common for executives at successful magazines, with corporate bonuses running much higher.
At the Time Inc. unit of AOL Time Warner, executives were told after the merger of America Online and Time Warner that their long-term incentive program would be replaced with options. Those options are worthless unless AOL's stock price rises sharply.
Yet despite the deep slump in advertising, Time Inc. met its goals for the year. Executives who ran successful divisions or magazines could double their salaries, with bonuses of $100,000 or more. In addition, Ann S. Moore, the chief of Time Inc., promised that reinstating the long-term incentive program would be a primary objective in the coming year.
At the Walt Disney Company, whose latest animated film, "Treasure Planet," was a disappointment at the box office, bonuses are due in a few weeks, and in many cases they will be smaller than last year, said Zenia Mucha, a spokeswoman.

Detroit Misses Out
In Detroit, the year is ending on a glum note, but employees of foreign automakers like Honda, Toyota Motor and BMW are sharing in their employers' comparative success. Most analysts and economists expect Ford Motor and the Chrysler unit of DaimlerChrysler to make slight profits this year, but not enough to hit the companies' bonus targets. Workers at General Motors are expected to get bonus checks of perhaps $500, said David L. Littmann, the chief economist at Comerica Bank in Detroit. There were no bonus checks at the Big Three for last year.
For workers at G.M., which struggled for much of the 1990's, those checks are not far below the average of $745 received during the previous seven years. But Ford workers were accustomed to checks averaging $4,671 and Chrysler workers were used to an average of $5,654 while their companies were cashing in on the S.U.V. boom.
"This past year was the first in seven or eight years we haven't had one," said Jerome Williams, 56, a pipe fitter at a Ford plant in Avon Lake, Ohio, who is also the first vice president of his United Automobile Workers local. "Sure, it's always good to get a bonus. We're hopeful for next year, but it hinges on if we get a profit for this year."
The disparity between the Big Three and foreign manufacturers will hurt states like Michigan while pockets of the South, which is dotted with factories owned by foreign brands, will benefit.
"South Carolina, Kentucky and Tennessee will get a good boost," as well as Alabama and Mississippi, Mr. Littmann said, adding that in a good year, bonuses can bring $2 billion of extra spending to Michigan's economy.

A Few Stars in Silicon Valley
In Silicon Valley, companies are still paring their payrolls. But some technology companies are making enough to keep paying bonuses.
At Dell Computer, average bonuses run up to 20 percent of salary, but for executives they can reach 80 percent or more. The bonuses are based on individual performance goals and the company's financial performance, though not its stock price. So far this year, Dell's profits are up 15 percent. "We put a pretty significant chunk of every employee's compensation at risk," said Dominick DiCosimo, Dell's vice president for compensation.
At Microsoft, salaries have grown considerably in the last few years because the value of employee stock options, which had soared during much of the 1990's at Microsoft and other high-tech companies, has evaporated in the last two years.
"The mix of pay is shifting," said Mark W. Englizian, Microsoft's director of compensation. "Employees want more secure forms of compensation," adding that there is "nothing more secure than cash."
Annual bonuses, Mr. Englizian added, are "not a significant portion of the cash pay, and that reflects that we're a company with a research and development culture." Software products, he explained, can take a few years to develop and bring to market, so bonus criteria are not always linked to company profits.

Expecting a Letdown
Like many other industrial companies, American Electric Power computes incentive payouts after year-end earnings numbers are announced in late January, and pays bonuses in the spring.
"Since the system was put together, we maxed it out once, had a couple of 'lunch money' bonuses during off years and the rest have been somewhere in the middle," said Pat D. Hemlepp, a corporate spokesman. The company's earnings were down this year, so Mr. Hemlepp expects bonuses to come out on the low end. Most employees may expect the same, and thus are not budgeting for a windfall.
"With the wide range of payouts we've had in the last five years, I doubt if anyone's counting on this money when planning expenditures," he said. "Employees understand that company performance is the key factor, and that weak earnings override strong departmental or individual performance."
For highly paid workers in service professions, year-end bonuses often determine how much spending they can do at the holidays.
"We may get nothing," said one associate at a New York law firm. Many lawyers have assumed that they will not receive a bonus this year, she said. In the past, she added, she has used bonus money to pay down student debt.
"I've been spending a lot of money" regardless of the lack of any information about a bonus, this associate said, adding that she had recently bought a sofa and other new furniture, as well as a new laptop computer for her apartment. "I'm going to put off the 32-inch flat-screen TV," she said.
But bonuses may be most important to Wall Streeters. Two years ago, they were demanding and getting multimillion-dollar pay packages; now, most of them know that they are fortunate to have survived rounds of layoffs as securities firms have eliminated more than 75,000 jobs. 
"People who really matter will get paid, and people who would be considered journeymen will be paid very poorly," said Joan Zimmerman, a partner at Rhodes Associates, an executive search firm in New York. "The differentials in compensation are going to be almost impossible to comprehend, they'll be that large."
What will matter most is which bonus pool a banker or trader is drawing from. Some businesses on Wall Street have held up, most notably sales and underwriting of corporate and government bonds. But those dependent on profits from selling new stocks or advising on mergers and acquisitions are likely to be disappointed, compensation consultants said.
"The mantra that we hear everywhere is: Where are they going to go?" said Alan Johnson, president of Johnson Associates, a consultant on compensation based in New York. "There are very few jobs, very few open positions. Most of the people we talk to say this is the worst hiring market in a decade."

GRAPHIC: Photos: David S. Pottruck, top left, co-chief of Charles Schwab, has yet to hear if he will get an annual bonus. HEADLINE: Surprise, It's the Economy Again, Stupid! 

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
IF you measure the success of a president by job creation, George W. Bush is a failure so far. The economy now supports 2.2 million fewer private-sector jobs than it did when he was sworn into office.
 That fact didn't bother voters in last month's elections, but the president decided that he needs a new economic policy team. On Friday, as some disappointing employment numbers were released, both Paul H. O'Neill, the treasury secretary, and Lawrence B. Lindsey, the president's chief economic adviser, were pushed out. 
 Just whom Mr. Bush will turn to is unclear. Mr. O'Neill had been criticized for off-the-cuff comments that sometimes unsettled currency markets, and for not having the feel for financial markets of Robert E. Rubin, President Bill Clinton's treasury secretary.
Mr. O'Neill had been among the Bush administration officials who seemed most concerned about budget deficits, and most sanguine about the immediate economic outlook. If the Bush administration wants to sell a new economic stimulus package -- and its budget deficits -- it probably needed officials who could advocate the policy with more conviction.
That stimulus may be a good idea was indicated by Friday's job reports. It was no surprise that the number of manufacturing jobs in the United States shrank. That figure has been falling for years. But the weakness in service industries is new. The number of private-sector service jobs edged up by 7,000 in November, but is still 72,000 lower than it was two years ago, when Mr. Bush was elected.
Not since 1958 has the service sector lost jobs over a two-year period, not even during the severe recessions of 1973-75 and 1981-82. It is easy to understand why the administration might feel this was not the time to wait and hope for a better economy.

HEADLINE: Bush, Iraq and Sister Souljah 

BYLINE:  By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
I am worried. And you should be, too.
 I am not against war in Iraq, if need be, but I am against going to war without preparing the ground in America, in the region and in the world at large to deal with the blowback any U.S. invasion will produce. 
 But I see few signs that President Bush is making those preparations. The Bush team's whole approach was best summed up by a friend of mine: "We're at war -- let's party." We're at war -- let's not ask the American people to do anything hard. 
This can't go on. We are at war. We are at war with a cruel, militant Islam, led by Al Qaeda, we are at war with a rising tide of global anti-Americanism, and we will probably soon be at war to disarm Iraq. There is no way we are going to win such a multidimensional conflict without sacrifices and radically new thinking.
For me, the question is whether President Bush, having amassed all this political capital by effectively responding to 9/11, is going to spend any of it -- is going to ask Americans to do things that are really hard to win these wars over the long haul. Does Mr. Bush have a Sister Souljah speech in him? If not, if he is just going to rely on the Pentagon to fight this war -- and on Karl Rove to exploit it -- then we will reap nothing but tears.
What would the president tell the American people if he were preparing them for this multidimensional war?
He would tell the American people that this war could cost over a trillion dollars, and no one should think that we're going to be able to use Iraqi oil to pay for it. It will be paid for by our Treasury -- and that means not just changing the faces of the Bush economic team but also re-examining the surplus-squandering tax cuts at the center of the Bush fiscal policy.
He would tell the American people that he is embarking on a Manhattan project to increase fuel efficiency and slash the cost of alternative energy sources to reduce our dependence on foreign oil. Yes, it will take time, but gradually it will make us more secure as a nation, it will shrink the price of oil -- which is the best way to trigger political change in places like Saudi Arabia -- and it will provide the alternative to Kyoto that Mr. Bush promised the world but never delivered.
He would tell the American people that we can no longer afford our selfish system of farm subsidies and textile protectionism. It is a system that tells developing nations they must open their borders to what we make, but we won't give them full access to our markets for what they make: farm goods and garments. If nations like Pakistan continue to live in poverty, if their people can only afford religious schools that teach only the Koran, then we will continue to live in fear. If our national security interests lie in their development, and their development requires access to our markets, we need to open our markets and live what we preach.
He would tell the Palestinians that the U.S. intends to cut off all assistance and diplomatic contacts until they get rid of their corrupt tyrant, Yasir Arafat, because no peace is possible with him. He would tell Ariel Sharon that unless he halts all settlement building -- now -- the U.S. will start cutting off Israel's economic aid. And he would tell both that he intends to put the Clinton peace plan back on the table as his plan.
He would also tell all Arabs that America has one purpose in Iraq, once it is disarmed of dangerous weapons: to help Iraqis implement the U.N. Arab Human Development Report, which states that the failing Arab world can only catch up if it embraces freedom, modern education and women's empowerment.
Finally, he would tell Karl Rove to take a leave of absence until September 2004 so that nothing the president does in this war will be perceived as being done for political gain.
Friends, we are on the edge of a transforming moment for America in the world. If President Bush uses his enormous mandate to prepare for war -- in a way that really deals with our political and economic vulnerabilities, increases our own staying power and convinces the world that we have a positive vision and are responsible global citizens -- there is a decent chance we can win at a reasonable cost. But if Mr. Bush simply uses his mandate to drive a hard-right agenda and indulge in more feel-good politics, the world will become an increasingly dangerous place for every American -- no matter what war we fight, no matter what war we win.
