HEADLINE: AIRLINE SHOCK WAVES: THE OVERVIEW; 
BANKRUPTCY CASE IS FILED BY UNITED

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WONG 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Dec. 9 

 BODY:
United Airlines today became the biggest airline and one of the largest American companies ever to seek bankruptcy protection from its creditors.
 Under pressure from its lenders for quick action to cut costs, the company said its first step to return to profitability would be to turn once again to its workers for deep concessions, a path that industry experts warned was bound to be perilous. 
 United said that all tickets for current and future flights would be honored and that it would make no changes to its frequent-flier programs. But analysts said that further cutbacks in routes and service would be necessary down the road.
The bankruptcy filing gives United, the world's second-largest airline, more time to look for cures to its ills. But experts say the answers are no more obvious now than when United's losses started mounting at an alarming rate two years ago, during an economic downturn that starkly revealed just how unprepared traditional hub-and-spoke airlines were for the challenge from low-cost carriers like Southwest Airlines. 
Glenn F. Tilton, United's chief executive, said today that United and other large rivals would eventually have to change their operations drastically to compete with Southwest and others like it. Toward that end, bankruptcy documents disclosed today that United had hired McKinsey & Company to help it devise a new business strategy. Page C1. 
But in the meantime, United plans to rely on more conventional steps -- starting with bringing down labor costs -- in hopes of emerging from bankruptcy protection relatively intact. United is one of the largest employee-owned companies, with many workers having forgone raises for six years in exchange for 55 percent of the stock. Their stock value, though, is wiped out in bankruptcy.
"Our employees are very smart, and they know our margin is unsustainable," Mr. Tilton said in a telephone interview today. "The business plan we have with the cost structure we have won't work."
Mr. Tilton raised the prospect of being forced to liquidate the company and either sell off or shut down its operations under a so-called Chapter 7 bankruptcy filing if he fails to transform the airline. "Let me offer you two scenarios," he said. "One is the prospect of my vision and my leadership and robust employment and a competitive United. That's door No. 1. Door No. 2 is Chapter 7."
United's executives said there would be no immediate changes to the airline's schedule of 1,800 daily flights, providing service to 117 airports around the world. Travelers in turn seemed relatively calm about United's entering bankruptcy court, a step that had been expected since last Wednesday, when a federal panel rejected its application for a $1.8 billion loan guarantee.
But in the months ahead, the changes at United could have far-reaching effects on travelers and many of the airline's 81,000 workers. Executives and industry experts say the airline will have to cut back its route system and revamp its hub airport operations. The United that will take shape could be far removed from the flush, globe-straddling carrier that profited handsomely selling high-price last-minute tickets to business travelers during the economic boom of the late 1990's.
In bankruptcy court here today, a lawyer for United submitted financial numbers to the bankruptcy judge, Eugene R. Wedoff, indicating that UAL, the parent of United, was in worse shape than people outside the company had known. UAL is expected to lose $20 million to $22 million every day this month, three times what executives had previously disclosed, the United lawyer, James Sprayregen, said. Next month, United is expected to lose $10 million to $15 million a day, he said. Currently, Mr. Sprayregen told the court, the company has access to about $800 million in unrestricted cash.
United enters bankruptcy protection with $1.5 billion in debtor-in-possession financing, of which $800 million is expected to be available in 10 days. Of the total amount, four creditors -- Citigroup, J. P. Morgan Chase, Bank One and the CIT Group -- are providing equal shares of $300 million, for a $1.2 billion package. Bank One, which issues the credit cards linked to United's frequent-flier program, is putting up the remaining $300 million in a separate package.
To get access to the financing beyond the initial $800 million, United would have to meet certain financial targets. That is expected to require United to begin cutting its labor costs "virtually immediately," according to a motion the company submitted to the bankruptcy court. The airline will also need to cut an additional $300 million in nonlabor costs, an executive involved in the negotiations said. The company must also show cumulative positive cash flow, which is expected to happen in September or October of next year, according to Todd Snyder, a managing director with Rothschild, the airline's financial adviser.
Mr. Tilton said that United would present a detailed restructuring plan this week to its union leaders. In the last month, the unions agreed to tentative cuts of $5.2 billion over five and a half years, but those agreements were voided when the mechanics' union voted before Thanksgiving against giving its $700 million portion, and when the federal panel rejected the loan guarantee application.
"This is going to take sacrifice by every single member of United's family," Mr. Tilton said.
United said today that its senior managers would take an immediate pay cut averaging 11 percent of their annual salaries, with those earning less taking smaller cuts. Managers will also not receive merit and incentive bonuses this year.
United's three biggest unions -- the pilots, machinists and flight attendants -- all issued statements today expressing disappointment at the bankruptcy filing, but vowing to work with the company to ensure the airline's survival.
The pilots, machinists and nonunion workers were each given one seat on United's board in exchange for stock options granted to those workers from 1994 to 2000. But if employee ownership falls below 20 percent -- which could happen in bankruptcy if creditors and lenders are given equity -- then the workers could lose their board seats.
"There have to be some adjustments made, we know that," said Paul Whiteford, who represents the pilots' union on the board. "We pretty much know that things have to change."
But he added that it was unclear how much in concessions the company needed to survive.
Industry experts said that Mr. Tilton, United's chief executive, would have to tread carefully while asking workers for concessions. Demanding too much could badly alienate them, which in turn could drive away customers over dissatisfaction with poor service. The recent mechanics' vote, along with a bitter dispute between pilots and management in the summer of 2000, are the two most visible instances of employee hostility toward management in recent years.
"There are a lot of things you could do to cut costs that would make it impossible for the airline to run," said Peter Cappelli, a professor of management at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. While it would not unduly harm the airline if high-wage pilots were forced to accept pay cuts, "if you cut the wages of mechanics," he said, "they could go elsewhere because they have more opportunities to get work elsewhere." 
He added: "You also have this internal rivalry between the pilots and mechanics, about who's given up more in the past. You have these inequity dynamics."
Having power on the board has also given the employees "a very short threshold for changes," Mr. Cappelli added. "In the past, if management tried something that didn't work out, they got rid of the management team. Their level of patience is not there."
At airports across the country, United workers expressed fear of cuts in the future, as well as bitterness at the federal government for its denial of the loan application. Employees pondered what would happen to pension plans, how much to spend on Christmas gifts and the prospects of finding jobs elsewhere.
"Our whole lifestyle will change," said Dawn Marie Bader, a flight attendant who also serves as president of the union local in San Francisco. "We are looking at cutting back everything. We will pull back on the number of Christmas gifts we normally buy, our plan to replace the 10-year-old car and even giving extra support to our daughter at university."
While workers at the airports fretted about their paychecks, passengers mulled over their travel plans and frequent-flier miles.
"I hope I can still catch my flight back to Tokyo," said Kate Brady, an acupuncturist living in Japan who was coming off a United flight at Newark International Airport. "I'm nervous. But I've traveled in third world countries, so something always happens. There's always something to deal with. I just hope it doesn't cost me more money."
Laura Bohn, a passenger from Denver who shares 700,000 United frequent-flier miles with her husband, said: "I used to hoard my miles; now I'm going to have to start using them, I guess. Maybe we'll take more weekend trips now."
In its bankruptcy filing today, United listed $22.7 billion in assets. That far surpasses the second-largest bankruptcy filing by an airline, which took place last August when US Airways sought Chapter 11 protection, with $7.8 billion in assets. United's filing is the seventh-largest among American companies, right behind Adelphia Communications, which listed $24.4 billion in assets when it filed last June.
United had operating losses of $2.1 billion last year and $1.8 billion in the first three quarters of this year. Without the government loan guarantee, it had no immediate access to financing to keep operating and pay back debt. It had payments to lenders of $300 million due today, $575 million due on Dec. 12 and $45 million due over the next month or so.
Last spring, United hired Rothschild Inc. as a financial adviser, and it recently retained the services of McKinsey and Huron Consulting to help it restructure. Those two companies will advise United on strategy and accounting matters, respectively, in Chapter 11. Huron, for example, is already working with United on dealing with its vendors.
"They've got thousands of vendors," said Gary Holdren, Huron's chief executive. "They'll have to go through them one by one. As for the larger vendors, those will be delicate negotiations, I'm sure."
Within a week or so, the bankruptcy court will assemble a creditors' committee. The powers of United's board will be weakened considerably, because major business decisions will have to be approved by that committee. In theory, the immediate day-to-day operations of the airline will still take place under the current management, who are generally entitled to keep their jobs for at least 120 days.
Although some industry experts are blaming United's senior managers for failing to secure the government loan guarantee, there were no immediate calls from United's board for anyone's resignation.
"I think our new C.E.O. has done a terrific job in mobilizing and reorganizing and working with organized labor through all this," said John Van de Kamp, a board member. "I think a lot of good will has been developed for the future."
If he stays in the job, Mr. Tilton will undoubtedly need that good will not only for delicate labor talks, but also for negotiations in Washington. He said today that he intended to go back to the same federal panel that rejected the loan guarantee, the Air Transportation Stabilization Board, to ask for exit financing.
United is such a large presence in the industry, and it is so symbolic of American aviation, that even its rivals were not entirely jubilant today. Donald J. Carty, the chief executive of the AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, the world's largest carrier, said that United's future reduction in capacity should help other carriers, but that its cost-cutting in Chapter 11 could give it a competitive advantage in a troubled business environment. These days, he said, "we're not talking about a slice of the economic pie; we're talking about whether there is going to be a pie or not."

PERSON: John W. Snow 

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL AT THE TREASURY: THE NOMINEE -- Man in the News; 
A Pragmatist At Treasury

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 

 BODY:
John W. Snow, the railroad executive President Bush has chosen to be his next secretary of the Treasury, is a pragmatic business executive who once campaigned vociferously to place top priority on balancing the budget rather than on cutting taxes.
 "The budget deficit puts a hole in the pocket of every American, every day of their lives," Mr. Snow declared in 1995, when he was chairman of the Business Roundtable and when the budget deficit was about the same size as it is now. 
 But today, as he stood alongside President Bush at the White House, Mr. Snow made it clear that his views are now closer to the supply-side, tax-cutting philosophy that is at the center of the administration's economic policy. Page A30. 
He and Mr. Bush both alluded to the need for promoting faster growth and more job creation, which for Mr. Bush means more tax cuts for businesses and individuals even if the deficit widens in the short term.
In picking Mr. Snow as his chief salesman on economic policy, Mr. Bush settled on a middle-of-the-road Republican whose greatest strengths are not his ideological fervor but rather his skills as a manager and a communicator, his credibility in the business world and his familiarity with Washington. But in making the selection, Mr. Bush may have introduced potential tensions within his economic team over the size and scope of future tax cuts.
In a display of his political sensitivities, Mr. Snow let it be known today that he had resigned as a member of the Augusta National Golf Club, which is under criticism for its refusal to admit women as members.
Many supply-side Republicans said they welcomed the choice of Mr. Snow, saying he is an effective political player who knows how to promote Mr. Bush's agenda even if he is less than passionate about tax cuts.
"I don't want to say that John Snow is a follower of Jack Kemp's precise philosophy," Jack Kemp, a former cabinet secretary and an ardent advocate of tax cuts, said today. "I am saying that he is an outstanding choice, and he wants to do what Bush wants to do."
But if the welcome for Mr. Snow seemed guarded among supply-side Republicans, many expressed alarm at the man Mr. Bush is expected to nominate as his economic adviser at the White House, Stephen Friedman, a former co-chairman of Goldman Sachs. In the past, Mr. Friedman has identified himself as an opponent of deficits, and therefore he is highly suspect to advocates of tax cuts. 
"I am not at all pleased with Friedman," said Stephen Moore, director of the Club for Growth, a group that lobbies for deep tax reduction and an overhaul of the tax system. Noting that Mr. Friedman has been associated with the Concord Coalition, a group that campaigns for greater budget discipline, Mr. Moore accused him of being "hypersensitive about budget deficits."
Mr. Bush has not yet announced that Mr. Friedman will be his new economic adviser, replacing Lawrence B. Lindsey, who, along with the former Treasury secretary Paul H. O'Neill, was fired on Thursday. Today, the president focused on Mr. Snow, who is chairman and chief executive of the CSX Corporation, the railway and shipping company based in Richmond, Va.
Over the years Mr. Snow has cultivated his ties in Washington and spoken out on policy issues like tax changes and corporate governance. His friends range from ardent supply-side Republicans like Mr. Kemp to Democrats like Senator Jon Corzine of New Jersey.
John William Snow, 63, was born in Toledo, Ohio, on August 2, 1939. His father was a lawyer and his mother a homemaker. He earned a Ph.D. in economics at the University of Virginia in 1965 and a law degree at George Washington University. He spent part of his early career in the Ford administration and was head of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration in 1976 and 1977.
He then became a lobbyist for the old Chessie System, now part of CSX, and moved through a series of senior management posts before becoming chief executive of CSX in 1991.
At CSX, Mr. Snow's biggest accomplishment was probably to engineer the takeover, with the Norfolk Southern Corporation, of the giant freight rail system owned by Conrail. CSX and Norfolk Southern became locked in a bidding war, then essentially agreed to carve up Conrail between the two of them in a $10 billion deal in 1997.
Mr. Snow has been planning to retire next year, and he had essentially picked his successor. 
Throughout the past decade, he kept a hand in public policy. He was chairman of the Business Roundtable, a lobbying organization for chief executives of large corporations, in 1995 and 1996. He served on a commission studying tax reform led by Mr. Kemp. And this year he was co-chairman of a panel on corporate governance organized by the Conference Board, a business group. 
"John is a very smooth operator, very personable and someone who everyone feels comfortable with," said John Meagher, a Republican tax lobbyist who has known Mr. Snow for years. "He's a mainstream Republican, and he's a player."
But Mr. Corzine, who has been friendly with Mr. Snow for years, says he is convinced that Mr. Snow is instinctively uncomfortable about letting the government run big budget deficits.
"These guys are team players, and I am sure they will agree whenever they are in public," Mr. Corzine said today. "But behind closed doors, he will be a Concord Coalition traditionalist, very concerned about the budget deficit."
Separate from the tax issue, Mr. Snow emerged this year as an outspoken critic of what he called excessive compensation for corporate executives and poor corporate governance.
Teaming with Peter G. Peterson, chairman of the Blackstone Group, Mr. Snow assembled a panel of highly respected business and economic leaders who urged companies to change the way they awarded stock options and stop rewarding executives who failed to improve their companies' operating businesses.
"He had the guts to take on the tough issues, and to resolve them," Mr. Peterson said. "His heart is in the right place."

John William Snow

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; 
Snatching Complications From the Jaws of Victory

BYLINE:  By RICHARD BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
THE CONQUERORS
Roosevelt, Truman and the Destruction of Hitler's Germany, 1941-1945
By Michael Beschloss
Illustrated. 377 pages. Simon & Schuster. $26.95.
 "We come as conquerors, but not as oppressors," went Dwight D. Eisenhower's Proclamation No. 1, as Allied forces crossed into Germany in October 1944. The mixture of toughness and possible leniency in his first words to the Germans has over the years taken on a gloss of inevitability. A program of punishment alone, an attempt permanently to cripple defeated Germany, wouldn't have brought about the prosperous, democratic postwar ally that is without doubt one of the great success stories of American foreign policy. 
 But as the historian and television commentator Michael Beschloss shows in "The Conquerors," Eisenhower's statement was full of political meaning and came only after a sharp debate within the administration of Franklin D. Roosevelt over how to treat Germany after the war.
Treasury Secretary Henry Morgenthau Jr., a major figure in Mr. Beschloss's account, wanted Eisenhower's proclamation to begin, "We come as militant victors to ensure that Germany shall never again drench the world with blood." But Morgenthau's vision of a sort of Carthaginian peace was opposed by others, notably War Secretary Henry L. Stimson and his chief deputy, John J. McCloy, and in the instance of Proclamation No. 1 it was their view that prevailed. With many fits and starts, and many instances of what seemed to be presidential vacillation, the Stimson-McCloy view prevailed in general.
Mr. Beschloss's book traces the debate over how to deal with postwar Germany as it raged within Roosevelt's administration and then, after his death one month before V-E Day, within Harry S. Truman's. As we have come to expect from Mr. Beschloss, whose two latest books were based on the secretly recorded tapes of Lyndon B. Johnson, this new book shows a strict adherence to the documentary record. As he did with his two Johnson volumes, Mr. Beschloss virtually transcribes and edits the record as he lays out the conflicting visions of Morgenthau and Stimson, even as Roosevelt and then Truman seemed to agree and then to disagree with one side or the other.
"The Conquerors," in other words, not only closely follows the movements and initiatives of the men wrestling with the shape of the postwar world, but alsoreproduces their conversations, meetings, diary entries and phone calls. 
Morgenthau, the only Jew in Roosevelt's cabinet and only the second Jew ever to serve in a cabinet (the first was Oscar S. Straus, secretary of commerce and labor to Theodore Roosevelt), emphatically wanted to punish Germany for its wartime atrocities by destroying its industries, giving away chunks of its territory to neighboring countries and transforming it into a largely pastoral nation that could never become a military threat again. Twice already during the 20th century, Germany, which was viewed as inherently militaristic and authoritarian, had caused world wars, and it could only be prevented from doing so a third time, in Morgenthau's view, if it was made permanently weak. 
At one point, illustrating his attitude, Morgenthau was talking with his aide Harry Dexter White about whether the Ruhr industrial region should be shut down or not.
"White warned that shutting down the Ruhr would exile millions of Germans and harm the rest of Europe," Mr. Beschloss writes. Morgenthau's reply: "Why the hell should I worry about what happens to their people?"
On the other side was Stimson, patrician, wealthy, contemptuous of Morgenthau and against his playing a key role deciding the German future on the ground that, as Stimson put it, "He, as a Jew, is the last man who ought to do it." Stimson, at the height of the competition for Roosevelt's heart and mind, told McCloy over a scrambled telephone line that Morgenthau was trying to foment "a very bitter atmosphere of personal resentment against the entire German people" that would lead to "clumsy economic action" as a weapon of "mass vengeance."
Mr. Beschloss is an efficient, workmanlike but not especially elegant or stylish guide through the twists and turns of these debates. His book is not literary in the way that, say, Simon Schama or Robert Caro might write history, full of brilliantly rich portraits and elaborate backgrounds. The focus is a narrow one, on a crucially important policy debate and the manner in which two adept presidents heard out their competing cabinet members without openly committing themselves philosophically to either side. Mr. Beschloss keeps his own commentary and analysis to a minimum, though here and there he does offer a useful explanatory comment.
He does this, for example, in several chapters that he devotes to the debate that took place at the time over whether the Americans should bomb the railroad tracks leading to the death camps, or perhaps Auschwitz itself. Morgenthau pressed Roosevelt to take action, or at least to speak out about the slaughter of the Jews. But Roosevelt refused to do so until 1944, and Mr. Beschloss, who calls that a serious mistake, speculates on the reasons: Roosevelt didn't need the Jewish vote; he might have worried that it would create domestic divisions "over what the war in Europe was really about"; he might have felt that departing from a single war aim would lead Stalin, a mass murderer himself, "to distrust his intentions."
Mr. Beschloss also closely traces the various Big Three meetings among Roosevelt (later Truman), Stalin and Churchill, from Casablanca in 1943, when Roosevelt first suggested the phrase "unconditional surrender" to define the overall policy toward Germany, to Potsdam in 1945, when the division of Germany into four zones of occupation was made final. No decision, in Mr. Beschloss's account, was easy or uncontested, not even unconditional surrender, a policy that bothered many American military commanders on the ground that it might convince the Germans they had no choice but to fight to the bitter end.
But in the end the main lesson of Mr. Beschloss's fine study is that what happens after a war is as important as what happens on the battlefield. This would seem a good lesson to keep in mind as the United States deals with Afghanistan following the anti-terrorism war there and contemplates an effort to transform dictatorial Iraq (whose ruler is said to admire Hitler) into a democracy.

HEADLINE: A TASTE OF SAN FRANCISCO; 
Fluent in French, With a West Coast Accent

BYLINE:  By AMANDA HESSER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO 

 BODY:
The frisee aux lardons at Florio was correct, as the French would say. The crisp frisee wilted slightly when bathed with the warm egg yolk, creating a tangy, creamy dressing. Salty bits of bacon slipped in here and there. I washed it down with a moody Gigondas, and looked out the window onto a placid street in Pacific Heights.
 If it seemed weird to be eating old-school French fare in a city where menus typically pay homage to the producer of everything from the veal down to the butter, it was not an aberration. After decades on the culinary frontier, defining a new American cuisine on a foundation of local foods and seasonal cooking, San Francisco has shifted into reverse, with more than a dozen new bistros settling in neighborhoods from Potrero Hill to the Financial District to the East Bay. 
 French cooking has long been a forceful presence in San Francisco's best kitchens, but having tolerated earnest California cooking for years, its adherents were ripe for a culinary revolt. They've done it in a stunning fashion and a vibrant confluence of cooking styles. 
The new bistros in San Francisco are French at the core, but American in manner. The frisee aux lardons at Chez Spencer, for instance, is smartened with a fan of smoked duck breast resting under the frisee. The lamb chops at Chez Nous are sprinkled with coarse sea salt infused with lavender; two chops are served alone. A watercress salad at Absinthe is brightened with slices of local persimmon and pomegranate seeds.
The bistros are appearing at a convenient time, too. "The San Francisco economy has been completely decimated in the past two years," said Meesha Halm, the editor of the San Francisco Zagat guide. "Our two biggest industries are high tech and tourism, so the high tech industry was gone before, and then 9/11 destroyed tourism. So basically we lost the out-of-town diners as well as the big expense accounts in the local economy."
Now, the city's many suddenly less rich foodies, preferring not to suffer on pizza, have turned to duck confit for comfort. While many restaurants, like Jardiniere and Redwood Park, where main courses hover around $28, are slow, the bistros are flourishing.
If I were surviving on my last few stock options, I would make Chez Papa Bistrot in Potrero Hill my cafeteria. 
It sits on the corner of a sunny hill, from which you can see the bay, downtown and the hazy outlines of Nob Hill. There is a sliver of patio jammed with zinc-topped tables and a pot of lavender. 
Inside the tiny square of a restaurant, formerly Daily Scoop, is a sensualist's paradise. There is the humming of the hood fan, the clatter of plates being stacked, the whining grind of a coffee machine. A fruit basket filled with flame-red persimmons crowns the tiny bar. When a breeze pushed in the front door, it swept the rich, sweet scent of lamb daube under my nose. 
The butternut squash soup and a potato, artichoke and asparagus salad began the meal with a statement. The soup was sweet, pure and as vivid as the freshly cut flesh of the squash. In the center of the bowl were tiny melted lumps of Parmesan cheese and bacon. The potatoes and baby artichokes in the gratin were bound with a warm, tangy mustard dressing and freckled with the mustard seeds. The potatoes were creamy and loamy, the artichokes sweet and still quite firm.
A pan bagnat was served on a floury roll, stained with balsamic vinegar. Inside were thin strips of cucumber, tuna, anchovies, olives and slices of egg and tomato. With it came the world's thinnest French fries -- strands really -- and a ramekin of garlicky, lemony aioli for dipping.
The daube, which kept the chef behind the counter busy, his head bobbing from stove to the stack of plates, then arrived. Baby carrots, turnips and white onions were colorful outcroppings in a dark glossy pool of lamb and sauce.
Chez Papa does not specialize in any particular region. The selections are generic, and in that way, perhaps Parisian. For desserts, there are creme brulee and tarte Tatin. The cherry clafoutis is delicious with boozy cherries nestled in a soft almond custard. But, then, the memorable conclusion to the meal was not a dessert at all. It was a mint tea, served Moroccan style: sweet and short in a tiny glass. On its surface floated a sprinkling of pine nuts.
Chez Papa has been so successful that the owners recently opened up another sliver-size restaurant down the block. It's called Chez Maman and is a creperie.
THIS seems to be the way restaurants in San Francisco are growing these days. Another bistro, Absinthe, near the War Memorial Opera House, has opened a sandwich shop and a wine shop, all on the same block. The ambition is low and the penetration is concentrated to a single neighborhood.
The affordability of these bistros, though, may be more coincidence than a reaction to the current economic climate.
"We started this project, putting it together from a conceptual standpoint, when the dot-coms were still booming," said Robert Cubberly, the chef and an owner at Le Petit Robert, which opened in October 2001. "A lot of the restaurants opening in the last year, I think they've all probably started when the economy was booming. What happened when the economy was booming, the only leases you could get were small spaces in neighborhoods." 
Chez Spencer is proof of this. It occupies perhaps the least desirable plot in the city. The loftlike restaurant is wedged into a dark, industrial street, whose main feature is an Office Max. It was the original location of the popular bakery and restaurant Citizen Cake and then was rented to a dot-com company. The company moved its desks and computers in, leaving the bar and wood oven intact. When it went under, Laurent Katgely swooped in. 
It's a spare, beautiful space with great arching trusses on a white ceiling, a cement floor, a brick oven and a few random hunting trophies -- a set of elk antlers and a large goose that looms menacingly over the bar with its wings spread.
Here is perhaps the best bistro food you will find in San Francisco right now. It's not quite as inexpensive as the other bistros. Dinner is about $70 a person. 
And although Mr. Katgely puts out-of-season vegetables like asparagus on the menu, in a city where that is akin to heresy, he is a gifted cook. The asparagus, admittedly, was superb. It was stacked like thin rods in a deliciously earthy, stone-colored truffle emulsion.
I would skip the sardines, which have an Asian dressing and are a distraction on a generally well-edited menu. Then I would order three of the foie gras terrines, because you won't want to share it. It was the ideal terrine: sweet, buttery and light. It melted in your mouth like whipped cream, and was served with a fluffy cloud of brioche and a quince compote, which was set on the plate with tiny trails of pepper on either side. 
Main courses were hefty. A wood-grilled Angus rib-eye was bathed in a red-wine reduction, a creamy morel sauce and then truffle butter. A succulent gamy squab rested on barley soaked in a foie gras jus. It may be haute bistro, but it's not cuisine minceur. 
Some of the best dishes I had during a week of eating out were this kind of simple, hearty fare. At BeauCoup, which opened just a few months ago, cater-cornered to the Fairmont Hotel on Nob Hill, Bruno Davaillon, the chef, bravely serves a chicken fricassee with garlic and green beans. The meat is all dark meat and the dish is mostly brown. But the sauce is rich and viscous from gentle cooking and the beans are soft, having soaked up the juices. You might think you were in France if there weren't such a hopping bar scene 10 feet from your table.
"When you look at the product that you get in San Francisco," Mr. Cubberly said, "and you look at what you get in France, we rival them in raw material and in some cases exceed what they do. We have our local cheese makers making French-style cheeses. We have Liberty foie gras and natural meats from Niman Schell, and good produce."
"Part of it is a culmination of 20 years of what Alice Waters started," he said, "which is using local indigenous products and treating them simply. That's also French bistro. It's a European concept that we didn't have in America until 25 years ago. Now, you have all of these chefs who have grown up in this environment. Part of it is a natural progression, of going back you might say. Of completing a cycle."
I adored the food at Mr. Cubberly's Petit Robert for just this reason. Everything seemed familiar, and yet surprises nudged you in every bite. A French onion soup was filled with silky onions, a distinctive, herbal broth and bread so drenched in it that it was like a fluffy mousse.
Brussels sprouts were shredded like confetti and sauteed, then folded together with an apple cider vinegar dressing and chopped hazelnuts. A thick pork chop was rubbed with a coarse grind of picholine olives and set on a mound of mashed Yellow Finn potatoes. And the braised lamb shank was soft and fragrant with cinnamon. Under it was an unassuming pile of couscous that sparkled with mint.
BISTROS have been around in San Francisco for years. More than a decade ago, Fringale and Bizou were the first to make a splash. Near them is another vintage bistro, South Park Cafe. They're now a little worn on the edges, but they're still going strong. The new bistros do not feel like flimsy copies. Many have been opened by single owners with a soulful purpose: survival. 
Pascal Rigo, who is a San Francisco version of Brian McNally, is the only real entrepreneur. He has opened a number of bistros and boulangeries over the last three years, including Le Petit Robert, Chez Nous, Bay Bread Boulangerie, Marinette, La Table, Galette and Boulange de Polk. 
"We invest in neighborhoods that were always busy before the dot-com craziness," Mr. Rigo said, "and I think that has helped us. We wanted neighborhoods where people are sleeping, not where people are working."
Each of his places has a slightly different slant. Chez Nous serves bistro food in a tapas style. Galette is a creperie. And La Table is set among expensive boutiques on Sacramento Street. It has a bistro dining room and a more formal dining room. The latter was empty when I visited. The bistro was full.
Like many of the bistros, it has a partially open kitchen, a design fad that has not yet died in this city. It's pleasant to have the visual theater of cooks' heads waving with activity. It gives you a sense of progress, especially when you ask your waiter to give you just one more minute to read the menu, and he takes that to mean 20.
The appetizers at La Table were original, small and tasty little bits in the manner of amuses-bouches. The frisee salad was more about oxtail, which was salty and rich like confit. A rye bread "roestie" -- a k a toast -- was spread with fromage blanc, red onion and a salt-cured anchovy. The toast was springy and crisp, and the topping exploded with flavor. A guinea hen terrine was similarly amplified and had a zippy persimmon chutney on the side for relief.
Despite quite good food, it was the only place where the service felt impersonal, if not rude. When I asked the waiter a question, he said, curtly, "Was I supposed to hear that?"
Was I supposed to leave him a tip? 
Most of the other bistros are small and the staff is attentive. "Many of these places are run not with 6 or 12 partners," said Hubert Keller, the chef and owner of Fleur de Lis. "It's places which are basically run by a couple, and they put what little they have in savings into it. You know, it's like the owner is there. It's that whole feeling that people connect with Europe and France."
Only it's right here in San Francisco. And the oeufs on your frisee are from Napa. The boudin is made in Oakland. And the pommes de terre were planted by a friend of Alice Waters.

Paris in San Francisco: Bistro Food and Boulangeries

HEADLINE: Fatwa Victim or a Fraud?; 
Mystery Enshrouds Kola Boof, Writer and Internet Persona

BYLINE:  By JULIE SALAMON 

 BODY:
Who is Kola Boof?
 She might be, as she claims, the object of a fatwa ordering her death because of her vehement criticism of the Muslim government in her native Sudan. Or she might be, as some have suggested, an author trying to bring attention to her books by fabricating a provocative public persona, using the specter of fatwa as a marketing ploy. 
 Either way, the Kola Boof story demonstrates how flashpoints are reached in cyberspace, the new forum for underground literature and politics, where fact and myth become indistinguishable and publicity campaigns become a kind of performance art. Without the imprimatur of a major publisher or a mainstream review or a public appearance, she has managed to instigate anger and discussion about her work.
Ms. Boof said a fatwa was ordered up on her in London for her stand against organized religion, but particularly against Arab Muslims. Sudanese officials in London, however, said that was not true. One of those officials did denounce her in Al-Sharq Al-Awsat, a leading Arab-language newspaper in the United Kingdom. A number of well-known African-American activists have taken up her causes, which include her opposition to slavery in the Sudan and her condemnation of stoning and female castration and other harsh measures taken against African women. 
They include Derrick Bell, the New York University law professor and author of several books, most recently "Ethical Ambition: Living a Life of Meaning and Worth," and Joe Madison, the Washington radio personality who for 14 years was on the board of the N.A.A.C.P. The attention has translated into sales. "Long Train to the Redeeming Sin" (North African Book Exchange), her collection of earthy and impressionistic stories about racial identity, has been selling briskly on AALBC.com, an online service that specializes in books for African-Americans, but is by no means a best seller.
Ms. Boof's Web site appeared on the Internet a few months ago, presenting her as a mysterious but alluring figure, whose life provided a potent brew of international politics, diplomatic and sexual -- part Graham Greene, part Jacqueline Susann. Among other things, she claims she briefly was Osama bin Laden's mistress, in the late 1990's.
More often, in subsequent postings and interviews, she invokes the memory of her father, an Egyptian archaeologist, and her mother, a Somali nomad. Ms. Boof said they were killed in front of her in Sudan, where the family was then living, and that her given name was Naima Bahri. Sometimes she says she was 10 or 12, sometimes 8. After that, she said she was adopted by an African-American family in Washington, whose names she won't reveal.
Her startling author photograph for "Long Train," in which she poses defiant and naked from the waist up, has become the subject of much lewd Internet chat. Ms. Boof said she wanted to discredit the notion that breasts were sexual objects and to celebrate the nakedness of African women. She has deplored the influence of Western culture on African women, and certainly, "Long Train" presents a bleak and angry vision of their lives.
Soon she was being touted on radio programs as an advocate for the cause of southern Sudan in the 20-year civil war between the Arab-dominated government in the north and the subjugated black African south. She says she was born Muslim, but has since rejected organized religion. In a statement posted on the Web, she says, "For just as Harvard University is an institution created by men so is every religion."
Now newspapers have begun associating her name with fatwa in diverse outlets like Pravda, The Village Voice, The Washington Times and The New York Post.
The Sudan People's Liberation Movement, representing the non-Muslim faction in the civil war, embraced her and then backed away, as Ms. Boof's personal, if not literary, credentials have been called into question. They may be more cautious, too, since the Sudan Peace Act was signed by President Bush on Oct. 21, which authorizes $300 million in aid to the south and requires the two sides to negotiate in good faith.
"Her writing speaks of anguish and protest and of fighting against an unjust regime," said Deng Ajak by telephone from London, where he is secretary general of the Sudan Commission for Human Rights. Mr. Deng has read excerpts of "Long Train" on the Internet, but has not read the book itself.
Mr. Deng added: "But when she said in one of her own e-mails to me that she had a brief encounter of dating Osama bin Laden, I said to my colleagues that we need to pull the plug on this one. This could be one of the most impressively spun and choreographed pieces of fiction that one could imagine, or she may be legitimate. That is a big maybe for now."
Ms. Boof manages simultaneously to seek publicity and to shroud herself in secrecy. Her publisher isn't just obscure; it is curiously absent. Calls taken by an answering machine at the Fullerton, Calif., office of the North African Book Exchange went unanswered. But her book "Long Train" does exist.
"I can't deny that I'm a conniving person," said Ms. Boof -- or a woman who said she was Ms. Boof -- in a series of telephone conversations that took place after many e-mail messages were exchanged. She made the calls, refusing to divulge her whereabouts, except to say she was somewhere near Los Angeles. "I came from hell," she said. "My parents were killed in my presence. That changed me forever. I have to manipulate the system, and I don't mind if you publish that. Women have to manipulate the system to teach young women how to grow up and be better women than I am."
"People can't believe my life is real," she said. "But the pain of it has been like living in a furnace."
She said she was shot at outside Los Angeles -- and that she shot back -- and that she was under F.B.I. protection. The F.B.I. in Los Angeles said, through a spokeswoman, the agency had no knowledge of Ms. Boof. This didn't faze Ms. Boof. "That's their way of protecting me," she said.
On the telephone, the woman was articulate and loquacious, moving from humorous self-deprecation to passionate denunciation of the treatment of women in Islamic countries. She told flamboyant stories about her life in Egypt and Morocco, where, she said, she was a B-movie actress and a high-level prostitute, operating in luxury hotels, not on the street. 
Her "sudden" appearance on the Internet several months ago wasn't accidental. "Long Train" was originally published in Arabic, in North Africa, and released in this country a year ago. Yi Nee Ling, then the public relations person for North African Book Exchange, created the campaign to make the writer's work known to African-American female audiences in the United States. "I used the Internet to give the world an 'African Garbo,' " Ms. Ling said by e-mail. "But Kola Boof seems to be tearing it down. She talks too much in my opinion." Ms. Ling said she recently parted ways with the publisher and Ms. Boof.
The campaign was successful in a modest way. "Kola Boof is good at promotion, at getting her name out, and moving her book," said Troy Johnson, who founded AALBC.com, the online bookselling service, in 1998. "For an author not published by a major house, her book is doing better than any book of its type." But sales are still small, even though Ms. Boof is one of his top sellers. "In the hundreds, not thousands," Mr. Johnson said.
By early November, Ms. Boof's public relations strategists also included Ajowa Nzinga Ifateyo, a political activist and former reporter for The Los Angeles Times and The Miami Herald, and Maria Sliwa (sister of Curtis Sliwa, who 20 years ago attracted much attention with his Guardian Angels, self-appointed protectors of New York City's subway passengers). Ms. Sliwa, now 47 and studying journalism at New York University, has traveled to Sudan and has been working to bring attention to human-rights violations there. 
Ms. Ifateyo signed on after reading about Kola Boof on the Internet. "I was so moved, so touched, so sad," she said. For two weeks, every day at the bus stop I'd think about her. What can I do to help this woman. I sent her an e-mail to let her know I support her." Only then did she read "Long Train," which fascinated her and disturbed her. "I had never seen such beautiful descriptions of black skin," she said. "As a fellow writer, I thought she was just wonderful."
Ms. Sliwa and Ms. Ifateyo contacted many news organizations, including The New York Times, to announce that demonstrations on behalf of Kola Boof would take place at the United Nations in New York and in front of the Sudanese Embassy in Washington on Nov. 7. Only a handful of people turned up (including this reporter), but that fact was omitted in subsequent public discussions on the Internet. Ms. Boof's ranking on Amazon.com's mysterious daily measurement of its book sales jumped from 190,000 to 951 in a day and she was booked on several radio programs.
One of those shows was "Back to Africa," Mr. Madison's nationally broadcast satellite radio show. "Her conviction and commitment to the whole Sudan peace effort just impressed me," said Mr. Madison, who for six years has been trying to bring the spotlight to the issue of slavery in Sudan. He interviewed Ms. Boof for an hour, by telephone.
"I didn't approach this interview naively, and I questioned her extensively and she didn't hesitate," he said. As for her claim of death threats, Mr. Madison said: "This is not a unique experience. That's something that happens to most people who have taken up this issue. The more visible you are, the more vocal you are, the more threats you receive."
Alicia Banks, a former talk-show host in Atlanta, now living in Arkansas, said she has met Ms. Boof, the first time in 1997. "My biggest concern for Kola is that she is haunted by some deep, dark secrets," Ms. Banks said.
Sudanese diplomats insist that no fatwa has been issued. "It's quite bizarre and baseless this claim," Jamal Ibrahim, the deputy head of the Sudanese mission to Britain, said in a telephone interview. "My own view is that she wants to make use of this to help her in selling her books. It is a bizarre exercise in public relations."
That didn't stop Mr. Ibrahim from contributing to the publicity, by writing an attack on Ms. Boof in Al-Sharq Al-Awsat. "Kola Boof is a 'phobia-maker' produced by the new crusade to tell us that she came to fight Islam," Mr. Ibrahim wrote.
"This woman who is full of insanity and falsehood and dishonesty has nothing to make us afraid of her," he continued. "She is a wooden cross planted in the field to terrify the birds from eating the fruits when they are ripe, though she is standing in a spot where the Islamic world should pay attention." 
But criticism isn't the same as a fatwa, which is a juristic opinion issued by a Muslim scholar to address a specific problem, that can be related to political, economic or social issues. "Nobody issued a fatwa against Kola Boof," said Sheikh Omar Bakri, a senior judge of the Islamic Sharia court in London. "I know she was criticized by a Muslim official in London, but he isn't in a position to issue a fatwa."
Professor Bell of N.Y.U. read "Long Train" and admired it. He began an e-mail correspondence with Ms. Boof several months ago when she sent him a fan e-mail message and asked for advice about publishing. Though he never met her, she confided in him about problems with her boyfriend and her fears of being assassinated.
"She never asked me for money or to do anything on her behalf," he said. "I volunteered to send her work to my agent. I have no sense she's a sham. Am I the most knowledgeable person in recognizing a hoax? No. But I do recognize jive and I got no sense of that."
Not all of Ms. Boof's supporters feel as certain. Ms. Sliwa has distanced herself because she is worried that the murkiness surrounding Ms. Boof could hurt the cause of those opposing the Khartoum government. "I don't think it behooves our human rights interest to connect ourselves with someone who is inconsistent and can't prove her identity," Ms. Sliwa said.
And there are those of Sudanese origin who are frustrated that it takes a Kola Boof to bring attention to the problems in Sudan. "I don't know why she wants to be an activist," said Edward Malwal, an international trade specialist for the state of Connecticut. Mr. Malwal has lived in exile from his country since 1979 because of the political situation there. "Why doesn't she let her writing speak for itself?" he asked.
But then she wouldn't be Kola Boof -- or would she?

PERSON: To Huu 

HEADLINE: To Huu, 82, Vietnam Poet And Communist Voice, Dies 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
To Huu, who was often called the poet laureate of the Communists' victories over the French and the Americans in Vietnam and who went on to high posts in the country's postwar government, died in Hanoi on Monday. He was 82.
 His death was reported yesterday by Agence France-Presse. 
 "He was a great poet who used his poetry as a means to gather and encourage people around the revolutionary cause over the decades," said the newspaper Saigon Giai Phong, which is controlled by Vietnam's Communist government.
To Huu was one of a group of Vietnamese poets who wrote about little else than the Vietnam War, urging people to fight, uphold socialism and defeat the United States. But Nguyen Ngoc Bich, an expert on Vietnamese literature, argued in a 1972 publication that To Huu transcended his peers.
In a lecture included in a booklet "Some Aspects of Vietnamese Culture" (Southern Illinois University, 1972), Mr. Ngoc Bich wrote that To Huu "alone manages to instill some force and vitality into his work." He added, "The others are no more than hacks."
But the poet's ideology was never subtle. In a poem quoted in The New York Times magazine in 1981, To Huu lamented the death of Stalin. It read in part:
 Oh, Stalin! Oh, Stalin!
The love I bear my father,
my mother, my wife,
myself
It's nothing beside the love I bear you.
Oh, Stalin! Oh, Stalin! 
What remains of the earth
and of the sky!
Now that you are dead.
Doan Van Toai, the author and a former South Vietnamese dissenter who had come to oppose the Communists, wrote that it seemed "incredible" that such a poem could be written in Vietnam, which is known for the strength of family love.
In To Huu's poem, "Since Then," quoted in "A Thousand Years of Vietnamese Poetry" (Knopf, 1975), he wrote of the moment he discovered Communism, "summer light has burned in me." Another poem in the same book celebrates the joys of sabotaging a road.
To Huu was born Nguyen Kim Thanh in Thua Thien Province in 1920 and educated in Hue, according to "Dictionary of the Vietnam War" (Peter Bedrick Books, 1981). He became a Communist as a student in 1938, and was jailed the following year for his political activities.
He escaped from prison in 1942 and was appointed in August 1945 as a regional information chief for the Viet Minh, the guerrilla opponents of the French colonizers. 
After the defeat of France in 1954 and the partitioning of Vietnam, To Huu became deputy culture minister in the North Vietnamese government. In 1956, he was appointed to the Central Committee of the Communist Party.
During the war with the United States, he held various positions in the government, including chief of the propaganda, education and scientific boards of the Central Committee organization. In 1976, he rose to the ruling Politburo.
He became deputy prime minister and was considered a candidate for prime minister until he was dismissed from the cabinet in 1986 for mishandling the economy.
His ability to combine true lyricism with revolutionary propaganda was his greatest legacy, as suggested by the poem "Little Luom." It tells of his nephew being killed in "a jet of blood." The poem ends gently:
His cap askew
he whistled away
like a warbler
on a garden path.

HEADLINE: Trying to Buy Our Way Out of Trouble 

BYLINE:  By Lizabeth Cohen; Lizabeth Cohen, a professor of history at Harvard, is author of the forthcoming "A Consumers' Republic: The Politics of Mass Consumption in Postwar America."

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. 

 BODY:
Retailers are not the only Americans paying more attention to the ringing of cash registers than Christmas bells this holiday season. Politicians, the news media and even some consumers anxiously await the daily reports on how we're doing with our spending, as if hourly notification of the fluctuations in the stock market were not feedback enough about the nation's precarious economic health. Consuming, we're repeatedly told, is our best hope for keeping recession at bay.
 The obsession with consumer spending is not as recent a phenomenon as we might think. It is worth recalling that America's astounding recovery in the late 1940's and 1950's, after 15 years of debilitating Depression and war, was built around a mass-consumption-oriented, demand-driven economy. Government officials, business leaders and organized labor all shared the view that "our economy feeds and grows on purchasing power as a baby does on milk," as the Congress of Industrial Organizations put it. 
 Spending earned income, moreover, was not enough. Vastly expanded consumer credit inflated that purchasing power, to the point where at least half of all household appliances and 60 percent of all cars were purchased on credit, contributing to a whopping nineteenfold growth in the value of installment credit between 1945 and 1960. Typically, when President Dwight D. Eisenhower faced a deepening recession in 1958, he promised that an economic recovery would result from "millions of citizens making their purchases, having greater confidence," which the government would support with more home and highway building and the easing of credit.
Americans of this early postwar era had more than economic ambitions for a dynamic mass-consumption economy. They believed it would nurture a more egalitarian and democratic nation as well. Citizens, living better than ever before, would be on an equal footing with their prospering neighbors. And as Vice President Richard M. Nixon reminded Soviet Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev in their famous "kitchen debate" outside a model suburban house at the American trade exhibition in Moscow in 1959, Americans exercised their cherished freedoms by making independent decisions in markets as well as in politics.
Less often calculated in these boom times, however, were the costs of entrusting these long-sought American ideals of social equality and political democracy to private consumption, even when supported by new government spending in the way Eisenhower promised: a G.I. Bill of Rights that helped returning vets buy homes and thereby qualify for more consumer credit; federally funded highways that literally paved the way to newly built houses and shopping centers in expanding suburbs; income tax deductions for mortgages and credit that encouraged still greater consumer spending.
But even with rising tides of prosperity, the postwar consumer culture fed inequalities that are still very much with us. As we embrace brisk sales as an answer to our current economic ills, it bears noting that consumerism has played a role in reinforcing social biases and prejudices. Consider, for example, shopping malls, whose daily sales receipts are an indicator of our hoped-for recovery -- and whose history shows the ties between mass consumption and inequality.
The regional shopping centers became the quintessential retail structure to emerge in postwar America. In a remarkably short time, they displaced urban downtowns. The suburban share of total metropolitan retail sales mushroomed from 4 percent in 1939 to almost 60 percent in 1961 in the 10 largest population centers. By 1976, 78 percent of total department store sales took place in branch stores, most of them in shopping centers strategically located at highway exits and along the busiest thoroughfares in suburbia.
As retailers chose to bring "the market to the people instead of people to the market" -- as an article in The New York Times Magazine described the strategy in 1953 -- they inevitably favored some people over others. Shopping centers aimed at what Macy's Annual Report for 1955 called "middle-income groups" explicitly distanced themselves from consumers deemed undesirable because they were too poor, black, or young and unruly. At a time when many low-income Americans didn't own cars, the few bus routes to shopping centers were carefully planned to transport nondriving customers, particularly women, from nearby suburbs, not low-income consumers from inner cities.
In a troubled city like Newark, all the major downtown department stores closed as suburban shoppers started staying closer to home. In addition, the largely black Central Ward became a commercial wasteland after the 1967 race riots, which prompted white-owned stores to close and banks and insurance companies to resist supporting new investment. Thus city residents without cars were largely excluded from participating in the promises of postwar consumerism. And if customers looking conspicuously different from typical suburbanites actually made it to the mall, they were often met by unwelcoming security guards who had been hired by management and were not accountable to any public authority.
Inequality manifests itself in other ways. For example, malls have done little to encourage public transportation to accommodate the low-paid, urban workers who now dominate shopping center sales forces. (Initially, many of these jobs were held by suburban housewives, who then turned to more lucrative careers in the 1970's.) The death in 1995 of a black retail clerk from Buffalo, killed trying to cross the seven-lane highway that separated her bus stop from her job inside a suburban mall, was only the most brutal example of this form of discrimination.
The location of shopping centers reinforced other discriminatory policies. As developers sought sites close to the affluent populations to which they catered, their presence augmented the prosperity of host communities, exacerbating an already unequal distribution of economic resources in metropolitan areas. Not only did a suburban municipality with a shopping center find its residential property values increased by convenient proximity to stores, but the presence of major commercial development greatly enhanced its tax base and, in turn, its core services like schools, which are funded overwhelmingly through local property taxes.
While Newark's commercial infrastructure was crumbling, a mere dozen miles away the upscale Short Hills Mall poured dollars into suburban Millburn's tax coffers. By the mid-1970's, it had helped to raise that town's per-pupil school expenditure to 36 percent above Newark's, while its property tax rate was actually 41 percent lower. Education, the major vehicle to upward mobility in postwar America, became captive to the shifting geography of commerce.
So before we praise consumer spending too lavishly this holiday season, it is worth recognizing that totaling up the dollars spent is not enough. Last week, Wellington E. Webb, the mayor of Denver, made this point when he implored his fellow citizens to do their holiday shopping in city stores rather than over the Internet because local merchants and the city's sales-tax-dependent coffers were suffering from the surge in e-commerce. One can appreciate Mr. Webb's sentiment. A broad-based recovery is defined not just by dollars spent but also by who has dollars to spend -- and where they are able to spend them.

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Urged to Promote Flow of Refugees From North Korea 

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 

 BODY:
In 1989, Hungary snipped open its barbed-wire border with Austria, allowing thousands of East Germans vacationing in Hungary to escape Communism. The tide of refugees turned into a flood, hastening the collapse not only of East Germany, but of the Iron Curtain, historians say.
 Now a growing number of Bush administration officials, policy experts and lawmakers say they are hoping to set off a similar chain reaction inside North Korea. They argue that the stream of refugees from the starved, Stalinist nation into China could sharply increase, particularly if China agreed not to send North Koreans back, and if South Korea and the United States took in more escapees. 
 "If this regime were actually to collapse, it won't be through an elite coup," said Victor D. Cha, associate professor of government and a Korea expert at Georgetown University. "Real regime change will come from the bottom, from people who can't oppose the regime but who can vote with their feet."
A senior administration official said: "When Hungary and Czechoslovakia opened their borders to East Germans, it helped speed the collapse of the Berlin Wall. Supporting refugees from North Korea could stress their system, too."
In Congress, Senator Sam Brownback, the conservative Republican from Kansas, and Senator Edward Kennedy, the liberal Democrat from Massachusetts, have sponsored legislation that would remove a provision in immigration law that makes it difficult for North Koreans to seek asylum in the United States. 
House Republicans have also called on the administration to share the costs of resettling North Korean refugees with South Korea, China, Russia and other Asian countries, much as it did with Vietnamese boat people in the 1970's.
"It looks like factors are lining up and history is clearly against the North Korean regime," Mr. Brownback said in a recent interview. "It's a failed state. It's starving its own people."
The administration and refugee advocates are also calling on Beijing to give the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees access to the North Korean border region, where it can screen potential refugees and assist their safe movement to other nations. As the flow of refugees rose, China expelled the United Nations from the border in 1999, arguing that most North Koreans were merely trying to better their economic circumstances.
"I think the Chinese are beginning to understand it's a problem," a senior State Department official said.
Another senior official said that once South Korea elected a new president this month, Washington would press harder for Seoul to accept more refugees. Although the Constitution states that all North Koreans can become citizens of the South, Seoul has accepted only about 2,000 North Korean refugees since 1954, experts said. 
Almost no North Koreans can escape across the heavily mined and militarized border with South Korea, which has also been ambivalent about the difficulties of assimilating such refugees and concerned that some are North Korean agents. 
"The South Koreans have not been famously sympathetic," said Nicholas Eberstadt, at the American Enterprise Institute in Washington.
But if South Korea accepts more refugees, China may allow the United Nations to shelter and feed them en route, and perhaps open a resettlement office along the border. Doing that, in turn, could encourage more northerners to flee, refugee advocates contend.
"China doesn't want to have to feed tens of thousands of refugees," the senior administration official said. "But if they thought these people would only stay a few weeks, it might change their mind."
President Bush has appeared to endorse a policy of helping the refugees, telling The Washington Post in a recent interview that he loathed Kim Jong Il and disagreed with those who say "we don't need to move too fast" against North Korea because of the financial costs. 
"Either you believe in freedom," Mr. Bush said, "and worry about the human condition, or you don't."
But there are sharp differences within the administration over how hard to push the refugee policy, with some officials arguing that the North Koreans might just crack down harder on border crossers. "This is not the East German regime," said one senior official. "It's much more brutal."
No one knows exactly how many tens of thousands of North Koreans are in the neighboring region of China. But the number is thought to have risen with a deepening famine in North Korea, which aid groups say has cost 2 million lives.
Over the summer, refugee groups organized daring attempts by North Koreans to break into embassies in Beijing to seek asylum and to illustrate the refugees' plight. The Chinese allowed some to travel to South Korea but it arrested many others and returned them to the north. The Chinese have since fortified security around the embassy compounds, and escape attempts have declined sharply.

HEADLINE: Charges Issued In Smuggling Of Parts to Iran 

BYLINE:  By ERIC LICHTBLAU 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 

 BODY:
A crackdown on smuggling military parts to Iran led to federal indictments today against three executives and three companies charged with violating export laws.
 Federal prosecutors said the companies had tried to sell engines, gear assemblies, spare parts and munitions for fighter planes and military helicopters without required State Department approvals. The sales, the prosecutors said, went through a sham Austrian corporation set up by undercover Customs Service agents. 
 "It's the seller's obligation to make sure export laws are followed, and these companies acted as if they just didn't care," Steven M. Biskupic, the United States attorney for Milwaukee, said in an interview. "In the past, these types of violations may have been viewed as more regulatory than anything. In the post-Sept. 11 period, the dangers and the reasons for these restrictions are much more readily apparent."
Charged with violating export laws were Jami S. Choudhury, 38, of Wauwatosa, Wis.; William W. Manning, 55, of Clinton, Utah, and the company where he is a vice president, Camnetics Manufacturing of Oregon, Wis.; Andrew A. Adams, 63, of Monroe, N.C., and the company that he heads, Equipment and Supply International; and Rick's Manufacturing and Supply of Harrah, Okla.
None of the defendants was taken into custody because prosecutors said they were not considered to pose a threat or a flight risk. 
Mr. Adams said he did not know of the indictment until a reporter called him this evening. "I don't know anything about this," he said, declining to answer further questions. 
At issue, prosecutors contend, are broad violations of export laws punishable by up to 10 years in prison and $1 million in fines. They did not say the executives or companies knew that the military parts they were selling were headed for Iran or anywhere else.
Mr. Choudhury has been linked to the Iranian black market. He was sentenced to six months of home confinement in 2000 for lying to a federal agent about sales of airplane parts to Iran. Mr. Choudhury said at his sentencing that he was "humiliated enough to last a lifetime."
Federal officials said today that they believed that he resumed the illegal export business not long after his release from confinement. 
The indictment against Mr. Choudhury charges that he and executives at Rick's Manufacturing arranged to have five shipments of rebuilt starter engines, designed for use in C-130 transports, shipped to Taiwan. Officials charged that Mr. Choudhury falsified invoices to understate the $20,000 value of the engines and to make it appear that the sales did not require an export license.
Prosecutors said the defendants also arranged to sell parts and supplies for F-4 and F-15 fighters and Sikorsky military helicopters.
The case grew out of recent cases in Milwaukee and elsewhere in which businesses sold military and aircraft parts, computer supplies and gas testers to Iran in violation of bans.
In 1995, President Bill Clinton imposed trade sanctions against Iran for what he called its sponsorship of terrorism and pursuit of weapons of mass destruction. President Bush has declared Iran one of the three countries of an "axis of evil."
Concerned about growing black-market sales, authorities in Milwaukee set up an undercover operation, posing as buyers in Vienna for black-market supplies.
"We've had an ongoing problem with people trying to purchase weapons for Iran, missile components, military jet components and more," a spokesman for the Customs Service, Dean Boyd, said.

HEADLINE: Text of Statement on Interest Rate Policy 

 BODY:
Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Fed's monetary policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, voted to leave the benchmark rate unchanged:
 The Federal Open Market Committee decided today to keep its target for the federal funds rate unchanged at 1 1/4 percent. 
The committee continues to believe that this accommodative stance of monetary policy, coupled with still robust underlying growth in productivity, is providing important ongoing support to economic activity. 
 The limited number of incoming economic indicators since the November meeting, taken together, are not inconsistent with the economy working its way through its current soft spot. 
In these circumstances, the committee believes that, against the background of its long-run goals of price stability and sustainable economic growth and of the information currently available, the risks are balanced with respect to the prospects for both goals for the foreseeable future. 
Voting for the F.O.M.C. monetary policy action were Alan Greenspan, chairman; William J. McDonough, vice chairman; Ben S. Bernanke, Susan S. Bies; Roger W. Ferguson Jr.; Edward M. Gramlich; Jerry L. Jordan; Donald L. Kohn, Robert D. McTeer Jr.; Mark W. Olson; Anthony M. Santomero; and Gary H. Stern.

PERSON: John R. Dellenback 

HEADLINE: John R. Dellenback, 84, Former Oregon Republican Congressman 

BYLINE:  By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
John Richard Dellenback, a four-term Oregon congressman, Peace Corps director and leader in Christian college education, died on Saturday at a hospital in Medford, Ore. He was 84 and lived in Medford.
 The cause was viral pneumonia, his family said. 
 A prominent Rockefeller Republican and lawyer, Mr. Dellenback represented southwestern Oregon in Congress from 1967 to 1974. 
He took a special interest in education and natural resources and wrote the bill that established the Oregon Dunes National Recreation Area in 1972. The legislation shielded a 47-mile stretch of undulating beaches from Florence to Coos Bay, with majestic white dunes that slope as high as 500 feet from the Pacific shore. The measure preserved one of the West Coast's natural treasures.
While in Congress, Mr. Dellenback sought a balance between energy concerns and conservation. He helped put amendments into the legislative go-ahead measure for the trans-Alaska pipeline, assuring that the pipeline's beneficiaries would be held responsible for any damaging oil spills.
His run for a fifth term foundered in the aftermath of the Watergate scandal. He fell in 1974 to a Democratic challenger; it was the first defeat of a sitting congressman in Oregon since 1932.
President Gerald R. Ford kept Mr. Dellenback in Washington as director of the Peace Corps. He held that post until 1977.
Mr. Dellenback was known among his colleagues on the Hill as a diligent straight arrow who shunned alcohol and tobacco. He had long been active in the work of his Presbyterian Church at home.
After leaving the Peace Corps, he became president of what was then known as the Christian College Coalition in Washington, an alliance of 10 small evangelical four-year colleges. Under his tutelage, its membership swelled to 77 by the time he left in 1988. (The coalition, renamed the Council for Christian Colleges and Universities, now has about 100 members.)
Born in Chicago, John Dellenback graduated from Yale in 1940 with a degree in economics. He was a lieutenant in the Navy in World War II, then went on to earn a law degree from the University of Michigan in 1949. He taught economic law at the University of Oregon for two years before going into practice in Medford.
He was elected to the Oregon Legislature in 1960 and served until his election to Congress. He was also a delegate to the Republican National Conventions of 1964, 1968 and 1972.
Mr. Dellenback is survived by his wife of 54 years, Mary Jane Benedict Dellenback; two sons, Richard L. and David A., of Salem, Ore.; a daughter, Barbara C., of Eugene, Ore.; a brother, Robert J., of Rome, Ga.; and three grandsons.

HEADLINE: Cup of Kafka? Coffee Roaster Cited for Coffee Smell 

BYLINE:  By ANDY NEWMAN 

 BODY:
On 19th Street in Brooklyn, where Donald Schoenholt has his factory, industrial odors abound. 
 Depending on the wind, the dark tang of ink from the printing plant next door might mingle with the fumes of solvent and paint from the signmaker up the street or the auto-body shops along Third Avenue. A constant olfactory drone of diesel exhaust permeates the neighborhood, and the Gowanus Expressway passes almost overhead. 
 So Mr. Schoenholt, president of a company that calls itself the city's oldest coffee roaster, was more than a little surprised on the warm day last June when a city inspector handed him a summons for polluting the air around his plant, on the outskirts of Sunset Park. 
The problem: "Offensive coffee odors." The potential fine: Up to $400.
Mr. Schoenholt's latest hearing date is next Tuesday. He intends to fight.
"This is not a smell that makes people sick," he said yesterday at the warehouselike headquarters of Gillies Coffee Company, as a hot load of decaf Colombian beans tumbled dark-roast brown from a chute. "This is one of those sweet smells like cut flowers, like fresh-baked bread, that's part and parcel of life in every city across the world."
Mr. Schoenholt, 57, said that Gillies, which supplies "coffee bars, private clubs, fine dining rooms, starred restaurants and boutique hotels" as well as Fairway supermarkets and other retailers, was being threatened by the very city it has called home for 162 years.
But the City Department of Environmental Protection said it had little choice but to issue the violation, after receiving several complaints from a nearby resident.
The administrative code under which Gillies was cited specifies that "no person shall cause or permit the emission of air contaminant, including odorous air contaminant . . . if the air contaminant . . . may cause detriment to the health, safety, welfare or comfort of any person." 
The code names 32 sources of contamination, including slaughterhouses, bone distilleries, coal tar plants and sulfuric acid makers. Coffee roasters do not appear on the list, but Charles G. Sturcken, special counsel to the Department of Environmental Protection, said that there was plenty of room for subjective judgments of offensiveness.
"From time to time," he said, "what can be normal smells that one might appreciate in the city can be, if they continue for hours and hours, considered noxious by some people. We've given these violations to Krispy Kremes. We've given them to pickle manufacturers."
In fact, one of Mr. Schoenholt's neighbors said that the vent stack on top of the roasting plant really did give off a nasty smell sometimes.
"It's really bad," said Michael Alfonso, who was stringing Christmas lights in front of the house he grew up in, directly across the street from the plant. "It smells like burning, melting plastic." Mr. Alfonso said he did not call the city, and Mr. Sturcken would not identify the complainant.
Yesterday afternoon, Mr. Alfonso, 38, said the factory smelled fine -- "like fresh-brewed coffee" -- but the plastic smell, he said, gives him nausea and headaches.
Mr. Schoenholt said the smell could not be coming from him. "There's no plastic used in the process at all," he said. Only coffee beans go into his roaster, the walls of which are lined with brick and steel, he said.
This is not the first time a coffee roaster has run afoul of the smell police. In 1995, a Cooper's Coffee bar on the Upper East Side was fined repeatedly at the request of a woman who lived above it and said the smell made her sick.
But the largely industrial north end of Sunset Park is not the thickly residential Upper East Side. When Mr. Schoenholt moved his company there in 1991 from Greenwich Village -- encouraged, he said, by a city program to help manufacturers move from Manhattan to other boroughs -- he was one of more than a dozen roasters in the area, clustered around the Continental Terminals, at that time the biggest port for green coffee in the Northeast. The coffee trade has since moved to ports in New Jersey, and all the roasters moved out except for Gillies. 
While the fine Mr. Schoenholt faces is not crippling, he said it was important to fight it. "Once it has been established either through conviction or because you admit guilt by paying a fine," he said, "you are on the slippery slope. It's a matter of time before you're forced to move your business from New York City."
So far, Gillies has lined up the support of a few elected officials. State Senator Carl Kruger, who represents the Brooklyn neighborhood where its co-owner, Hy Chabbott, lives, called the summons "a disgusting and despicable act," and plans to hold a news conference today at the factory.
If he cannot beat the violation, Mr. Schoenholt said, he does not know what he will do. Engineers have told him that there is no way to stop a coffee roasting plant from smelling like roasting coffee from time to time.
Mr. Sturcken said maybe the Department of Environmental Protection could help. "We could send some inspectors out there," he said. "Sometimes we have a good way to advise them on some of the odors."
Mr. Sturcken was asked if all the hundreds of cafes and shops that now roast their own coffee were potentially in danger.
"You know," he replied, "we're complaint-driven. You never know what the next unfortunate little economic boomlet in a product is going to do to the quality of life or to someone's sensibilities."
