HEADLINE: Cleaning Up Malaysia's Bad Debts 

BYLINE:  By WAYNE ARNOLD 

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia 

 BODY:
Mohamed Azman Yahya is hard to keep up with. A fast talker with a rapid-fire intellect, he is also an avid amateur racecar driver.
 In Asia's financial community, though, Mr. Azman, 38, is best known for his speedy cleanup of Malaysia's debt problems. And he is already moving on to run his own company, having helped rid his country's banks of almost $13 billion in bad loans in only four years. 
 "I always intended to go back into the private sector," said Mr. Azman, chairman of Pengurusan Danaharta, the agency handling the debt crisis. Mr. Azman also served as head of the corporate debt restructuring committee and, after a government takeover, the deeply indebted conglomerate UEM-Renong.
Asia, particularly Japan, is famous for debt crises. Cleaning up the morass of bad debt means severing the ties among politicians, bankers and executives who have defined the region's development for 50 years.
Investors once considered Malaysia the epitome of such "crony capitalism," and Malaysia's prime minister, Mahathir Mohamad, its unrepentant adherent.
Yet even as Mr. Mahathir thumbed his nose at the International Monetary Fund, he and his officials were apparently cultivating younger technocrats who could run Malaysia Inc. without owning it. With Mr. Azman at their helm, they have nearly completed what economists say is a primer for countries in need of overhaul.
"The Malaysians got this thing right," said Manu Bhaskaran, the Singapore-based partner at the Centennial Group economic consultancy in Washington. 
Mr. Azman is on the verge of accomplishing what his Asian counterparts can only dream of: without taking over or closing a single bank, he forced banks to write off their biggest nonperforming loans and averted a credit crisis. Now, without producing widespread layoffs or selling chunks of the nation to foreigners, he is selling off those loans.
Malaysia's troubles reached critical mass in 1997, when the Asian crisis washed south from Thailand. After growth in lending of 70 percent a year to finance the purchase of stocks, office buildings and hotels, more than a quarter of Malaysia's bank loans slipped into default.
Malaysia's leaders responded by setting up a triumvirate of agencies. One, Danamodal, pumped cash into the banks, while the corporate debt restructuring committee helped companies rework their debts. 
The most urgent task, however, belonged to Danaharta: mop up the bad loans before they forced banks to stop lending new funds. In May 1998, the government announced that Mr. Azman, a little-known banker with few apparent political connections, would lead the agency.
The son of a small-business man, Mr. Azman grew up in one of Malaysia's most conservative Muslim states -- a verse from the Koran hangs prominently over his desk. 
After earning a degree from the London School of Economics, Mr. Azman returned and by 1994 had become Malaysia's youngest bank chief executive. All the while, he pursued a passion for motorcycle racing. After a serious accident, he switched to racing cars.
To build the bad-debt agency, Mr. Azman assembled a team of five bankers that spent three months studying other countries' experiences, including the successes of the Resolution Trust Corporation in the United States and the frustrations of Thailand and Indonesia. 
Danaharta's counterpart in Thailand closed 56 failing finance companies and nationalized 2 banks. But in its haste to raise funds, it sold the finance companies' assets at just 25 cents on the dollar, igniting political protests.
Thai banks were left to decide whether to sell their bad loans. Most, hoping payments would flow when the economy recovered, held on, only to have more loans go bad. When they tried to foreclose, borrowers tied them up in courts. Seeing how easy it was, many healthy borrowers defaulted as well. Thailand is now replacing the agency with a new one modeled on Danaharta.
Indonesia's Bank Restructuring Agency, or I.B.R.A., closed 66 banks and took over 14, becoming the country's biggest property owner. But corrupt courts have enabled borrowers to elude foreclosure, and political interference and xenophobia have hobbled efforts to return I.B.R.A.'s assets to the private sector.
Mr. Azman is the first to admit that his task was less formidable. Malaysia was never so short of cash that it had to sell assets at any price. And its capital controls, though reviled by investors, kept the financial system flush with cash. 
Malaysia's banks were also never as deeply mired in bad debts, and because Malaysia had long before banned them from lending to affiliates, they were not as intertwined with their borrowers. Equally important, Mr. Mahathir's government avoided the kind of political upheaval that seized Indonesia and Thailand.
As a result, Danaharta never had to take over banks. Instead, it offered to buy any bad loan over 5 million ringgit ($1.3 million) at a price it determined and pay the bank 80 percent of anything it recovered above that. If banks declined, they were required to write the loan's value down to Danaharta's offer price anyway.
"We wanted to make sure banks that were reckless in lending were punished," Mr. Azman said, but that nonperforming loans "remained at reasonable levels." Danaharta bought 19.8 billion ringgit ($5.2 billion) in bad debt for 46 cents on the dollar.
The government enacted the Danaharta Act to enable the agency to take over management of debtors or foreclose without going to court.
"The main reason for our success," Mr. Azman said, "was the strength of the Danaharta Act."
By 2000, Mr. Azman's agency was entertaining officials from bad-debt agencies around the region, as well as from the World Bank, the I.M.F. and the Treasury Department.
In 2001, Mr. Mahathir chose Mr. Azman to carry out a chore investors and analysts had demanded for years: the purge of Halim Saad, one of the nation's biggest tycoons, from the helm of United Engineers Malaysia and its debt-laden affiliate Renong. Accounting for 5 percent of all Malaysian bank loans, Renong loomed like a tsunami over Danaharta's efforts. 
Mr. Azman engineered a buyout of Mr. Halim and was then named a director of the newly combined UEM-Renong. 
The next month, Mr. Mahathir ordered him to take charge of the corporate debt restructuring committee. Within a year, the committee had increased the amount of debt successfully restructured by 65 percent. Declaring its work finished, the committee disbanded this summer.
Danaharta is also winding down, and plans to close by 2005. Despite a global downturn, the agency forecasts that it will recover 57 percent of the value of its loans.
Mr. Azman plans to leave Danaharta next spring to run his own company, a small financial software consulting firm called Symphony Global. While he may be willing to leave government to politicians, analysts and investors are waiting to see whether Malaysia's government will leave banking to bankers. 
"I think they've done a good job," said J. Mark Mobius, president of the Templeton Emerging Market Fund. "But embedded in the political system there is a natural tendency for favoritism towards certain groups, political bodies and so forth. More has to be done."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mohamed Azman Yahya, chairman of Pengurusan Danaharta, assembled a team that studied other countries' debt experiences, including the successes of Resolution Trust in the United States. (Tara Sosrowardoyo for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BLOCKS; 
Public Space, Private Sales, at a Price

BYLINE:  By David W. Dunlap 

 BODY:
UNLIKE sidewalk vendors on Fifth Avenue, Henri Bendel executives probably don't spend much time looking over their shoulders to see if the law is around. But it could be argued that they are doing much the same thing as the peddlers: taking over public space without authorization to show off their goods.
 What appears to be the forecourt of Bendel's flagship store -- with makeup counters in the corners and a merchandise island piled high with teddy bears, snow domes, nutcrackers, ceramic Santas and penny-candy Christmas trees -- is actually a public atrium. 
 It is supposed to be retail-free under the terms of a permit issued in 1988 to allow development of the 712 Fifth Avenue office tower, at 56th Street. Bendel occupies much of the base of the tower, behind the facades of the former Rizzoli and Coty Buildings, both landmarks. 
Bendel's selling floors extend from the atrium, where visitors are meant to enjoy views of subtly sculptural windows installed in 1910 by the French glass master Ren Lalique. Today, Lalique's sinuously braided vines are only partly visible. The middle windows are all but obscured by fabric screens along a balcony used by the Garren salon at Bendel.
Requests for comment this week from the Limited Inc., Bendel's parent company, were not answered.
Bendel's apparent failure to comply with the permit was noted as a "commercial takeover" in the book "Privately Owned Public Space: The New York City Experience" (John Wiley & Sons), by Jerold S. Kayden, the City Planning Department and the Municipal Art Society. That was two years ago. Little seems to have changed since then.
A commercialized atrium is scarcely the gravest problem facing public space in New York, but it does underscore the pitfall of trading municipal approvals for privately financed public amenities. Without the resources to enforce the terms of these deals, the benefits may end up flowing in one direction only.
Each small erosion of the public sphere -- padlocks on passageways, advertising placards wrapped around parking meters, open-air restaurants spreading into plazas, corporate logos displayed on lamppost banners -- contributes to a growing sense that the city belongs less to citizens than to security guards and marketers.
The point, though, is not that Bendel has ruined the atrium. To the contrary, it has enlivened the space. The enormous wreath suspended over the main floor obviously delights arriving shoppers. The Christmas merchandise is a pleasure to look at, and the makeup-demonstration counters contribute a welcome sense of bustle.
But they are simply not supposed to be there, Mr. Kayden said.
"A continuing lack of compliance with legal obligations by public-space users and owners, especially well-known ones, can undermine the significant role played by public spaces," said Mr. Kayden, an associate professor at the Harvard Graduate School of Design, whose book documented and analyzed more than 500 public spaces created in return for zoning concessions and bonuses.
In 1988, the developers of 712 Fifth Avenue agreed in writing that the "ground floor of the Fifth Avenue atrium at all times shall be restricted to unobstructed lobby use and may not be used for any retail sales activities."
They also agreed that on the second through fourth floors there would be an "unobstructed viewing path" around the openings to the floors below "to ensure viewing access to the Fifth Avenue atrium and the architectural glass" -- that is, the Lalique windows.
Mr. Kayden recalled that the atrium had an ethereal quality before Bendel moved in. "Today, it's unrecognizable as a public space," he said. "I don't think the department store needs to be swept out of every square foot, but I do think it needs to be made legal."
THERE are precedents for trying to strike such a balance. Two years ago, the city sued Worldwide Plaza on Eighth Avenue. Planners said the seating arrangement and signs there conveyed the impression that chairs and tables intended for the public could only be used by customers of the restaurants on 49th and 50th Streets.
The case has been resolved, said a spokeswoman for the City Planning Department, by permitting the operation of two open-air cafes while also requiring improved landscaping, increased public seating and a guarantee that half the seats around the restaurant kiosks would be unrestricted.
David Karnovsky, counsel to the planning department, said the Bendel situation had not escaped the city's attention but that, since resources are limited, enforcement efforts had to be chosen carefully. 
"Our primary focus is on situations where there has been a total denial of access," he said. "That will always be our top priority."
As for Bendel, Mr. Karnovsky said, the situation might be resolved through negotiations that acknowledged that this is a public space surrounded by a department store. "Of course, we would work with them and consider anything they'd want to propose that was reasonable," he said. "They have not come in."

HEADLINE: Schr der Says He Won't Quit Despite Strife In His Party 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Dec. 11 

 BODY:
Eleven weeks ago, Chancellor Gerhard Schr der confounded the skeptics by holding on to his job. Today, he was forced to deny rumors that he would leave it.
 Mr. Schr der said he had no plans to resign, despite reports that he made a veiled threat to quit at a meeting of his Social Democratic Party on Monday. The chancellor has been buffeted by dissent within the party, which has seen a vertiginous drop in popularity since its narrow election victory in September. 
 His coalition partner, the Green Party, has added to the impression of disarray by declaring that Germany should not grant the United States unrestricted access to its airspace and military bases for an attack on Iraq, unless it received a mandate from the United Nations.
Two weeks ago, Mr. Schr der said he would give the Pentagon the freedom to fly in German skies and to move troops in and out of American bases here. His gesture was seen as an effort to patch up relations with Washington, which frayed after he opposed a war.
"The chancellor won't leave the ship," Mr. Schr der said to reporters in Berlin. "All who attach hopes to that will be disappointed, and all those who would have been disappointed will be happy."
He did not comment on whether he had threatened to quit at the party meeting. But he made it clear that he would no longer brook public dissent from party officials on issues like taxes, where his own zigzag policy has incurred the wrath of voters.
"One can debate things internally but should address the outside world with one voice," he said.
German newspapers have seized on the squabbles as evidence that Mr. Schr der's grip is weakening. Some speculated that unless his fortunes improved, he might hand over power to his economics and labor minister, Wolfgang Clement.
Support for Mr. Schr der's party has tumbled 10 percentage points since the election, to 28 percent, the swiftest decline in postwar history. In part, that is a reflection of Germany's moribund economy. But voters also blame the chancellor for breaking a pledge not to raise taxes.
"It's incredible, but it shows you the public mood," said Reinhard Schlinkert, the chairman of Dimap, a polling firm in Bonn. "Voters are in a state of uncertainty."
Mr. Schlinkert said he doubted that the chancellor would resign so soon after his re-election, though there is a precedent in German politics. In 1966 Ludwig Erhard, a Christian Democrat, resigned after a year in office, in the face of seemingly intractable economic problems.
The more likely result of Mr. Schr der's unpopularity, Mr. Schlinkert said, will be a defeat in elections next February in the states of Hessen and Lower Saxony. 
In Lower Saxony, the chancellor's home state, the governor, Sigmar Gabriel, has become a nemesis of Mr. Schr der. A rising star within the party, he is advocating a new tax on wealthy people, despite the chancellor's opposition.
Mr. Schr der's taxes, which seek to spread the pain more evenly, have made him the target of bitter jokes, a satirical song and a campaign to send shirts to his office. The message is that the new taxes will rip the shirts off the backs of Germans.
Mr. Schr der's opposition to a war in Iraq has played better among people here. But even his small gesture to the United States of access to German airspace has drawn quibbles from the Greens.
They say it should be denied if the United States proceeds without the approval of the United Nations, even though they acknowledge that such a prospect now seems less likely. "There have been misgivings, strong misgivings," said Reinhard B tikover, one of the party leaders.
Those misgivings may deepen after a television interview today with Mr. Schr der, in which he indicated that German crews would be permitted to fly on NATO surveillance planes in the event of a war.
Mr. Schr der said Germany was not backtracking on its refusal to take part in a military campaign, because the Awacs planes would be used only to safeguard NATO territory and airspace.
Despite their cavils, most politicians here said they had little choice but to support Mr. Schr der.
"The chancellor is the boss, and his voice should be the decisive one," said Dieter Wiefelsp tz, a Social Democrat legislator. "We all know we won the election thanks to him."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
Sticks and stones can break bones, but the wrong name can make a job hard to find.

BYLINE:  By Alan B. Krueger; Alan B. Krueger is the Bendheim professor of economics and public affairs at Princeton University and editor of The Journal of Economic Perspectives. E-mail: akrueger@princeton.edu.

 BODY:
WHAT'S in a name? Evidently plenty if you are looking for a job.
 To test whether employers discriminate against black job applicants, Marianne Bertrand of the University of Chicago and Sendhil Mullainathan of M.I.T. conducted an unusual experiment. They selected 1,300 help-wanted ads from newspapers in Boston and Chicago and submitted multiple r sum s from phantom job seekers. The researchers randomly assigned the first names on the r sum s, choosing from one set that is particularly common among blacks and from another that is common among whites. 
 So Kristen and Tamika, and Brad and Tyrone, applied for jobs from the same pool of want ads and had equivalent r sum s. Nine names were selected to represent each category: black women, white women, black men and white men. Last names common to the racial group were also assigned. Four r sum s were typically submitted for each job opening, drawn from a reservoir of 160. Nearly 5,000 applications were submitted from mid-2001 to mid-2002. Professors Bertrand and Mullainathan kept track of which candidates were invited for job interviews. 
No single employer was sent two identical r sum s, and the names on the r sum s were randomly assigned, so applicants with black- and white-sounding names applied for the same set of jobs with the same set of r sum s. 
Apart from their names, applicants had the same experience, education and skills, so employers had no reason to distinguish among them.
The results are disturbing. Applicants with white-sounding names were 50 percent more likely to be called for interviews than were those with black-sounding names. Interviews were requested for 10.1 percent of applicants with white-sounding names and only 6.7 percent of those with black-sounding names. 
Within racial groups, applications with men's or women's names were equally likely to result in calls for interviews, providing little evidence of discrimination based on sex in these entry-level jobs.
There were significant differences in interview-request rates among the nine names associated with black women, but not among the names within each of the other groups.
At the low end, the interview-request rate was 2.2 percent for Aisha, 3.8 percent for Keisha and 5.4 percent for Tamika, compared with 9.1 percent for Kenya and Latonya and 10.5 percent for Ebony. 
Only part of this variability reflects chance differences resulting from sampling, although the authors have not been able to find a good explanation for the wide range. Thus it is important that the names chosen for black women were not uncommon; they represent 7.1 percent of all names listed on Massachusetts birth certificates for black girls from 1974 to 1979. 
The 50 percent advantage in interview requests for white-sounding names held in both Boston and Chicago, and for both men and women.
This discrepancy complements findings from earlier studies in which researchers sent a small number of matched black and white "auditors" to apply for jobs in person. Typically, though not always, the black job seekers were less likely to be invited for an interview or offered a job. 
Those findings, however, were criticized because the applicants knew the intention of the study and might have behaved differently. In addition, the auditors might not have been well matched with the jobs in question; they could have been overqualified or underqualified. 
Professors Bertrand and Mullainathan's study is less susceptible to these concerns. First, they used a large number of names and inanimate r sum s. Second, the job openings involved administrative, sales, clerical and managerial positions, and they submitted r sum s patterned after real r sum s of people who were actually seeking similar jobs.
Their most alarming finding is that the likelihood of being called for an interview rises sharply with an applicant's credentials -- like experience and honors -- for those with white-sounding names, but much less for those with black-sounding names. A grave concern is that this phenomenon may be damping the incentives for blacks to acquire job skills, producing a self-fulfilling prophecy that perpetuates prejudice and misallocates resources. 
Two main theories explain labor market discrimination. One, known as taste-based discrimination, posits that employers -- or customers, co-workers or supervisors -- have a preference against hiring minority applicants, even if they know they are equally productive. 
The other, known as statistical discrimination, assumes that employers personally harbor no racial animus but cannot perfectly predict workers' productivity. In this case, an employer assessing an applicant would assign some weight to the average performance of the person's racial group, instead of basing the judgment solely on the individual's merits. 
A difference between these models is that employers sacrifice profits to indulge in taste-based discrimination, while, in principle, statistical discrimination, if based on accurate information, can help the bottom line. Professors Bertrand and Mullainathan cannot distinguish between the models -- and both may be applicable -- but they suspect that their finding that employers in heavily black areas of Chicago are less likely to discriminate against black-sounding names augurs for taste-based discrimination. 
Nevertheless, either rationale for discrimination is illegal and prohibited.
"That which we call a rose," Juliet said, "by any other name would smell as sweet." An organization like the Civil Rights Commission or the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission could perform a service if it routinely monitored discrimination by conducting audit studies similar to Professors Bertrand and Mullainathan's.

HEADLINE: A Dependence on Tobacco 

 BODY:
Gov. George Pataki has a terrible plan to balance New York State's budget: paying for continuing expenses with borrowed money. It's shocking that a man who likes to depict himself as an economic conservative would come up with such a scheme before he has even begun to talk about cutting costs or raising taxes. 
 During his re-election campaign, Mr. Pataki tried to give the impression that all the economic miseries hitting other states had bypassed New York. Now the governor has suddenly discovered a $2 billion hole in this year's $90 billion budget, with an even larger one looming next year. 
 Mr. Pataki's solution is to borrow money against the payments the tobacco industry is supposed to give the state over the next 25 years. Unlike New York City, which used tobacco money to borrow for one-time capital projects, Mr. Pataki wants to use the cash to pay this year's and perhaps next year's operating expenses. It is, as conservative politicians used to say, like taking out a loan to pay the monthly grocery bill, knowing that the same bill will be back a month later, along with a demand for payment on the loan.
Mr. Pataki balanced last year's budget with one-shot revenues and argued that it was necessary because of the 9/11 emergency. But today almost no one is expecting the quick economic turnaround he would need to make his plan work.
He wants to get approval for this borrowing as soon as possible, but the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, has balked -- a healthy reaction. Legislators need to see the entire budget plan so they can weigh all possibilities. The underlying threat from the Pataki quarters is that unless the Legislature agrees to a tobacco bailout, state funding for health care or education will have to take the hits instead.
Nobody thinks there is an easy way out of New York's fiscal problems, but most other states began months ago shaving expenses and raising taxes to cover their deficits. By being the pre-election Pollyanna, Governor Pataki has delayed the hard choices and made a difficult process so much worse.
Instead of settling in for a winter vacation, the State Legislature should get to work identifying service cuts and new revenues. One of the worst aspects of Mr. Pataki's plan is that it lets the lawmakers -- always eager to shirk hard choices -- off the hook. New York State is facing a fiscal crisis. Albany can no longer whistle its way out.

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: SEABORNE TRADE; 
Warnings From Al Qaeda Stir Fear That Terrorists May Attack Oil Tankers

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: ABOARD PETRO RANGER, in the Strait of Malacca, Dec. 6 

 BODY:
As the distant jungle shore of Malaysia faded from green to gray to black at sunset, Noer Rahman put a bright red fire ax on the back deck of this aging tanker, then tied two high-pressure fire hoses to the stern handrail and turned them on.
 Mr. Rahman, an experienced Indonesian sailor, was getting ready to fight pirates and terrorists, dangers especially great in this important waterway, the fastest route around the southernmost tip of continental Asia. 
 A recent audiotape believed to have been made by Osama bin Laden praised and seemed to take responsibility for a suicide attack two months ago in which a speedboat packed with explosives rammed and crippled a French tanker, the Limburg, off Yemen. Other leaders of Al Qaeda have vowed to cut the "economic lifelines" of the world's industrialized societies. 
The threats have focused the attention of intelligence agencies and marine police worldwide on the vulnerability of tankers. Representatives of most of the world's seagoing nations are meeting in London to discuss how to keep ships safe from the long-term problem of piracy and the new risks of terrorism.
"With the attack on the Limburg, commercial vessels, especially vulnerable vessels like tankers, are terrorist targets," said Pootengal Mukundan, the director of the International Maritime Bureau, a United Nations affiliate that works with Interpol to combat seaborne crime.
Nowhere has the concern been more acute than here in the Strait of Malacca, between Malaysia and Indonesia. A quarter of the world's trade passes through the strait. That includes half of all sea shipments of oil, bound for East Asia or sometimes the United States, and two-thirds of the world's shipments of liquefied natural gas.
More pirate attacks occur in Indonesian waters than anywhere else in the world. The pirates have spies in ports to identify valuable targets, and sometimes confederates aboard as well. 
Since Indonesia has many radical Muslim groups with a history of violence, which have been linked to the bombing in Bali in October, law enforcement and intelligence officials worry that terrorists may tap the pirates' expertise to mount attacks on ships in the region.
Smaller tankers like this 420-foot-long vessel, making slow trips through the strait while fully laden with valuable cargos, run the greatest danger, Mr. Mukundan said. 
The big fear is that Al Qaeda might seize a ship and crash it into another vessel or into a refinery or port.
Singapore, where the Petro Ranger started its current journey, has the world's second-busiest port, after Hong Kong's, so its government has taken the threat of terrorism very seriously.
As the ship began inching away from the jetties of Singapore's immense refinery, where it took on three million gallons of gasoline and diesel fuel, a brown Singaporean F-4 Skyhawk fighter flew overhead on combat air patrol, a precaution started after the attacks on Sept. 11 of last year. 
A Singaporean Hawkeye airborne surveillance plane circled twice over the refinery in the next hour, while a half-dozen fast patrol boats with deck guns and a small gray warship cruised the anchorage. One of the patrol boats escorted the Petro Ranger.
But once vessels enter the Strait of Malacca they are essentially on their own. An hour from Singapore, the Petro Ranger peacefully steamed past Iyu Kecil, a jungle-covered Indonesian island that Mr. Mukundan described as a base for an organized crime gang that has been hijacking small tankers to sell the cargos.
Three hours later, the Petro Ranger sailed past Laboh Point, Malaysia, where the tanker's crew had a close call just two months ago. A watchman on the deck of the Petro Ranger spotted a fast, low boat with no lights within 100 yards of the stern. 
The tanker's bells sounded to wake the unarmed crew, a radio call went out to the Malaysian coast guard and Istaque Hossain, the second officer, aimed a spotlight at the craft to signal to the occupants that they would not take the Petro Ranger unawares.
The spotlight revealed the boat to be packed with crouching men. "All of them were squatting, coming very close in masks and full black body suits," recalled Fong Chung-chen, the Petro Ranger's Malaysian chief officer. After it was caught in the light, the boat sheered off and vanished.
Armed with machetes, swords, even assault rifles and hand grenades, pirates often climb up the stern of a vessel, using grappling hooks and rope or sometimes shinnying up thick bamboo poles with hooks at the top. Pirates frequently choose the stern because it is low and because they are unlikely to be seen by officers on the bridge watching the sea ahead. 
Once aboard they try to disable a ship's radio systems before the crew can send a distress signal to local coast guard units.
Experienced sailors say pirates consider fire axes and hoses to be fair defensive weapons, unlike guns, for which they often punish ship crews. The axes are used to sever the pirates' grappling hooks, and the hoses spraying water off the stern are supposed to make the pirate boats wet and slippery platforms from which to mount an attack.
The pirate boats are typically equipped with several outboard motors on the back, allowing them to go up to three times as fast as the tankers, which lumber along at 11 knots, the equivalent of 13 land miles an hour. The pirates also use a low-tech version of stealth technology: they choose boats made of wood, which are hard to spot on radar.
Laws in many ports bar the equipping of tankers with deck guns. Many companies, including Petroships Pte. Ltd., which operates the single-hull Petro Ranger and seven newer tankers, also ban the crews from carrying guns.
"Let's say we shoot at them," Mr. Fong said. "When they board they would kill us all. Once they board we are finished -- if we lock the doors, they break the glass" of the windows.
Four and a half years ago, a dozen pirates swarmed aboard this tanker off the eastern coast of Malaysia and took the crew prisoner. The pirates sailed to China to try to sell the gasoline and diesel fuel, then worth about $2 million at wholesale prices. But a Chinese marine police vessel discovered the tanker and freed the crew.
The International Maritime Bureau's records show a decline in reported attacks against vessels in the Strait of Malacca in the last two years. 
Bureau officials say that partly reflects the fact that fewer captains are reporting incidents, but also some progress in combating piracy.
China has begun keeping pirates out of its waters, notably by executing members of one gang that murdered the entire crew of a vessel. Malaysia has purchased more fast patrol boats and has identified some of the ringleaders of pirate gangs based in nearby countries, said Muhamad Muda, the commander of Malaysia's marine police.
"We gave them the warning that if they ever came into Malaysian waters we will apprehend them and eliminate them," he said.
Indonesia, struggling with a crippled economy, has proven unable to mount such an ambitious effort. Intelligence officials say most pirates are based on the Indonesian side of the strait and buy the collusion of villagers by sharing their loot.
A few shipowners, notably Petroships' chairman, Alan H. J. Chan, say efforts to date have been completely inadequate, and have begun calling for the formation of a small military force, operating under a license from the United Nations, to patrol the strait. 
"A big project may cost millions but save billions, and save lives, too," Mr. Chan said.
But Malaysia and Indonesia oppose the idea, arguing that intelligence gathering and law enforcement ashore are just as important.
Additional patrols might discourage pirates but will not stop terrorists willing to die for their cause, Mr. Mukundan said. The International Maritime Bureau has begun calling for the creation of special shipping lanes reserved for commercial vessels in waterways like this one, with military force used to exclude fishing boats and pleasure craft.
"The only way to stop it is to blow it out of the water before it hits the tanker," Mr. Mukundan said. The United States and other countries have been leery of such a drastic response.
By 9 p.m. on the second day of its voyage, the Petro Ranger was chugging across calm seas in moonless, utter darkness. The nearest land was Tuan Point, Malaysia, where the captain of a fishing trawler was kidnapped by pirates in broad daylight. He was later released unhurt.
Aboard the Petro Ranger, Mr. Fong fretted over the radar. A long, thin fishing boat was barely visible by its navigation lights, yet the radar showed no trace of it. 
When Mr. Fong turned up the radar, it showed a mass of reflections from every ripple on the sea, and still no boat was discernible. The boat quietly passed around the stern of the Petro Ranger, where it unexpectedly turned up on the radar, and then sailed off into the distance.
Two hours later the Petro Ranger's 31-year-old engines began spewing clouds of sparks because of a fuel mixture problem. The bridge officers were alarmed that sparks might blow onto the cargo tanks, or that pirates might see the sparks as a sign of engine distress and pounce. It took an hour for the ship's engineers to fix the problem.
After traversing the narrowest and most dangerous 130 miles of the strait, the Petro Ranger safely sailed up an estuary and docked at 6 a.m. at Port Klang, the main port for the Malaysian capital of Kuala Lumpur. Mohda Hadapi, the Malaysian helmsman, was relieved after a nerve-racking night of scanning a pitch-black sea.
His wife cries each time he leaves, he said. "Pirates and now terrorists -- after January, I'm going to sign off, maybe find a job ashore," he added.

HEADLINE: Businesses Fight to Keep New Housing Out of District 

BYLINE:  By DAISY HERN NDEZ 

 BODY:
A public hearing yesterday on whether to allow the construction of a 32-story residential tower in the heart of the meatpacking district drew dissents from businesspeople, who said that the smells, noises and sights of the area made it incompatible with new housing.
 The project's developer, however, said the district's gritty character would make the tower, proposed for 848 Washington Street between Little West 12th Street and West 13th Street, a magnet for apartment buyers. 
 But for two hours after his presentation before the Board of Standards and Appeals, about two dozen people offered a different view -- saying it was perfect for business but bad as a place to live. 
"We like it loud, we like it crazy, we like it smelly," said Eli Halliwell, a senior operating manager for Bumble and Bumble, which plans to open an upscale hair salon in the district in the spring.
Michelle Dell, owner of the bar Hogs & Heifers, said she would be out of business within a year given the noise complaints that she would receive from the tower's residents.
"We're a die-hard American bar," Ms. Dell said, adding that on weekends it is open until 4 a.m. and has a regular crew of bikers accompanied by the rev of their motorcycles.
Others who testified said the "pungent aromas" from the all-night meatpackers would only draw complaints from neighbors.
The developer, Landmark Development, is asking the Board of Standards and Appeals for a variance to zoning regulations, which prohibit the construction of residential housing in the meatpacking district. The board said it would accept further testimony in writing and issue a decision on March 25. 
Peter Pfeffer, an urban designer with the Department of City Planning, said that while the meatpacking industry had diminished and that other businesses had moved in, it was still one of the most thriving manufacturing zones on the West Side. "These operations are incompatible with residential use," Mr. Pfeffer said.
But Stephen Touhey, a partner in the development company, said the local businesses would not bother potential residents. "They're actually going to be there because of the smells," Mr. Touhey said.
And Mr. Touhey's lawyer, Howard Hornstein, said newer businesses would also make the neighborhood attractive.
"It has nightclubs. It has galleries," Mr. Hornstein said. "People will be living there in three to five years and I think we all know that." 
At over 400 feet, the tower would be the tallest building for many blocks and would have 34 apartments priced at $2 million to $4 million dollars each. 
The controversy could soon be complicated if the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission decides to name the meatpacking district historic. That would prohibit tampering with the current architecture. Last night the commission heard public testimony on the proposal.

HEADLINE: Priest Guilty in Sex Abuse Of 11-Year-Old Altar Boy 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT HANLEY 

 BODY:
A 56-year-old Roman Catholic priest in New Jersey was found guilty yesterday of sexually assaulting an 11-year-old altar boy on two occasions after Sunday Mass nearly a decade ago.
 A jury of nine women and three men deliberated only a few hours between Tuesday afternoon and late yesterday morning before returning its verdict in the first sex-abuse trial of a priest in New Jersey since the scandal erupted this year. 
 After the priest, the Rev. John M. Banko, was convicted, the trial prosecutor, Dawn M. Solari, of the Hunterdon County prosecutor's office, appealed to victims of other priests to come forward and help the authorities bring charges in their cases. "I hope they can see that the system worked in this case," Ms. Solari said. 
At least one other priest in New Jersey, the Rev. Michael Fugee, 42, of Wyckoff, has been charged with molesting a young male parishioner. His trial is expected to begin in the spring in Hackensack.
In a statement, the Diocese of Metuchen, in which Father Banko had served as parish pastor and priest, called his actions abhorrent and vowed to help the authorities prosecute any other abuse cases against priests. 
"Our hearts go out to the victims who testified in this matter and to their families, who surely have endured years of pain and anguish," the statement said. "To each of them we apologize."
Father Banko's victim, who is now 20 years old, buried his head in his hands when the verdict was announced in New Jersey Superior Court in Flemington. Moments later, according to The Associated Press, his mother said: "We've waited a long time for this. I'm just glad it's over. My son can get back to, maybe, a normal life."
Father Banko, who has been a priest in New Jersey since 1972, showed little emotion. The presiding judge, Ann R. Bartlett, revoked his $25,000 bail and ordered him held in the Hunterdon County jail. He faces a prison term of up to 35 years when he is sentenced Feb. 7. The judge ordered that he undergo psychiatric evaluation at the state's center for sexual predators in Avenel before he is sentenced. 
The jury convicted Father Banko of all three charges against him: aggravated sexual assault, sexual assault and endangering the welfare of a child. The authorities said the assaults occurred on two consecutive Sundays between September 1993 and September 1994 in a small changing room near the main altar at St. Edward the Confessor Church in Milford, N.J. On both occasions, Father Banko, the church pastor at the time, had just finished saying Mass, and he and the youth, who had served as his altar boy, were changing clothes. Both times, the authorities said, the priest performed fellatio on the youth and then forced the boy to touch the priest's genital area.
After testifying about the acts when the trial opened last Wednesday, the young man said Father Banko warned him that his parents would be harmed if he told anyone of the incidents. The boy kept the secret until he told a friend in November 1999, Ms. Solari, the prosecutor said. The friend notified the authorities, and the investigation started in December 1999. The Diocese of Metuchen suspended Father Banko from ministerial duties in April 2000, meaning he could no longer publicly say Mass, said a diocesan spokeswoman, Joanne Ward.
Before he was jailed yesterday, Father Banko had been living with his 94-year-old mother in Trenton, his lawyer, Lewis White 3rd said. Mr. White said he planned to apply for reinstatement of the $25,000 bail. As for an appeal, Mr. White said he would refer the priest to the state public defender's office because he is unemployed and unable to afford a private lawyer. Ms. Ward, the diocesan spokeswoman, said the church had provided no funds for Father Banko's defense.
In addition to the former altar boy, three men, now in their 30's, testified against the priest to show that he had engaged in a pattern of seduction. One said the priest once grabbed his buttocks, another said Father Banko had once masturbated in front of him, and the third said the priest had performed fellatio on him several times while he was still a seminarian in the early 1970's. No charges were filed in their cases because the statute of limitations had expired.
Father Banko testified in his own defense and denied their accounts, as well as the former altar boy's. But during Ms. Solari's cross-examination he acknowledged that he had once told detectives he had had sexual relations with both men and women who, he believed, were all older than 18. He said he had interpreted his vow of celibacy to mean he could never marry but could engage in sexual relations.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters; 
On Hudson, On Potomac, On Edge

BYLINE:  By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
THOUSANDS are expected to demonstrate on the Mall in Washington this weekend to support changing the name of the nation's capital to better reflect the prevailing fears of war and mayhem. To register its plea for relief, the public favors the new name of Hypothetica. 
 A rally to recommend a parallel name change in the country's premier city -- to New Mania, H.A. (High Anxiety) -- will be held at the same time in Times Square because the city, too, is in constant agitation over fears of chaos. A name change in New York is considered most unlikely, however, because of its citizenry's inability ever to agree on anything. 
 Hypothetica in place of Washington prevailed over several alternatives, including Whatif, Couldbe, MightJustHappen and YouNeverKnow. But Hypothetica drew 98 percent support in an instant poll taken by Fox News between 10 and 10:05 last night, after a typically wide-ranging discussion between Bill O'Reilly and Ann Coulter. 
The sentiment in Congress is against a change. The strongest negative voice belongs to Trent Lott, the Republican Senate leader, who said that he has favored no significant changes of any kind over the past 50 years, each of which has caused "problems" for him. He is not alone, but a lively debate looms on Capitol Hill.
Americans favor Hypothetica because, according to well-placed sources familiar with the pulse of the country, it best captures the pulse of the country. "Americans have come to accept living in a daily state of risk, a kind of suspended animation as they await an uncertain future," explained Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary.
He noted that people have come to accept the president's selection of Tom Ridge to head the Department of Homeland Security; he, of course, devised the color-coded terrorism alert system, which the public has recognized to sometimes be slightly better than nothing.
Mr. Fleischer has also pointed out that the public has been accepting of the latest strategies and preparations for war that have dribbled out of Washington, incrementally, day by day.
In the event of war, the daily Fleischer briefings will be televised live on C-Span, CNN, Fox, MSNBC and Nickelodeon, as will the daily briefings by Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld. Secretary of State Colin L. Powell is expected to make public his e-mail address.
NEW YORKERS, though not unmindful of the country's war plans, have their ears full of other dire warnings. 
Firefighters foresee the city burning to the ground if one more firehouse is ever closed. A mass flight to New Jersey is predicted if taxes are raised again. Park lovers have been led to fear that a beetle could kill all the trees. The mayor fears perpetual gridlock if he doesn't impose tolls on the bridges, and business leaders fear economic collapse if he does. The whole city fears the return of a high crime rate, and everyone is really frightened of the latest scare -- the prospect of a transit strike. 
Three weeks before the strike deadline, the mayor began sounding the alarm in his mild way. As the date approached, he began giving tutorials about car-pooling and bicycling, rush-hour lane reversals and the dangers of gridlock. "We have to prepare for the worst," he intoned.
What the mayor lacked in fervor, the media provided. The prospect of a paralyzing strike evoked vivid accounts of transit strikes past, and counsel from mayors past. Businesses developed contingency plans for employees, and headline writers and producers of television newscasts went into overdrive.
"City Strike Chaos," screamed one tabloid. "A Strike Alert!" promised an 11 o'clock newscast on WCBS-TV. The Strike Alert! warning -- five days before there could be a strike -- even trumped a story predicting "a major ice storm." Which turned out to be mainly rain.
History would suggest that the mayor has little choice but to play as tough with the union as his temperament allows -- just as the union leader has to play tough with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. That's the only way they can justify the settlement that is finally reached, as it must be, strike or no strike. They're carrying out their assigned roles.
So is the public, assigned to be on the receiving end of fearsome warnings. That is how it's played, from the Potomac to the Hudson -- elaborate rehearsals based on what might be, followed (or not) by the real thing. 
No, they won't soon be changing the names of any cities, but it is helpful from time to time to remember that the hypothetical is hypothetical.

HEADLINE: THE TRANSIT SHOWDOWN: HISTORY; 
22 Years After the Last Transit Strike, Familiar Doldrums and Grievances

BYLINE:  By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
Commercials for Calvin Klein jeans and the mystery of who shot J. R. might seem like relics from the ancient past. But in many ways, the gulf between 1980 and today is not so wide.
 Then, as now, the president of the Transport Workers Union was an immigrant elected as a firebrand to wrest a better deal for his members. The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority was a real estate developer with close ties to the governor. 
 Talk of a fare increase was in the air, the economy was poor, the mayor spoke of the dire consequences of a strike and the union warned -- as Roger Toussaint, its current leader, warns now more obliquely -- that it would no longer subsidize the city and state by sacrificing raises.
Whether history will repeat itself is far from certain. But the first 11 days in April 1980, when a subway and bus shutdown -- as well as a short Long Island Rail Road strike -- paralyzed the city, provide a kind of guide to what could happen during a new strike and about the long-term effects on the city.
The images from those days 22 years ago remain powerful even now: the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges so flooded with New Yorkers that it seemed as if a marathon was under way; train yards lined with idle subway cars; traffic so snarled that a trip from Herald Square to 59th Street could take more than an hour; classrooms half empty around the city. 
The statistics were just as stark. During the strike, at least 50,000 people temporarily relocated to be closer to work. The number of cars coming into Manhattan between 4 and 7 a.m. more than doubled as commuters tried to avoid a single-driver ban, similar to the one that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has said he would enforce during a new strike.
The public and private sector together lost more than $1 billion during those 11 days, according to some economists, and the working poor, the most reliant on public transportation, were hit the hardest. The transit union was fined $1 million and later lost even more. 
In ways both profound and not so profound, damage from the strike lingered. By the next year, for example, ridership on buses and subways had fallen to its lowest level since 1917. In the fashion world, experts said that a troubling and persistent trend -- women wearing white socks and running shoes with business suits -- was most likely spawned by the pedestrian requirements of the strike.
But some of the effects were actually positive. The number of people riding bicycles, for example, doubled during the strike and continued to rise in the years after it, helping to lead to better accommodations for city bike riders.
And even during the strike, not all of the dire consequences predicted by Mayor Edward I. Koch came to pass. Theater attendance and the restaurant business did not suffer much at all, and the Mets, at their season opener, managed to draw even more fans than they had the year before without a transit strike. (The attendance, 12,219 people, was still dismal.)
In fact, for many New Yorkers who lived through the 1980 strike, the memories are mixed with a strong combination of nostalgia, humor and pride at having weathered it. They recall Mayor Koch, who compared the city to London during the Blitz, standing at the foot of the Brooklyn Bridge in Manhattan, cheering on the armies of pedestrians.
"I talked to Mayor Bloomberg the other day," Mr. Koch said recently, "and he said, 'The bridge was yours. I've got to find something else.' And he did. He found his bike. It will be his symbol."
Strike survivors fondly remember a city coming together and wearing a friendlier face, the way it sometimes does during crises -- people hitchhiking, talking to strangers, going to work late or skipping it altogether and napping in Central Park. They remember paramedics riding mopeds to get through traffic and charter boats delivering investment bankers to the shores of Manhattan.
Gerry Casanova, a junior account executive then at Young & Rubicam, said that for a few spring days, as he biked to work, the city felt more like Amsterdam or Copenhagen than a dysfunctional metropolis. "I think about it all the time," said Mr. Casanova, now an executive vice president at Rubenstein Associates, the public relations firm. "I just remember it being calm, fun. It was like people cross-country skiing during a rare blizzard in New York."
But of course, mention of a blizzard inevitably brings up the big differences between the 1980 strike and any that might happen now, differences that many city officials warn will make a strike now much more damaging.
Walking and biking in December -- an unusually wintry one at that -- will be much harder and less appealing than doing so in April. Financially, the city is also much less able to pay for the police overtime and other expenses associated with a strike. And businesses, already struggling with sluggish holiday sales, will almost certainly be hit much harder than they were during the last strike.
In addition, the number of people affected by a strike would be larger. The average daily weekday ridership on subways and buses is now 7 million, about 1.4 million more than in 1980, and many of the city's 1.1 million schoolchildren also have farther to travel now than in 1980 because they can now choose to attend schools outside their neighborhoods.
"I can only say that I hope there's a lot going on in a back room that you and I don't know about," said Richard Ravitch, the M.T.A. chairman during the last walkout. "Because if there's not, we're all in trouble."

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: Excerpts From Reports by Congressional Inquiry Into Sept. 11 Attacks; 
Conclusions of the Majority Report

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the final report of the joint Congressional committee investigating the Sept. 11 attacks. Fuller excerpts are online at nytimes.com/politics.

Recommendations
 Congress should amend the National Security Act of 1947 to create and sufficiently staff a statutory director of national intelligence who shall be the president's principal adviser on intelligence and shall have the full range of management, budgetary and personnel responsibilities needed to make the entire U.S. intelligence community operate as a coherent whole. These responsibilities should include: 
 *Establishment and enforcement of consistent priorities for the collection, analysis, and dissemination of intelligence throughout the intelligence community;
*Setting of policy and the ability to move personnel between elements of the intelligence community;
*Review, approval, modification, and primary management and oversight of the execution of intelligence community budgets;
*Review, approval, modification, and primary management and oversight of the execution of intelligence community personnel and resource allocations;
*Review, approval, modification, and primary management and oversight of the execution of intelligence community research and development efforts;
*Review, approval and coordination of relationships between the intelligence community agencies and foreign intelligence and law enforcement services; and
*Exercise of statutory authority to ensure that intelligence community agencies and components fully comply with communitywide policy, management, spending, and administrative guidance and priorities.
The director of national intelligence should be a cabinet-level position, appointed by the president and subject to Senate confirmation. Congress and the president should also work to ensure that the director of national intelligence effectively exercises these authorities.
To ensure focused and consistent intelligence community leadership, Congress should require that no person may simultaneously serve as both the director of national intelligence and the director of the C.I.A., or as the director of any other specific intelligence agency. . . .
The National Security Council, in conjunction with the director of national intelligence, and in consultation with the secretary of the Department of Homeland Security, the secretary of state and secretary of defense, should prepare, for the president's approval, a U.S. government-wide strategy for combating terrorism, both at home and abroad, including the growing terrorism threat posed by the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and associated technologies. This strategy should identify and fully engage those foreign policy, economic, military, intelligence and law enforcement elements that are critical to a comprehensive blueprint for success in the war against terrorism.
As part of that effort, the director of national intelligence shall develop the intelligence community component of the strategy, identifying specific programs and budgets and including plans to address the threats posed by Osama bin Laden and Al Qaeda, Hezbollah, Hamas and other significant terrorist groups. Consistent with applicable law, the strategy should effectively employ and integrate all capabilities available to the intelligence community against those threats and should encompass specific efforts to:
*Develop human sources to penetrate terrorist organizations and networks both overseas and within the United States;
*Fully utilize existing and future technologies to better exploit terrorist communications; to improve and expand the use of data mining and other cutting-edge analytical tools; and to develop a multilevel security capability to facilitate the timely and complete sharing of relevant intelligence information both within the intelligence community and with other appropriate federal, state and local authorities;
*Enhance the depth and quality of domestic intelligence collection and analysis by, for example, modernizing current intelligence reporting formats through the use of existing information technology to emphasize the existence and the significance of links between new and previously acquired information;
*Maximize the effective use of covert action in counterterrorist efforts;
*Develop programs to deal with financial support for international terrorism; and
*Facilitate the ability of C.I.A. paramilitary units and military special operations forces to conduct joint operations against terrorist targets. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: New Chief of F.D.A. Advocates Quicker Approval Process for Brand-Name and Generic Drugs 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 

 BODY:
The new head of the Food and Drug Administration, Dr. Mark B. McClellan, said today that he intended to speed the approval of new drugs and crack down on deceptive pharmaceutical advertising.
 The agency has substantially reduced the time required to review and approve new medicines since 1993, when drug companies began paying fees to help cover the costs of such reviews. It still takes a little more than a year for the agency to approve a typical brand-name drug, and Dr. McClellan said today, "We can do better." 
 Dr. McClellan said he wanted to accelerate the approval of both brand-name and generic drugs, as well as medical devices.
"We have some great opportunities to do better in drug approval times and in getting products that are safe and effective to market more quickly," Dr. McClellan, a physician and economist who worked at the White House until he took charge of the agency on Nov. 14, said.
User fees paid by drug companies accounted for about half the $332 million that the agency spent on drug reviews in the last year.
Told of Dr. McClellan's commitment to speed the review of low-cost generic versions of brand-name drugs, Jake Hansen, vice president of Barr Laboratories, a large maker of generic drugs, said, "That's music to our ears."
Currently, Mr. Hansen said, "the decision on approval of a generic drug is supposed to be made within six months after an application is filed, but it's not at all unusual for the process to take 14 to 16 months, which is longer than the time needed to approve many brand-name drugs."
Some consumer groups assert that quicker review of new drugs has increased the risk that products will later be found unsafe and removed from the market. Some studies have found such an increase, but the agency disagrees.
Dr. McClellan said his agency would be more aggressive in policing claims made in television advertisements for prescription drugs.
"We will not be afraid to go to court when necessary" to stop companies from exaggerating the benefits or understating the risks of drugs, he said.
Since 1997, the agency has sent more than 88 letters to drug companies objecting to their advertisements on television and radio and in print. 
The General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, reported last week that several major companies had repeatedly disseminated misleading advertisements for the same drug even after being cited for violations.
Dr. McClellan said he would try to deter violations by setting clearer standards.
"If we see patterns of recurrent use of misleading techniques in advertising," he added, "we will go further than warning letters."
The commissioner said he was even more concerned about misleading claims for the health benefits of some dietary supplements. "I am looking for ways to improve our enforcement" in that area, he said.
Dr. McClellan also said that with the rapid growth in drug development, "there's a real problem" getting enough people to participate in clinical trials of new medications. New technology, he said, may allow researchers to predict a drug's side effects at an earlier stage, alerting the government and industry to potential problems, like liver damage, without waiting for the results of lengthy clinical trials with large numbers of patients.
In addition, Dr. McClellan said he wanted to negotiate arrangements with some hospitals and nursing homes so they would automatically and promptly report the adverse effects of drugs and medical devices already on the market.
Dr. Raymond Woosley, a pharmacologist who is vice president of the University of Arizona, called such surveillance an excellent idea.
"It would indicate what proportion of patients exposed to a drug suffer adverse effects," Dr. Woosley said, "and we could use that information to measure the relative safety of different drugs.
The government receives vast amounts of information about the adverse effects of drugs on the market. But the reporting by doctors and patients is generally voluntary, and the government usually has no idea how many people have been exposed to a particular drug.
Dr. McClellan said he did not intend to weigh the costs and benefits of new drugs submitted to his agency for approval.
"That's not part of our mandate," he said. "But I would like to do some additional cost-benefit analysis of our drug approval process. If there are different ways of assuring that a safe, effective drug gets to market, we ought to follow the approach that does it as efficiently as possible, at the least cost to the agency and the drug producers."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Enron Records Contradict Denials of Speculating
Even as Enron's top executives were insisting that the company did not engage in speculative trading, Enron was reaping the bulk of its profits during the California energy crisis betting on the direction of gas and electricity prices, according to company records and interviews with former Enron traders and executives.
 Enron made the profitable bets -- including one that resulted in a $485 million gain on one day in December 2000 -- at a time when investigators say it was conspiring with other companies to manipulate prices. Page A1. 

Coco-Cola Names a President
Coca-Cola said that it had named Steven J. Heyer, who joined the company in 2001, president and chief operating officer. C15.

Taubman Rejects Takeover Offer
A. Alfred Taubman's shopping mall empire, Taubman Centers, rejected a $1.5 billion bid from Simon Property Group, calling the offer inadequate, and "clearly not in the best interests" of shareholders. The rejection is the second time Taubman Centers has dismissed Simon Property's overture offer over the several weeks. C2.

U.S. Bank in Deal in Mexico
Bank of America said that it would pay $1.6 billion for 24.9 percent of Grupo Financiero Santander Serfin, the most profitable bank in Mexico. World Business, Section W.

F.D.A. Head Vows Faster Approvals
The new head of the Food and Drug Administration, Dr. Mark B. McClellan, said that he intended to speed up the approval of new drugs and would crack down on deceptive pharmaceutical advertising. A34.

Large pharmaceutical companies have increased their promotional spending so much in the last four years that each dollar spent on marketing no longer brings in the profits it once did, accord to a Datamonitor report. C3.

US Airways Pilots Accept More Cuts
US Airways said that it had reached a tentative agreement with its pilots' union on an additional $101 million in concessions. C4.

Vivendi Moves to Sell Art Collection
Vivendi Universal, the troubled French entertainment company, has asked three auction houses for proposals to sell off its modern art collection. E1.

ABC Plans Changes on Mondays
ABC reshuffled its prime-time schedule, moving its hit drama "The Practice" to 9 p.m. Monday from Sunday. "Miracles," a drama about investigators of the supernatural, will run at 10. Lloyd Braun, left, the chairman of ABC Entertainment, said the moves were made to shore up its schedule after "Monday Night Football" ends for the year. C5.

Taking the Criticism and the Ad
A campaign from the Wall Street Journal Online, one of the few news Web sites to charge for access, mocks its free counterparts as uninformed and unreliable. But the critical words are not preventing the competing sites from accepting the ads. Advertising. C5.

Dow Slips Before Finishing Higher
The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 14.88 points, at 8,589.14. The Nasdaq rose 5.83 points, to 1,396.59. The Standard & Poor's 500 index gained 0.51 points, to 904.96. C10.

Name Can Make Job Hunt Hard
Researchers testing whether employers discriminate against black job applicants found that applicants with white-sounding names were 50 percent more likely to be called back than were those with black-sounding names. Alan B. Krueger: Economic Scene. C2.

HEADLINE: THE TRANSIT SHOWDOWN: NEGOTIATIONS; 
Union Lowers Its Demands As M.T.A. Plans to Request Injunction Against Strike

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Showing flexibility for the first time, the transit workers' union lowered its wage demands yesterday, while transit officials said they would go to state court this morning to seek an injunction to bar any strike.
 At the first high-level negotiations in more than a week, the union representing 34,000 subway and bus workers said it would accept raises of 6 percent a year over three years, down from its previous demand for an 8 percent annual raise. 
 On Saturday, members of the Transport Workers Union Local 100 authorized a strike if no settlement is reached by Monday morning. Eager to avert a strike, officials with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said their lawyers would file motions in New York State Supreme Court in Brooklyn today to prohibit a walkout. 
The Taylor Law bars strikes in New York State by public employees, including transit workers, and calls for fines of two days' pay for every day a striker is out. One transit official said the authority would seek a basic court order spelling out those penalties and might also ask for a stronger order threatening greater penalties.
In its effort to obtain an injunction, the authority is scheduled to appear at 9 a.m. today before Justice Ann Pfau, administrative judge of the State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.
City Hall and transit officials said the city was also considering seeking an injunction with additional penalties, but they said the city would probably not seek an injunction today.
At a news conference, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg suggested that the city was holding off on seeking an injunction for fear of worsening an already tense situation.
"We have a legal strategy ready to go," Mr. Bloomberg said. "Whether we file or not, people should understand, New York City will exercise every legal right it has to prevent a strike. And should an illegal strike take place, New York City will use every legal remedy it has to recover damages and to punish those who break the law."
When the transport workers threatened a strike during negotiations in 1999, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani obtained a far-reaching injunction that threatened the union with millions of dollars in fines.
The union agreed yesterday to withdraw a federal lawsuit brought in Manhattan that sought an order that would have barred the city from seeking a broad antistrike injunction. 
After yesterday's two-hour bargaining session at the West Side Y.M.C.A. on West 63rd Street, Roger Toussaint, president of Local 100, said the transportation authority was being inflexible, and had not budged from original proposals, including a wage freeze, even though the union had reduced its demands. 
"They did not show any flexibility at the table," Mr. Toussaint said. "We've modified our demand, and they have not done likewise."
Saying it faces a $2.7 billion deficit, the authority has called for the union to accept a wage freeze in the first year and has offered raises in the second and third years only if the union agrees to numerous measures to increase productivity.
Mr. Toussaint said: "We want them to move vigorously on the issues. We don't want this last-minute brinksmanship that the M.T.A. apparently is planning."
One top adviser to the union praised yesterday's negotiations as the "realest" session so far and said management discussed more details than it has before.
Gary Dellaverson, the authority's chief negotiator, praised the union for reducing its wage demands. "The fact that they moved is good," he said. "On the other hand, the union is still not recognizing the economic environment in which the negotiations are taking place, and any agreement that we reach will only be reached in the context of that economic environment." 
The union and the authority had disagreed about when the current contract expires, but they appeared to settle that dispute yesterday. Transit officials had insisted that the contract expired at 12:01 a.m. Sunday, but yesterday they said they agreed with the union's position that the expiration would come at 12:01 a.m. Monday.
Mayor Bloomberg rebuffed the union's call for him and Gov. George E. Pataki to get involved in the talks. "Nobody should expect the mayor or the governor to go to a table where somebody's got a gun to your head and is threatening to break the law," he said.
Since the city is facing a $6 billion deficit next fiscal year and its union contracts are expiring soon, Mr. Bloomberg supported the authority's position of accepting raises only if there are commensurate productivity increases. "There is not a lot of money without productivity enhancements to pay anybody anymore," he said.
The authority announced yesterday that in the event of a strike, some Metro-North and Long Island Rail Road trains would be converted to shuttle routes to help residents of outlying boroughs get into Manhattan. The authority said it would suspend ticket sales on trains and might allow lines to form at street level to get onto trains.
For Metro-North, regularly scheduled trains headed to Grand Central Terminal would not stop at most Bronx stations from 5 a.m. to 11 a.m. and from 3:30 p.m. to 8:30 p.m. Instead, trains would provide shuttle service between the Bronx and Manhattan.
For the Long Island Rail Road, regularly scheduled trains heading to Penn Station would stop at hub stations in Queens from 6 a.m. to 9 a.m. and 4 p.m. to 7 p.m. At other times, special shuttles and regular trains would provide service to all Queens stations.
The authority said on its Web site that the contingency plan would not take effect until 24 hours after a strike begins.

HEADLINE: THE TRANSIT SHOWDOWN: ASSESSMENT; 
Angry Workers and Militant Union Leaders vs. Cash-Poor M.T.A.

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Invariably, union contract talks begin with bluff and bluster and outlandish demands that both sides know they will have to compromise on. Despite such sharp differences early on, 98 percent of contract disputes reach a settlement without a walkout, labor surveys show, as the two sides hear each other out and recognize what is achievable and affordable.
 But many labor experts say New York's transit negotiations could end up as part of the unhappy 2 percent that result in strikes, even though state law bars transit walkouts. 
 There are many reasons why the talks involving 34,000 subway and bus workers are so volatile: the smoldering resentment that transit workers feel toward management, fueled by the recent deaths of two subway workers; a deficit-plagued transportation authority that cannot, as usual, turn to the city and state for money to seal a deal because they, too, are drowning in deficits, and a militant, new union leadership that is intent on showing union members just how tough it is.
Another factor is the combative history of Transport Workers Union Local 100. In 1966 and again in 1980, its members defied state law, fines and jail sentences and shut down the nation's largest transit system. 
David L. Gregory, a labor law professor at St. John's University, said, "They might go on strike because they are probably one of the most militant labor unions in any municipality in the United States, and they have a long history of demonstrating that militancy."
The two sides appear to be on a collision course once again because the union's leaders are eager to secure a substantial raise while management is crying poverty. The mayor and governor, knowing that the settlement can set a pattern for their coming labor talks, are eager for transit officials to drive a hard bargain and keep raises to a minimum.
And union members are seething that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is seeking large concessions on pensions and health coverage that will cost workers more than $1,000 a year.
In years past, most transit talks were amicably resolved when transit officials went cup in hand to the mayor and governor, who at the last minute played Santa Claus and found sacks of money to make a deal possible. But this time around the authority might have little luck hitting up Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg or Gov. George E. Pataki for cash to reach a deal because the city faces a $6 billion deficit next year and the state, a $10 billion deficit.
"In any negotiations, if you want to avoid a strike, the union leadership needs to be able to point to some concessions by management and some victories for the workers," said Robert Snyder, a Rutgers University professor who has written a history of the transit union. "It's not clear to me how they might or can achieve that in these negotiations."
The transit workers' resentment toward management takes many forms and one of them is sheer disbelief in the M.T.A.'s claims of a $2.7 billion deficit. Insisting that the authority is trying to trick them, many workers say they are mystified at how the agency suddenly went from a large surplus last year to a huge deficit this year. 
All the pent-up resentment stems from what workers say is a flood of slights, large and small. Two subway workers died on the job in the last month, and the workers contend that management has shown little concern about safety. Transit workers often complain of second-class treatment, noting that they earn less than workers at Metro North and the Long Island Rail Road even though their jobs are dirtier and more dangerous. Many transit workers also feel slighted that the M.T.A. has proposed a wage freeze just months after the police, firefighters and teachers got double-digit raises.
Perhaps the workers' biggest complaint is that the transit agency's disciplinary system treats them like wayward children -- each year the authority issues more than 10,000 citations against transit workers. The workers also say it is demeaning that when they call in sick, the M.T.A. often sends investigators to their homes to see why they are absent.
Echoing the views of many workers, Steve Jenney, a longtime bus driver in Upper Manhattan, said: "To get treated like a human being, I'd go on strike. Absolutely."
With this background of resentment, many New Yorkers concluded that a strike was inevitable when Roger Toussaint, president of Transport Workers Union Local 100, kicked off the talks by demanding a raise of 8 percent a year for three years. But no one, not even Mr. Toussaint, believed that the union would obtain such a large raise; indeed, he lowered his demands to 6 percent a year yesterday.
Even as Mr. Toussaint reduced his pay demands, he said there was no way the union would accept "three zeros." In his view, that is all the M.T.A. has offered, because it has proposed a wage freeze in the first year and raises in the second and third years contingent on the union's accepting new efficiency measures that pay for any raises. Union officials are bridling at that idea.
The key to this dispute may be how high the M.T.A.'s wage offer will go and how low a figure union officials can accept without angering workers and making their militant talk ring hollow.
If the agency offered raises of 3 percent or 4 percent a year, which is above the inflation rate, several labor experts predicted the union would accept that. But with the M.T.A. warning of a large deficit, many labor experts doubt that management would offer nearly that much. An annual 4 percent raise would cost the authority roughly $480 million over three years, while a 3 percent raise would cost $360 million.
More likely, the experts say, the M.T.A. might offer a 1 percent raise three years in a row, although management officials are saying they cannot go even that high unless the union agrees to major measures to increase productivity. Judging from Mr. Toussaint's promises of winning a strong contract, it is doubtful that the union would accept 1 percent raises. 
If at the contract deadline, management says its last and best offer is 1 percent a year, union leaders might feel required to call a strike, even though it is illegal, to show their unhappiness and their mettle. 
Mr. Toussaint was elected two years ago on a platform that denounced his predecessor, Willie James, for not winning enough at the bargaining table. In the 1999 negotiations, when the M.T.A. was enjoying a surplus, the union got raises averaging 4 percent a year. "Toussaint is going to have to substantially fulfill some of his commitments or otherwise his leadership will be in serious question," Professor Gregory said.
If there is a secret in the negotiations, it is whether the M.T.A. has enough millions squirreled away in its opaque budget to finance a raise of, say, 2 percent a year, a number the union might consider, or even 3 percent, a number the union might embrace, labor experts say.
But even if M.T.A. officials conclude that they can offer 2 percent or 3 percent a year, they might face strong pressures from the city and state not to be so generous. City Hall officials have voiced fears that a substantial raise would pressure the cash-poor city to do likewise with its unions. 
Professor Snyder saw a way out: "A settlement could be achieved through a wage agreement that is less than the union is seeking, but it could be augmented by some improvements on working conditions, like discipline and safety, that are very much on workers' minds."
