HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* "DRAWING NOW: EIGHT PROPOSITIONS," Museum of Modern Art, Queens, 45-20 33rd Street, at Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, (212) 708-9400 (through Jan. 6). This generous sampling of work by 26 young artists provides a sweeping, even opulent view of drawing at the threshold of the 21st century. The variety of techniques and materials, the mix of large-scale feats of draftsmanship with clusters of framed works, the breadth of sources (from American quilt patterns to Japanese anime to 19th-century illustration) and the range of narrative ambition create an exhilarating sense of possibility. The division of the work into eight approaches, or propositions, balances coherence with diversity. Some of the artists illustrate rather than fully embody the curators' categories, and there is an excess of fashionable, even overexposed artists from a handful of hot galleries. Nonetheless, "Drawing Now" is required viewing for anyone remotely interested in today's art. It sets a standard for future shows of its kind. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m; until 7:45 p.m. on Fridays. Admission: $12; $8.50, students and 65+ (Roberta Smith).

* "GENESIS: IDEAS OF ORIGIN IN AFRICAN SCULPTURE," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through April 13). This splendid show, installed in the Michael C. Rockefeller Wing, examines African myths about the creation of the world, the foundations of kingship and the formation of the family as told in the art of more than a dozen sub-Saharan cultures. The images range from naturalistic figures to fantastic animals and culminate in a coup de theatre display of some 40 Bamana headdresses, many of the classic Ci Ware type. The dynamic is one of ethical persuasion, physical and psychological healing and a holistic connection to the world through objects of irrepressible energy and beauty. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $7 for students and 65+ (Holland Cotter).

* "KAZARI: DECORATION AND DISPLAY IN JAPAN: 15TH-19TH CENTURY," Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street, (212) 832-1155 (through Dec. 31). The hard-to-grasp term kazari refers to the decorative arrangement of objects. And it is demonstrated with enchanting results in a show that demolishes the cliche of Japanese art as inherently minimalist. Here everything is layered: something is always in front of or behind or above something else, and each something has its own painted, incised or embroidered intricacies. This results in a total environment of conspicuous but elusive richness, encompassing painted screens, samurai jackets and Kabuki costumes that sag under acres of padded silk and gilded thread. It's maximalism all the way. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; $3, students and 65+ (Cotter).

* "MASTERPIECES OF EUROPEAN PAINTING FROM THE TOLEDO MUSEUM OF ART," Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, (212) 288-0700 (through Jan. 5). This small but weighty group of 12 masterworks salutes the collecting activities of an important Ohio institution that was founded in 1901 under the leadership of the Toledo glass manufacturer Edward Drummond Libbey. With no dominant theme, the paintings range in period from the 16th century to the 19th and include New Testament scenes by Piero di Cosimo, Jacopo Bassano and El Greco, landscapes by Gainsborough, Boucher and Cezanne and a still life by Pissarro. Complementing the Frick's own collection of masterworks, they make a compelling show, one that could possibly encourage a visit to the Toledo museum itself. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. (Fridays through Dec. 27, to 9 p.m. with free admission after 6 p.m.); Sundays, 1 to 6 p.m. Admission: $12; $5 for students; $8 for 62+ (Grace Glueck).

"DAGOBERT PECHE AND THE WEINER WERKSTATTE," Neue Galerie, 1048 Fifth Avenue, at 86th Street, (212) 628-6200 (through Feb. 10). This survey of the Austrian designer Dagobert Peche (pronounced DAH-go-bert PEH-kuh) is a case study in the use of material objects to effect cultural reform. And the installation is as lively as any design show New York has seen. Peche, who died in 1923 at 36, represented the second generation of the Wiener Werkstatte, whose designers regarded decorative objects as ideological vessels. But his highly ornate work is in full contrast to the spartan aesthetic associated with the movement. With more than 400 drawings and objects on view, the show is a tumble of stylized flora and offers an equal range of materials: fabric, wallpaper, precious metals, ceramics, wood and glass. Like Philippe Starck and Ettore Sottsass today, Peche designed rooms of inner nature, enclosures for emotion. Hours: Fridays, 11 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Saturdays, Sundays and Mondays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; $7, students and 65+ (Herbert Muschamp).

* "THE QUILTS OF GEE'S BEND," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through March 2). The most ebullient exhibition of the New York art season in the unlikely guise of a show of hand-stitched quilts from a remote, historically black community along the Alabama River. For generations, the women of Gee's Bend have passed down an indigenous style of quilting geometric patterns out of old britches, cornmeal sacks, Sears corduroy swatches and hand-me-down leisure suits -- whatever happened to be around. Imagine Matisse and Klee arising not from rarefied Europe, but from the caramel soil of the rural South. The best designs, minimalist and spare, turn out to be some of the most miraculous works of modern art America has produced. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $8, students and 62+ (Michael Kimmelman)

Galleries: Uptown

JOHN EVANS, "Collages," Pavel Zoubok, 1014 Madison Avenue, at 78th Street, (212) 879-5858 (through Dec. 21). Every day from the early 60's to the end of the 20th century, Mr. Evans created a new collage, 33 of which are here. His compact compositions of ticket stubs, bottle and box labels, photographs and other ephemera with cityscapes, ducks and abstract elements added in richly colored inks are often associated with those of Ray Johnson, but Mr. Evans's works have their own distinctively emblematic form and sweetly poetic charm (Ken Johnson).

"HIGH NOTES OF AMERICAN MODERNISM: SELECTIONS FROM THE COLLECTION OF TOMMY AND GILL LiPUMA," Berry-Hill Galleries, 11 East 70th Street, (212) 744-2300 (through Dec. 31). Concentrated on four American artists of the early 20th century -- Alfred Maurer, Arnold Friedman, Marsden Hartley and John Marin -- this show of 40 works was assembled over three decades. Among the Maurer standouts are an early still life from his Fauve period, "The Painted Bowl With Chicken," and some beautifully wrought late canvases that helped to shape an American Cubist vocabulary. Nine Friedmans attest to the vibrancy of his work -- a kind of Impressionist figuration. This highly personal collection has enough pizazz to make any art lover's day (Glueck).

* "LE CORBUSIER BEFORE LE CORBUSIER: APPLIED ARTS, ARCHITECTURE, PAINTING AND PHOTOGRAPHY, 1907-1922," Bard Graduate Center for Studies in the Decorative Arts, Design and Culture, 18 West 86th Street, (212) 501-3000 (through Feb. 23). This dense, brainy show has been organized by curators who have a healthy respect for the visual impact of actual objects. With everything from farm furniture and peasant ceramics to frighteningly austere city plans that, thankfully, were never built, it sheds new light on the precocious polymath who became, as the introductory text panel states, "arguably the most influential, admired and maligned architect of the 20th century." It is accompanied by an excellent 57-page exhibition guide, which should become a model for other exhibitors (Smith).

Galleries: 57th Street

AL HELD AND GEORGE SUGARMAN, "The Early 60's," Washburn, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 397-6780 (through Jan. 25). These two artists were close friends in the early 60's, and it looks as if they egged each other on like Picasso and Braque, breaking with the faded romance of Abstract Expressionism for a more cheerfully hedonistic formalism. The sculptor's logic-flouting arrangements of brightly painted, semiorganic shapes chainsawed from laminated wood are well matched by the painter's punchy, generously sensuous canvases (Johnson).

MICHAEL SPANO, "Time Frames," Laurence Miller, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 397-3930 (through Dec. 21). For two decades Mr. Spano has been exploring ways the camera may be used to reflect the complexities and disjunctions of urban experience. This retrospective includes split-screen diptychs, ghostly multiple exposures, seemingly radioactive solarized pictures and gridded prints made with a camera that sequentially exposes eight images on a single negative. At his best, in panoramic pictures made using a rotating lens, there is an intoxicated receptivity to the world (Johnson).

"LOUIS STONE, AMERICAN MODERNIST," Michael Rosenfeld, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 247-0082 (through Jan. 11). The Modernist abstractions painted between 1938 and 1942 by this little known Ohio-born artist are undeniably fetching, even if they don't put him in a league with Arshile Gorky. Living in Lambertville N.J., Stone sampled and re-mixed possibilities gleaned from Picasso, Kandinsky, Miro and other European pioneers. He was, perhaps, more a sophisticated designer than a deeply original painter, but seeing more of his work could alter that impression (Johnson).

Galleries: SoHo

ENID BAXTER BLADER, "Letter From the Girl, Mailed at the Gas Station," Location One, 26 Greene Street, (212) 334-3347 (through Dec. 28). Cerebral film buffs might find in Ms. Blader's 18-minute video projection all kinds of inside references and jokes about film noir, B movies and other sorts of low-end cinematic Pop. A puzzling montage of scenes set in a rural wasteland features a woman in a trench coat on the run, a mysteriously menacing 1980's-style bar girl and an overweight bleached blonde looking for someone who remains unspecified. Instead of plot, there's a curious blend of suspense and tedium (Johnson).

"FRIDA'S WORLD," Cavin-Morris, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 226-3768 (through Jan. 4). If Frida Kahlo was as tempestuous as the new biographical movie has it, you would never know it from this selection of vintage portraits by various photographers, in which she invariably radiates a regal, mysteriously contained dignity. Her husband, Diego Rivera, appears, too, but is no competition for the uni-browed one's photogenic magnetism (Johnson).

* ALEX HAY, "Work From the 60's," Peter Freeman, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 966-5154 (through Dec. 21). In the 1960's, Mr. Hay produced paintings and sculptures that were featured in important Pop Art exhibitions. Each of the enchanting works here is a greatly enlarged representation of an ordinary object made with dry verisimilitude: a grainy, printed cash register receipt fills a canvas more than seven feet tall; a three-dimensional lunch-size paper bag stands five feet tall, its wrinkles, tears and saw-tooth edges reproduced with loving exactitude (Johnson).

* CHRIS JOHANSON, "Now Is Now," Deitch Projects, 76 Grand Street, (212) 343-7300 (through Dec. 21). Mr. Johanson's funny and touching faux-naive painting, drawing and sculpture seem the products of an inspired simpleton's holistic vision. An installation in which a ship goes round and round, driven by a pivot arm balanced by a cartoon moneybag, represents the futility of materialism; smaller works spoof New Age therapy culture, like a picture of people dancing in silly cat suits, one exclaiming, "This is an excellent workshop!" Under the satiric surface, there's a genuine religious yearning (Johnson).

"PHOTOGRAPHY (AS COMMENTARY)," Kent, 67 Prince Street, (212) 966-4500, (through Jan. 25). Hans Haacke's pairing of a Walker Evans photograph of an impoverished farm family and a photo-op picture of the elder George Bush in a farmer's costume with his wife, Barbara, on the porch of a hurricane-wrecked house still resonates in the era of the younger George Bush. Dennis Adams's grid of Patty Hearst images and darkly comical studio pictures of Hispanic folks in alpine fantasy-scapes by Leandro Erlich and Judi Werthein also stand out in this smart 10-artist show of photography put to political purpose (Johnson).

"ANDY WARHOL: MODEL," Ronald Feldman, 31 Mercer Street, (212) 226-3232 (through Dec. 21). If you are fascinated by the famously enigmatic Warhol persona, this barrage of portraits could cure you. The show features over 300 images of the artist by the photographer Christopher Makos. Most interesting is a huge series of formal portraits of Warhol in women's makeup and various wigs. Contact sheets show him posing as a fashion model. Video clips are also on view, including his cameo appearance on "The Love Boat" (Johnson).

Galleries: Chelsea

MARINA ABRAMOVIC, "The House With the Ocean View," Sean Kelly, 528 West 29th Street, (212) 239-1181 (through Dec. 21). The 12-day public fast by this extreme-performance veteran, which introduced hundreds of visitors to the rigors of early 70's performance art while giving it a new sense of form, ended just before Thanksgiving. But the sculptural combination of elevated platforms and starkly geometric furniture -- Donald Judd boxes crossed with Robert Wilson set designs -- that contributed to its gravity and clarity remains. The ladders with butcher knives for rungs seem melodramatic, compared with the restraint with which Ms. Abramovic conducted herself, but the setting remains charged with her intensity (Smith).

SIAH ARMAJANI, "Glass Room for an Exile and Related Works," Senior & Shopmaker, 21 East 26th Street, (212) 213-6767 (through Jan. 11). Mr. Armajani is justly celebrated for his public artworks. In the gallery his sculpture is less surprising. "Glass Room for an Exile," the main attraction here, has two large adjoining cubes, one lined with a black curtain, the other transparent and furnished with a chair and a wheel. The conjunction of metaphysical obscurity and utilitarian transparency is rich, but the installation's overly precious formality does the symbolism less justice than it deserves (Johnson).

DELIA BROWN, "Pastorale," D'Amelio Terras, 525 West 22nd Street, (212) 352-9460 (through Dec. 21). Departing from her watercolors of attractive young people lounging about in expensive homes, Ms. Brown offers a series of faux-kitsch Arcadian landscape paintings and a music video in which the pop singer Goapele lip-syncs her way through a party of attractive young people in a luxurious, rustically styled house. The artist treats her themes of vanity, pastoral escapism and the cult of youth with an annoyingly blithe, Warholian superficiality (Johnson).

SARAH CHARLESWORTH, "Neverland," Gorney Bravin & Lee, 534 West 26th Street, (212) 352-8372 (through Dec. 21). Once associated with artists like Barbara Kruger and Sherrie Levine, who used photography to expose the medium's own sociology, Ms. Charlesworth is still making glossy images of iconic objects in super-saturated colors. With their color-coordinated frames, her photographs are wry mock-commodities, but hanging at different heights in the gallery, her images of a full moon, burning fireplace logs, a Magrittean pipe and other singular objects create a mood more of playful domestic reverie than intellectual suspicion (Johnson).

* KARIN DAVIE, Mary Boone, 541 West 24th Street, (212) 752-2929 (through Dec. 21). Spirits will be lifted by Ms. Davie's exuberantly sensuous abstract paintings. Undulating, striated ribbons in high-contrast colors fill the canvases, seeming to balloon into three-dimensional space and threatening to burst the rectangular edges of the picture. She mixes Abstract Expressionism, Op and Pop into ravishing visual plenitude (Johnson).

BILL FEENEY, "Out West/Back East," Cornell DeWitt Gallery, 547 West 27th Street, (212) 695-6845 (through Dec. 21). Mr. Feeney grew up in Laramie, Wyo., which explains his Neo-Pop multimedia evocation of an Old West saloon, complete with swinging door, a bar and a broken mirror in remembrance of an angry, gun-wielding patron. Gunslingers and a bronco rider outlined in neon add illumination, while a lovely wooden model of a fire escape in a gallery alcove nods to the artist's current home in Brooklyn (Johnson).

JANET HENRY, "American Anatomy and Other Work?" P.P.O.W., 555 West 25th Street, (212)647-1044 (through Dec. 21). Words are the stuff of Ms. Henry's work, words that she cursively traces in ropy necklaces, or lariats, made of beads, tiny dolls, coins, scraps of cloth, plastic, shredded cellophane and the like. Enshrined on the wall, they read "fear," "dirt," "once," "plethora," and "Ana," the latter a tribute to the promising young artist Ana Mendieta who died in an unexplained fall out a window in 1985. Proving that Ms. Henry also has a sense of humor, there is a whole phrase, made of paper squares encased in clear vinyl. Each square reads like a running journal of her wide-ranging ruminations, but they are arranged in block letters to form "Oh Shut Up" (Glueck).

THOMAS HIRSCHHORN, Barbara Gladstone, 515 West 24th Street, (212) 206-9300 (through Dec. 21). To imagine Mr. Hirschhorn, the 45-year-old Swiss-born installationist, think of him as Joseph Beuys with a sense of humor and without the egomania. This show is a tour de force of wood, cardboard and duct tape. The gallery is transformed into a cave. There are books everywhere, with posters of Tupac Shakur and mannequins wrapped in aluminum foil. The results look like a shantytown Lascaux-terrorist hideaway-teenager's room. The spirit is lightly anarchic (politics are the subtext) and open armed. At a time when so much new art is so meticulously packaged and commercial, the cheerful messiness is almost a political statement in itself (Kimmelman).

DENNIS HOLLINGSWORTH, Nicole Klagsbrun, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 243-3335 (through Dec. 21). Paint seems to have an antic life of its own in Mr. Hollingsworth's viscerally lyrical abstractions. Brushed, drizzled, squeegeed, congealed, squeezed from the tube and formed into spiky buttons like sea urchins in a luscious range of colors, it coheres into off-kilter compositions that push to the limit tension between the seductively physical and the visionary (Johnson).

JERALD IEANS, Lucas Schoormans, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 243-3159 (through Dec. 28). This young, self-taught painter produces economical, well-composed arrangements of biomorphic forms on medium-large canvases. With their overlapping, amoeboid shapes in shades of gray or muted pastels, finely combed textures and sharp edges, Mr. Ieans's paintings have great decorative appeal. Slyly sophisticated updates of Miro-style Surrealism, they are formally restrained yet funky (Johnson).

JOHN ISAACS, "Dumb Planets Are Round Too," Feigen Contemporary, 535 West 20th Street, (212) 929-0500 (through Dec. 21). Among many different sorts of photographs, paintings, videos and an installation, one amazing sculpture stands out: a life-size, morbidly obese man made with the verisimilitude of a wax-works horror. Spotlighted in a darkened empty room and elevated on a low pedestal, he is like a force-fed Frankenstein's monster, a bald-headed mountain of swelling and sagging flab and horrendously diseased skin. It is meant to be a Dorian Gray-style portrait of the artist as a symbol of Western overconsumption (Johnson).

FRANK LOBDELL, Charles Cowles Gallery, 537 West 24th Street, (212) 925-3500 (through Dec. 21). This show of works from 1948 to 1972 by the West Coast Abstract Expressionist Frank Lobdell is his first in New York in some years, although the artist himself, now 81, has not lacked exposure in his own Bay Area haunts and elsewhere. His early mentors were Clyfford Still and Mark Rothko, so it's not surprising that color is his passion, strong hues urgently laid on in impasto textures or thin glazes and often tempered by vibrant blacks. An edge of tension that's almost palpable runs through the work. It's refreshing to see it again (Glueck).

BRIAN MAGUIRE, "The Bayview Project," White Box, 525 West 26th Street, (212) 714-2347 (through Jan. 4). This exhibition is billed as a collaboration between Mr. Maguire, an Irish painter and conceptualist, and 13 unidentified women incarcerated at the Bayview Correctional Facility in Chelsea. It includes paintings made by the women in workshops directed by Mr. Maguire, Expressionistic portraits of individual women by him and an outdoor billboard publicizing the project with four giant reproductions of Mr. Maguire's paintings. One can imagine a fierce debate arising around questions of identity, art therapy and exploitation (Johnson).

"MULTIPLES: AN INCOMPLETE SURVEY," Brent Sikkema, 530 West 22nd Street, (212) 929-2262 (through Dec. 22). This crowded exhibition of more than 60 multiples is surprisingly engrossing. Notable items include Sarah Stanton's chrome-plated hamburger; a pair of porthole-shaped nautical lights in a wooden crate by Andrea Zittel; animated faux-wood by Richard Artschwager; glass egg yolks by Kiki Smith; little free-standing racially provocative silhouettes by Kara Walker; and beautiful goat-skin gloves with hand-stitched surrealistic veins by Meret Oppenheim (Johnson).

GEORGE SUGARMAN, "Yellow to White to Blue to Black," Gary Tatinstian, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 633-0110 (through Dec. 21). One of the most interesting sculptors of the 1960's, Sugarman would organize eccentrically shaped, brightly painted objects into sprawling groups, playfully blending Cubism, Matissean color and Post-Minimalism installation. Along with collages from the 50's and 60's, this show features a three-part sculpture from 1967. Each colored laminated wood piece is a paradoxical mix of complexity and simplicity, elegance and awkwardness; they go together like a jazz trio (Johnson).

* RYAN WEIDEMAN, "In My Taxi," Bruce Silverstein, 504 West 22nd Street, (212) 627-3930 (through Jan. 5). When he arrived in New York in 1980, Mr. Weideman took a job as a taxicab driver and began taking pictures of his transient back-seat occupants. Celebrities, party girls, drag queens, tired businessmen and tourists have all briefly visited his mobile studio, and he has recorded them in portraits of disarming, sometimes exquisitely erotic intimacy. In most cases the artist's own visage leans into the picture, wearing an expression of Buster Keatonish ennui (Johnson).

Other Galleries

"GLOBAL PRIORITY," Jamaica Center for Arts and Learning, 161-04 Jamaica Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, (718) 658-7400 (through Jan. 11). The curators Heng-Gil Han and Gordon Knox invited 30 artists from around the world to deliver responses to globalization via generic mailers marked "global priority." On view are works by well-known artists like Xu Bing, Mark Dion and William Kentridge, but some of the most memorable efforts are by less familiar artists. Ayelet Zohar's video tour of a fence encircling an Israeli settlement is a canny wedding of Minimalism and political provocation (Johnson).

ALEX GREY, Tibet House, 22 West 15th Street, Flatiron district, (212) 807-0563 (through Jan. 3). Mr. Grey's painting, with its tantric symbolism, medical-illustration finesse and New Age optimism, might be described as psychedelic realism. In it the human figure is rendered with X-ray or CAT-scan transparency, the way Aldous Huxley saw a leaf when he was on mescalin. Mr. Grey's images have been appropriated by a countercultural audience: they have shown up on promotional posters for rave events and on paper used for blotter-style LSD. But they look right at home at Tibet House, where contemporary versions of religious tankas, meant for esoteric instruction and meditation, often hang (Cotter).

DAVID HAMMONS, "Concerto in Black and Blue," Ace Gallery, 275 Hudson Street, at Dominick Street, South Village, (212) 255-5599 (through Feb. 1). This stone-soup installation consists only of small blue lights available at the entrance. With them visitors can explore the vast darkness of the gallery's several vast spaces while the possible meanings of the show's title hum in the mind. Extending Duchamp's notion of the viewer as essential to the completion of an art work, its fleeting beauty exists only when it is being seen (Smith).

Last Chance

"STUART DAVIS: ART AND THEORY, 1920-31," Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, (212) 685-0008 (through Sunday). The mountain of papers, notebooks and sketchbooks left by Davis (1892-1964) show that his jazzy, spontaneous-looking works didn't just happen. They evolved from meticulous plotting on paper, in words and drawings, before he put brush to canvas. To celebrate its acquisition of his earliest known diary, dated 1920-22, and a 1926 sketchbook, the Morgan has mounted a small show of 12 drawings and paintings that point up the role of the sketchbook and diary in the development of his artistic theory between 1920 and '31. The gouache "Coffee Pot No. 2" (1930), a brightly colored, boldly patterned streetscape, for example, reflecting his fascination with urban life and signage, derives directly from a modest drawing in the sketchbook. By putting the roots of Davis's work in context with some of his early flowerings, the Morgan has found a lucid way to present its important new acquisition. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, to 8 p.m.; Saturdays, to 6 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $8; $6 for students and 65+ (Glueck).

GUILLERMO KUITCA, Sperone Westwater, 415 West 13th Street, West Village, (212) 999-7337 (through tomorrow). Mr. Kuitca's ambitions have turned Wagnerian. His latest show includes "The Ring," a big multipart painting inspired by Wagner's opera cycle, the backgrounds painted in different styles, meant to track an arc from Cubism to the digital age. Mr. Kuitca's work is cool, airless, philosophical and oblique. When it isn't arch and dry, it can be hypnotic. There are also paintings of airport luggage-conveyor belts, apartment-floor plans and peep show booths, akin to the Wagner panels and similarly melancholic. But the most memorable works are small ones on paper: seating plans for theaters that seem to melt, explode, drip and bend (Kimmelman).

* BRUCE NAUMAN, Van de Weghe Fine Art, 521 West 23rd Street, Chelsea, (212) 929-6633 (through tomorrow). This three-decade survey administers a substantial dose of Bruce Nauman's cerebrally punishing visual poetry. Neon signs feature flat-footed wordplay; one, for example, blinks "war" one way and "raw" the other. Most repellent are sculptures made from the animal forms used by taxidermists: a mobile has dangling cast-aluminum dogs with legs cut off and reattached in reverse (Johnson).

PAUL NOBLE and GIOVANNI BATTISTA PIRANESI, Susan Inglett, 100 Wooster Street, SoHo, (212) 343-0573 (through tomorrow). Among the most impressive works in the Museum of Modern Art's "Drawing Now" exhibition are Mr. Noble's huge architectural fantasies. His two etchings on view here, though ordinary in scale, are similarly absorbing in their detail and narrative lunacy. They are well matched by four views of ancient ruins by Piranesi, the great 18th-century printmaker and architectural visionary (Johnson).

GRAPHIC: Photos: Detail from "Self-Portrait With Charles Kuralt," 1989, by Ryan Weideman, on view through Jan. 5 at the Bruce Silverstein Gallery in Chelsea. (Bruce Silverstein Gallery); Tissot's "London Visitors," on loan to the Frick Collection. (Toledo Museum of Art)

PUB-DATE: December 13, 2002
 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section F; Column 1; Escapes; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1454 words

HEADLINE: DRIVING; 
Wounded to the Quick By an Affair Gone Astray

BYLINE:  By JASON TANZ 

 BODY:
THERE is nothing so cruel as betrayal, and when the love betrayed has been as pure as Mike Dini's for Porsche, the initial shock can turn quickly to outrage. From his adolescence in Livermore, Calif., in the 1970's Mr. Dini fantasized about owning a Porsche, and in 1999, when he finally bought one -- a glacier-white 911 -- his joy was almost unbounded. "I stared at the crest on the steering wheel," he recalled in a telephone interview a few weeks ago from his home in La Jolla, Calif., "and said, 'Am I really driving this thing?' "
 And then, out of the blue, came the unthinkable. Sometime in 2000 he first heard reports that Porsche, the iconic maker of sports cars, was developing a sport utility vehicle. 
 His first reaction was denial. ("Oh, no," he remembered thinking. "You can't be doing this.") Then he moved onto the second stage of grieving -- anger -- and that is pretty much where he has stayed. "Every S.U.V. I've seen is driven by some soccer mom on her cellphone," Mr. Dini said. "I hate these people, and that Porsche would throw me into that category made me speechless. Just speechless." 
Mike Dini is not alone. Since Porsche's S.U.V. project was first announced in 1999, it has been dogged by controversy. Autoextremist.com, an online automotive journal, said in October that the S.U.V., called the Cayenne, "threatens to destroy the very soul of the company." An October 2000 article in The Independent Weekly of Durham, N.C., called it "a stupid idea conceived by chimps." Even the relatively staid Car and Driver magazine referred to the Cayenne last month as "either a brilliant marketing scheme or a sure sign that The End is near." But by far the loudest cries of anguish are coming from Porsche owners.
Several were happy to be interviewed. "Everything about the Cayenne is completely the opposite of what Porsche is and does," Pete Grazaitis, a Porsche owner in Cockeysville, Md., said. "It will be the death of a tradition," Robert A. Grant, a Boxster owner in Agoura Hills, Calif. 
Porsche unveiled the finished Cayenne in September at the Paris Auto Show. The car will not appear in United States showrooms until March 15, but dealers are taking orders. The company says it does not know how many have been presold but it does say that it has received expressions of interest from at least 20,000 potential buyers.
To the layman, the Cayenne seems like a car that should satisfy any Porsche fan. It looks a bit like a stretched and swollen Boxster (the relatively low-priced roadster introduced in 1997) and its turbo model, with a 450-horsepower engine, can go from a stop to 62 miles an hour in 5.6 seconds. But the Internet is clogged with the sentiments of the dissatisfied and the incensed.
Porsche fanatics have long flocked to the Web to discuss their favorite carmaker. But over the last couple of years, Porsche-related bulletin boards have become polarized group therapy sessions, as Porschephiles have hotly debated the merits of the new vehicle. Many say the money spent on it would have been better used improving racing performance. (Porsche hasn't won a trophy at Le Mans since 1998.) Even those who don't object to the S.U.V. idea have complaints -- that the Cayenne is ugly, too expensive, or being released years too late.
"No other Porsche -- past, present, or future -- comes close to generating the kind of response that the Cayenne has," said Chuck Hammersmith, founder of Porsche Pete's Boxster Board, a Web site (www.986board.com) that draws thousands of Porsche fanatics every week. Over the last two years, Mr. Hammersmith estimates, the Boxster Board has received more than 10,000 postings about the Cayenne. Even Porsche admits, on its own Web site (www.porsche.com), that the S.U.V.'s debut is "surrounded by speculation, curiosity, and a measure of skepticism."
But what really sends Porschephiles' outrage into overdrive is the thought that Porsche has turned its back on its sports-car-loving fan base to appeal to a different breed of driver: the yuppie dilettante. And there may be no vision more heretical to a testosterone-poisoned 911 owner than that of a suburban mother loading groceries into the back of her Porsche after dropping her children off at soccer practice.
"A Porsche S.U.V. will, perhaps forever, cheapen the brand," fumed Matt Mintzer, a Milton, Mass., Porsche 911 owner and a frequent contributor to Porsche-related Internet bulletin boards. "Which demographic will this thing attract? My guess is BMW poseur types."
Robin Sun of Miami, who drives a 1996 911, picked up the argument: "People will buy these Porsche S.U.V.'s because they're a fad, and they'll embarrass the real Porsche crowd."
"They're not going to know how to drive and they'll do stupid things," he added. "It's scary to think about."
The Cayenne is the result of a scare that Porsche experienced during the recession of the early 1990's, when the company faced the very real possibility of bankruptcy. Porsche survived, but its executives were convinced that it needed to appeal to a more diverse range of car owners. "The company learned a very important lesson back in the early 90's," said Martin Peters, a Porsche spokesman. "The sports car market alone is not sufficient to maintain our security as a company."
Porsche wasn't the only car company to conclude that the growing S.U.V. market was the one to tap. "S.U.V.'s have become the new fashion statement in this business," said Chris Cedegren, an analyst at Nextrend, an automotive industry research and consulting firm in Thousand Oaks, Calif.
But unlike Cadillac or Lexus, Porsche is not a luxury-car manufacturer; it makes sports cars. And by entering the S.U.V. market, Porsche is vaulting into an entirely new business, all while trying to preserve the power of its brand. "It's a classic problem in brand management," said Nancy Koehn, a professor of business administration at Harvard Business School -- and particularly difficult for brands like Porsche, whose loyal customers cling to its particular reputation and the exclusivity that comes with it. (If businesses don't manage the transition carefully, the results can be devastating. When Halston introduced a down-market clothing line for J. C. Penney in 1983, for instance, Bergdorf Goodman pulled Halston items from its shelves.)
"If I say to somebody, 'I own a Porsche,' I want them to think I'm a swinger," said Al Ries, a co-author of "The 22 Immutable Laws of Branding," and a founder of Ries & Ries, marketing consultants.
To be sure, some Porsche owners have already made down payments on Cayennes, according to the company. "A lot of people love Porsches but need a bigger car," said Tony Sciple, a general manager at Champion Motors in Pompano Beach, Fla., the country's largest Porsche dealership.
And Carter Dunkin, a spokesman for the Porsche Club of America, an independent organization that receives some money from Porsche and arranges racing events for Porsche drivers, said that the club wanted to be "inclusive." But opening the club to S.U.V. owners may be too much for some Porsche enthusiasts. At least one member has posted a demand on the organization's Internet bulletin board for a vote on whether Cayenne owners should be included in club events.
Porsche has faced this dynamic -- the gearhead purist versus the upwardly mobile car-polisher -- before. Some fans were dismayed when, in the 1970's, Porsche developed the 914, which had a Volkswagen engine, and the 924, which was built in an Audi plant and had an engine used in tractors. (Porsche and Volkswagen worked together on the Cayenne, another sore spot.) Others refuse to recognize 911's built after 1998 as true Porsches, since that is the year that the company replaced its air-cooled engine with a water-cooled one, largely to help meet new emissions standards. Even the Boxster was originally dismissed by some purists as an entry-level wannabe.
This history causes some to view the anti-S.U.V. faction as a band of intransigent diehards.
"Most of these yahoos are so predisposed to hate the Cayenne, they can't even think straight," said Brian Rickerson, a Boxster owner in Los Angeles, in an e-mail interview. "Everything they say about the Cayenne not being a real Porsche was said about every model after the original 356, including the hallowed 911."
But Cayenne revilers like Mike Dini insist that this is a more serious breach. This time, after all, people who have no interest in driving sports cars will be able to describe themselves as Porsche owners.
In June, Mr. Dini moved up to a 911 Turbo. But he says sliding behind the wheel has already lost its thrill and glamour. "It's now like driving a Ford or a G.M.," he said. "It's just another 'me-too' car company."

HEADLINE: Aristide of Haiti: Pragmatist or Demagogue? 

BYLINE:  By DAVID GONZALEZ 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Dec. 12 

 BODY:
To his many impoverished followers, President Jean-Bertrand Aristide is the leader they fervently believe will lift them out of their misery. To his opponents -- a group that has become more vocal and more visible -- he is a demagogue who must reform or resign for the good of the country.
 Those competing camps have clashed in the streets here in recent weeks, sometimes with fatal results as Haiti's lingering political stalemate, now two years old, flirts with disaster and disorder. 
 Negotiations have so far failed to end the deadlock, which stems from an election dispute. Several hundred million dollars in foreign aid have been frozen because of the crisis, and the economy of the hemisphere's poorest nation has festered. 
Yet President Aristide says Haiti is at peace, or at least not in open warfare, thanks to him. In a 90-minute interview at the National Palace, he said he had already made significant concessions to his opponents. 
He faulted international lenders for criticizing him while not providing Haiti with money that would allow the government to work. He has every intention, he said, of finishing his second five-year term.
"I am not saying that I am the best," he said. "I am saying it is not easy to find someone capable of doing what I am doing for two years. I do not have to say a lot. I just have to invite people to look at what we have accomplished with nothing."
As much as offering a defense of his record, the statement provided a precis of Haiti's political conundrum.
Even his critics acknowledge that for all his flaws, there is no other politician with Mr. Aristide's popular standing. But they complain that the president has deflected responsibility for the political deadlock and made progress toward breaking it impossible.
Despite assurances about his commitment to democracy, they say, he has built his support in part by playing dangerously on the race and class differences that have made the country's politics so volatile -- and its democratic governments so fleeting -- since Haiti's founding.
"If he does not do something dramatic we are going to be in a terrible situation," said a leading businessman who has tried to intercede with the government. "I do not know if he has the wisdom to do what is necessary, because time is running out."
The Organization of American States has urged international lenders and donors to release the money, and donors meeting in Washington this week said they were looking for ways to provide some immediate funds to assist development and provide jobs.
But first they want Mr. Aristide to make some administrative changes that will account for how the money is used. Those changes hardly depend on the political opposition, said one official at the meeting.
During the interview, held in the antechamber to his office in the hushed, almost still palace, Mr. Aristide portrayed himself as having already been reasonable with his opponents, a fractious coalition known as the Democratic Convergence.
He has offered to shorten or even end the terms of the winners of the disputed 2000 elections, he said. He blamed the opposition for sabotaging any chance for a peaceful resolution of the political crisis by refusing to take part in new legislative elections next year against his Lavalas movement.
"Those who say Lavalas is weak, why not go to elections?" he said. "It would be good for the country."
His critics answer that Mr. Aristide has been slow to guarantee their security, particularly since a mysterious nighttime raid on the presidential palace a year ago that the president's supporters say was an attempted coup.
Since then, the critics say, the government has yet to disarm gangs of thugs who have sought retribution and intimidated Aristide opponents. Some say it is an indication that Mr. Aristide cannot control his supporters in the Lavalas movement, or does not want to.
Diplomats are warning both sides not to use the anniversary of the palace raid, next week, to provoke more confrontations.
"After 200 years of independence we still have some consequences from that past where we had 32 coups d'etat," Mr. Aristide said. "It is not easy for all the political parties to forget about that bad way to behave, moving from one coup d'etat to another."
Mr. Aristide, a former Roman Catholic priest who was first elected president in 1990, was himself quickly ousted in a coup, only to be restored in 1994 by an American-led invasion force. Washington has had an ambivalent relationship with him since.
In recent weeks, protesters, including former allies, have charged him with dividing the nation with worrisome appeals to race and class. Last week, during a speech in the town of Les Cayes, Mr. Aristide condemned the opposition, many from a fair-skinned elite, for being against dark-skinned Haitians, like himself.
"You are peasants; you are poor," he said in Creole, the language of most Haitians, in the cadence he perfected from his days as a preacher. "You are the same color I am. They don't like you. Your hair is kinky, same as mine. They don't like you. Your children are not children of big shots. They don't like you."
Mr. Aristide amended his remarks in a later speech, in French, the language of the upper classes, to say that all Haitians must work together for the common good. 
But his critics charged that it was a familiar pattern of making different appeals to different audiences and leaving open the potential for misunderstanding and possibly conflict.
The morning of the interview, several dozen supporters gathered in a park near the palace to decry the withholding of foreign aid. The protest echoed a theme that Mr. Aristide himself has emphasized, that withholding the money has directly increased his people's suffering.
"Many people seem to forget the poor have a right to eat," Mr. Aristide said. "Keeping the money out of Haiti is a violation of human rights."
Such words have failed to sway international officials. "Aristide has to understand there is political governance and there is economic governance," said the official who attended the donor's meeting. "People are skeptical and think he will probably do what he always does, blame somebody else."

HEADLINE: The Ghost of Walkouts Past 

BYLINE:  By Jonathan Mahler; Jonathan Mahler is writing a book about New York and baseball in the 1970's.

 BODY:
The parallels have not gone unnoticed. The city is facing a huge budget gap. Businesses are fleeing Manhattan. The mayor is under fire for trying to provide desperately needed low-income housing in middle-class neighborhoods. The downtown rock music scene is flourishing. The Knicks are slipping. The Mets have placed their faith in a pitcher named Tom. The 70's, it's being said, are back.
 In the surest sign yet that we are being visited by ghosts, the members of Transport Workers Union Local 100 are poised to walk off the job, just as they did in early 1980. 
 If the subways and buses are the city's central nervous system, a transit strike equals paralysis -- another indicator that New York is, in 70's-speak, the pits. But history suggests another possibility.
The story begins in the 1950's, when, after 20 years or so of intramural ideological squabbling, New York's municipal unions started building political muscle. Mayor Robert F. Wagner recognized the unions as a force to be reckoned with and pandered to. In those blissful days of limitless spending, Wagner bettered working conditions, instituted pensions and standardized health benefits. True empowerment came in 1958, when the mayor granted collective bargaining rights to New York's public unions. That move did not go unrewarded. In 1961, the mayor was reelected with a key assist from municipal unions.
By the end of the 60's, New York City government had more employees than the garment, banking and longshore industries combined, according to Joshua B. Freeman, a historian at Queens College. In a sense, the growth was in keeping with the city's unique civic culture. If New York aspired to be all things to all its people, it needed plenty of men and women on the payroll.
With numbers came militancy. Work stoppages were common in the 60's. Teachers, welfare workers and even the Metropolitan Opera Company were involved in labor clashes. Fun City became Strike City.
The transit union was perhaps the most radical of the bunch, in part because it pre-dated the other municipal unions. (New York's subway system was privately owned until 1940.) Its leader, Michael J. Quill -- "Red Mike," to his enemies -- was a blustery, swaggering union boss who was locked in a perpetual war of nerves with City Hall.
On the first day of 1966, his transit workers walked out, shutting down the city's subways and buses. John V. Lindsay had just become mayor, prompting Sammy Davis Jr. to crack that Lindsay had eliminated subway crime on his first day in office.
The transit strike was Lindsay's first test as mayor, and he failed it. For starters, he encouraged people to stay home. He also invoked the Condon-Wadlin Act, the notoriously harsh (and practically unenforceable) precursor to the Taylor Act that required the firing of the strikers. And he threw Quill and his cohorts in jail, making them martyrs.
The strike lasted 12 long days. Quill, who'd had a heart attack during the strike, died shortly after a settlement was reached, but he died triumphant. He had secured a 15 percent raise for his men. 
Some 14 years later, Mayor Edward I. Koch provided a dramatically different model as he dealt with the 1980 transit strike.
Mr. Koch was determined to prevent the April strike from crippling the city or deflating its spirit. He expected everyone to go to work and cheered them on as they did. He denounced union demands as outrageous and was irrepressibly defiant, going about his daily business, occasionally pausing to dismiss pro-union hecklers as "wackos."
Close to 90 percent of those with jobs in the city made it to work. The 11-day strike somehow stirred New Yorkers' sense of pride in their hometown. There were plenty of frustrated commuters, but the images of people in sneakers and suits pouring off the bridges at rush hour became symbols not of a city paralyzed but of a rugged metropolis refusing to give in. The transit strike of 1980 turned into an emblem of the rebirth of New York City after the fiscal crisis, layoffs and soaring unemployment of the 1970's.
Mr. Koch captured the mood of the city in the days after the strike in one of his many memoirs. Even discounting for self-inflation, it reads accurately: "New Yorkers were in a kind of euphoria that weekend," he wrote. "They had been called upon to run the gantlet, and they had done it with style."
Mayor Michael J. Bloomberg should remember this as he steps into the breach. Perhaps a transit strike isn't something to be feared. Handled correctly, it may be just the thing to pull us out of our funk. After all, that's what happened last time.

HEADLINE: Tiger Singapore Changes Its Stripes 

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, Dec. 6 

 BODY:
In less than a generation this island nation transformed itself from a swamp into a glittering jewel of Southeast Asia, a powerhouse of electronic exports and a center of financial services.
 Now, faced with economic uncertainty and pressed by the swift rise of China, Singapore is asking a hard question: how should it reinvent itself, yet again? 
 A government-led national debate is under way, with special panels, including one called the "Remaking Singapore Committee," created to come up with solutions. 
Cabinet ministers deliver motivational speeches to buck up confidence. Top businessmen ponder how they can keep Singapore, with no natural resources and a small population, in a premium global position. 
"Singapore is really a living example of the saying of Andy Grove, the head of Intel," said Ho Kwon Ping, a member of Singapore's powerful Government Investment Corporation, citing the title of Mr. Grove's 1996 book, "Only the Paranoid Survive."
"We've made paranoia into a state of art," said Mr. Ho, who is the head of one of the nation's successful business enterprises, Banyan Tree Hotels and Resorts, and is on the board of another, Singapore Airlines.
Singapore is not content with just job creation, he said, but wants to find ways to "stay ahead of the competition."
Singapore was forced into its reassessment after a long ride on the back of the information technology boom abruptly ended last year. Unemployment of 4.8 percent, small by world standards, is a record here.
After shrinking last year, the economy is expected to expand by 2.5 percent in 2002, down from a forecast of 4 percent. Few here expect annual growth to return to the sustained 7 and 8 percent of the mid-1990's, let alone the 9.8 percent of 2000.
High-end technology products were the specialty here, but now China is cornering that market. Singapore's position as a financial services center is also threatened.
Offshore banking peaked here in 1997 and has now settled back down to its 1989 level, according to Tan Khee Giap, the head of the government's central banking policy research unit.
Professor Tan said he anticipated the moment not too far in the future when Shanghai would overtake Singapore as a financial center.
Solutions to the gloom and doom are being sought in several directions: political, economic and educational.
To cushion itself from the economic growth of China, Singapore is further cementing its ties with the United States, particularly by working to complete a free trade agreement.
To make up for the downturn in the demand for its electronics and other manufactured goods, Singapore is moving into high-end niche industries, particularly biomedicine.
The educational system is being overhauled. The idea is to have less emphasis on rote learning and more emphasis on Chinese language, so that business with China will be easier. The 3.8 million population of Singapore is about 75 percent ethnic Chinese, but as part of the drive to ensure that the country moves easily in the global economy, English is the language of instruction.
The trade minister, George Yeo, has spent a great deal of time on the fine details of the trade agreement with the United States. The pact, now undergoing final negotiations, is expected to be signed early next year.
The underlying purpose of the deal is to keep the United States in the region, he said.
"As China becomes more powerful, the United States presence in the region will become more important," Mr. Yeo said in an interview. "The free trade agreement sends a signal."
Singapore seeks a "complementary" economic relationship with China but does not want to become "exclusively tied to China -- because that's uncomfortable," the minister said. 
"The free trade agreement makes us almost an extension of the United States in Southeast Asia," he added.
As China moves aggressively into Singapore's old strengths -- the disk drive, semiconductor and consumer electronics industries -- the government here is seeking to move into fields like biomedicine.
But China is beginning to compete in many of the same areas. "China has ambitions to be a major research and development center, and the brainpower being developed for this undertaking is breathtaking," Mr. Ho said.
For the moment, Singapore is banking on its reputation for rule of law and its strict protection of intellectual property rights as a major draw for pharmaceutical companies, Mr. Yeo said.
It is also tinkering with tax policy to make Singapore competitive with places like Hong Kong, Shanghai and the Shenzhen special economic zone in southern China. Corporate and personal taxes are to be lowered over three years to 20 percent.
But as the government makes its policy changes, the usually confident people of Singapore, given more to hard work than introspection, are asking questions. Some skeptics have wondered whether the shift to biomedicine is too little too late, and whether Singapore's restrictions on press freedoms may put off some.
Others wonder if the current generation of Singaporeans, spawned by a hardy breed of peasants who came from China, have become too comfortable.
"Our instinct for survival has gone," said Professor Tan, 45, the father of two children. His own father came to Singapore as a 16-year-old illiterate peasant from China and built a thriving palm oil plantation business.
"He came here as a beggar dressed in a gunny sack," Professor Tan said. "And look at my 3-year-old son -- he complains if there is no air-conditioning in the car."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 11, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article on Dec. 13 about Singapore's economic uncertainty and China's growing economic power misidentified the post held by Tan Khee Giap, who commented on Singapore's role as a financial center. He heads the central banking policies research unit at Nanyang Technological University's business school in Singapore and is an adjunct senior fellow at the Institute of Policy Studies there. He does not head the government's central banking policy research unit.
The article also misstated his view of the challenge posed by Shanghai. He said that not far in the future Shanghai could catch up with Singapore as a financial center -- not that it would catch up.

HEADLINE: Turks Look West; Will It Look Away? 

BYLINE:  By DEXTER FILKINS 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Dec. 12 

 BODY:
Like a nervous outsider standing at the gates of an exclusive club, Turkey awaited word today on whether the European Union would finally offer it a chance to step inside. 
 The decision whether the 15-nation group will ever admit this predominantly Muslim nation of 70 million people is an extraordinary test for both Turkey and the European Union, and word tonight from Copenhagen that no firm date for membership talks was set seemed sure to disappoint many Turks. 
 For Turkey, a NATO member nation straddling both Europe and Asia, union membership is seen as a way to plant itself in the Western camp once and for all. 
Across Europe, the question of admitting Turkey has sparked an unusual debate about the definition of Europe itself, and whether an Islamic country is compatible with a group of historically Christian countries. 
Turkey's new leaders, who hail from a party with Islamist roots, have suggested that a rejection in Copenhagen might compel them to turn their gaze to the east. 
"If the European Union insults Turkey, it will bear the consequences," Recep Tayip Erdogan, the leader of the governing Justice and Development Party, said after meetings this week in Copenhagen. 
The attacks of Sept. 11 last year and the possible war in Iraq have placed the debate over Turkey in the context of the clash between Islam and the West. They have also drawn the United States deeper than it has ever been into a debate on membership of the European Union.
The Bush administration, seeking permission to ferry ground troops through Turkey into Iraq if there is a war, was pushing European nations to set a date for membership talks. The United States also wants to use Turkey as an example of an Islamic country that can prosper while maintaining a strong friendship with the West. 
Public opinion in Turkey is running strongly in favor of membership. Looking west, the Turks see an economic powerhouse, where even the poorest countries, like its neighbor and longtime rival Greece, have seen living standards soar with membership.
"Why do Turks want to be part of the West?" asked Deniz Gocke, an economics professor at Bosporos University. "The factory worker wants his wages to rise. And we want democracy to be firmly established." 
Modern Turkey has long stood out in the Islamic world. Founded in 1923 after the collapse of the Ottoman Empire, the Turkish republic imposed strict limits on the role of Islam in public life. Its economy is relatively open, it is a member of the European Customs Union, and it has long maintained ties with Israel.
Still, Turkey has been torn by conflicting impulses. Its politics have been beset by corruption, and the military has repeatedly intervened against elected governments. Its current leaders, including Mr. Erdogan, flirted with doctrinaire political Islam in the past.
European leaders worry about Turkey's mixed record on democracy and human rights, including the past use of torture in jails and the sometimes brutal treatment of the Kurdish minority, which mounted an armed insurgency in the 1990's. 
Among Turks, there is widespread suspicion that the real reason behind Europe's coolness is religion.
Last month, Valery Giscard d'Estaing, the former French president and now head of a group charged with charting the future of the European Union, said Turkey's entry could spell "the end" of the group.
Mr. Giscard d'Estaing, in an interview with Le Monde, raised the specter of Turkey's rapidly increasing population, saying it would quickly become "the biggest member state in the European Union . . . with the biggest bloc in the European Parliament."
The remarks caused a sensation in Turkey, but have since been echoed across the Continent. Josef Joffe, editor in chief of the German weekly Die Zeit, said Mr. Giscard d'Estaing spoke for a large number of Europeans, who fear that thousands of Turks would pour in, searching for jobs and driving wages down.
In Istanbul's grittier neighborhoods, Europe indeed beckons to the men who pass their days in coffee houses waiting for the rumor of work.
Yilmaz Oksuz, 27 and a father of four, left his village on the Black Sea coast 10 years ago, but has never found much more than the occasional construction job. If Turkey joined the European Union, Mr. Oksuz said, he would head straight for Germany. 
"If I had the opportunity, I would go the next morning," he said. 
"If Turkey is going to be accepted by the union, then it will behave as a European power," said Fehmi Koru, a prominent Turkish newspaper columnist. "But if Turkey is going to be rejected by the union, then it is part of the Middle East and ought to take care of itself in the region."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Muslims coming out of noon prayers in Istanbul. There is a widespread suspicion in predominantly Muslim Turkey that religion is the reason for the European Union's coolness toward admitting it to membership. (Bikem Ekberzade for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Are Up Sharply, but Jobless Claims Rise 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 

 BODY:
Retail sales in November increased at the fastest rate in three months, the Commerce Department reported today. 
 Sales were up 0.4 percent from October, the department said. The month before, they edged up 0.1 percent and in September fell by 1.5 percent. 
 "The urge to splurge started to creep back into consumers' spending patterns," said Joel Naroff of Naroff Economic Advisers. "The fears that households would not visit the malls appear to be unfounded." 
Excluding auto sales, which can swing widely from month to month, retail sales rose 0.5 percent in November, a stronger performance than the 0.2 percent rise economists were forecasting. 
Sales of furniture and home furnishings jumped 2.3 percent, the biggest increase in nearly two years after a 0.2 percent rise in October. 
Last month's rise comes as the housing market, helped by low mortgage rates, is on track to post record sales this year. Sales of building materials rose 1.2 percent in November, up from a 0.1 percent advance in October. 
At electronics and appliance stores, sales rose 0.9 percent on top of a 1 percent increase in October. Food and beverage sales rose 0.9 percent, up from a 0.1 percent gain. Health and beauty store sales increased 0.3 percent, after a 0.2 percent advance. 
Auto sales dipped 0.1 percent, an improvement from October's 2.1 percent drop.
At bars and restaurants, sales rose 0.3 percent last month, a turnaround from the 0.5 percent decline in October. 
Sales at general merchandise stores, including department stores, increased 0.3 percent after a 1.2 percent gain in October. 
There were a few weak spots: Clothing sales dropped 1.3 percent in November, after a sharp rise in October of 5.5 percent. Sales at book, sporting goods and hobby stores fell 0.5 percent after a 0.1 percent decline. 
Consumer spending has been the main force keeping the economy going this year.
But an economist at Merrill Lynch, Gerald Cohen, said, that "if consumer spending is going to continue to grow, the job picture needs to improve sooner rather than later." 
And new data suggested that unemployment remained a problem. The Labor Department reported that new claims for jobless benefits increased by a seasonally adjusted 83,000, to 441,000 last week, the highest level since the middle of April. 
Analysts said the increase was exaggerated by seasonal adjustment problems, but they still predicted a sluggish job market in the months ahead. 
In still another report, the Commerce Department said that the current account deficit, the broadest measure of trade, narrowed slightly in the third quarter, to $127 billion, from a $127.6 billion deficit in the second quarter. 
The current account measures the movement of goods and services between countries as well as investment flows and transfers, including American foreign aid payments. 
The Labor Department also reported today that import prices, led by a decline in previously rising oil prices, fell 1.0 percent in November, the most in almost a year, after no change in October. Export prices climbed 0.1 percent.

HEADLINE: Fed's Rate Cut Is Linked to Strategy for Growth 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 

 BODY:
Members of the Federal Reserve's rate-setting committee decided on the reduction of half a percentage point in November as the best way to cut short a "soft spot" in economic growth, according to minutes of the meeting released today. 
 "A relatively aggressive easing action could help to ensure that the current soft spot in the economy would prove to be temporary and enhance the odds of a robust rebound in economic activity next year," the Nov. 6 minutes of the panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, indicated. 
 Some members also cited restrictive financial conditions, especially in bank lending, as another justification for the move. 
"The members agreed that monetary policy could do little to improve the performance of the economy in the near term," the minutes said, "but some emphasized that a 50-basis-point easing likely would feed through to some degree to market interest rates, with favorable implications for spending next year." (One hundred basis point are equivalent to 1 percent.) 
With inflation subdued, the panel thought that the risks of sharply easing rates were much less than the risks in not acting. 
"A failure to take an action," the minutes said, "that was needed because of a faltering economic performance would increase the odds of a cumulatively weakening economy and possibly even attendant deflation." 
The committee voted 12 to 0 to cut rates by a larger-than-expected amount and said the risks to the economy were balanced between inflation and weakness. 
There was less agreement on what is known as the balance-of-risks statement. Coming into the meeting, the panel had said the risks were tilted toward economic weakness. But the minutes noted that "some members" were less worried about that possibility. 
At the most recent meeting on Tuesday, the Federal Open Market Committee voted unanimously to leave rates steady.

HEADLINE: After Banning 1,092 Movies, Chile Relaxes Its Censorship 

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 11 

 BODY:
For nearly 30 years, it has been illegal here to exhibit or view the Bernardo Bertolucci film "Last Tango in Paris." The same prohibition has also been applied to Woody Allen's "Everything You Ever Wanted to Know About Sex," Ingmar Bergman's "Smiles of a Summer Night" and hundreds of other motion pictures.
 Now, though, that peculiar situation is about to end. After enduring ridicule for its attitudes and being chastised by human rights organizations for suppressing free expression, this nation of 15 million people is finally ending a censorship system that has kept some of the world's most popular and admired movies from being shown publicly here. 
 "This is a new step in favor of personal liberties and the dignity of the individual," President Ricardo Lagos said in signing the bill this week. It goes into effect on Jan. 1, just in time for the peak Southern Hemisphere summer movie season, and theaters and film societies are lining up to be the first to show forbidden works.
Though its embrace of laissez-faire economic policies suggests a certain libertarian inclination, Chile is probably the most socially conservative nation in Latin America, in large part because the Roman Catholic Church is even more powerful here than in neighboring countries. Divorce is prohibited here, for instance, and abortion is forbidden even to save a woman's life.
"We have lived too much time with the Opus Dei all over us, dominated by obscurantism," the Chilean film director Orlando Lubbert told a local newspaper. "It is time to come out of our shell." Opus Dei is a conservative Catholic lay group.
Since the censorship board began more than 75 years ago, 1,092 movies have been prohibited here. Most, to judge by their titles, are simply pornographic, but films by directors including Federico Fellini, Pier Paolo Pasolini, Pedro Almodovar and Oliver Stone have also been banned.
During the right-wing military dictatorship of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, from 1973 to 1990, military officers routinely banned or ordered huge cuts in any movie that aroused their ire or suspicion.
At one point, even a movie as innocuous as "Fiddler on the Roof" was prohibited, on the ground that too many of its characters were Russians. But the military censors were especially alarmed by politically charged movies like "Missing," about the disappearance of an American citizen here during the coup that brought General Pinochet to power, or Mr. Stone's "Salvador."
More recently, censors have also banned movies that they considered blasphemous, ranging from the Monty Python comedy "The Life of Brian" to Martin Scorsese's "The Last Temptation of Christ." 
Approval of the law does not mean the end of the censorship council. Instead, the board will now assign one of four ratings to movies and, in a move that has caused controversy, its membership is to be increased from 12 to 21, with psychologists, film directors and critics entering in place of army officers and judges.
During congressional debate of the changes, a conservative legislator argued that it was imperative the military remain represented on the board, given the number of war movies that would be screened. That led an opponent to reply that in view of the even larger number of films with sexual themes, the same logic would seem to demand that a prostitute be appointed.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Judge Says California Owes Money to Power Sellers
A federal administrative law judge rejected claims by California for nearly $9 billion in refunds for what officials said was price gouging during the energy crisis of 2000-2001, and instead said the state owed $1.2 billion to cover unpaid electricity bills.
 The judge, Bruce L. Birchman of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, ruled that energy companies overcharged California about $1.8 billion during the crisis, but said the state had an unpaid balance of $3 billion, and thus actually owed the $1.2 billion difference. The ruling will be reviewed by the three-member commission. Page A30. 

OPEC Tries to Rein In Members
Facing a credibility problem and rampant overproduction by members, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries moved to increase export quotas while demanding that members rein in their cheating. C8.

The board of the Ford Motor Company announced that it had formed a committee to look into the allocation of shares of Goldman Sachs to William Clay Ford Jr., left, the chairman and chief executive. Goldman Sachs allocated 400,000 shares to Mr. Ford in 1999 as part of its initial offering. Ford and Goldman have a long business relationship. C6.

United and Unions Discuss Changes
United executives and union leaders met for the first time since United filed for bankruptcy protection to discuss how the airline will be revamped, a process that is certain to include wage and benefit cuts for employees. C2.

Police Search Vivendi Offices
French investigators searched the offices of Vivendi Universal and the home of its former chief executive, Jean-Marie Messier, as they pursued an inquiry about the company's accounting. World Business, Section W.

Barnes & Noble Buys Publisher

Procter & Gamble announced that it had completed a multiyear restructuring effort and would thus cease reporting two sets of results, one including restructuring charges and the other without them. The Publicis Groupe's efforts to hold onto a top creative executive, part of its strategy to keep clients from straying during a reorganization, have failed. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C6.

Members of the Fed's rate-setting committee decided on the reduction of half a percentage point in November as the best way to cut short a "soft spot" in growth. C8.

HEADLINE: COMMODITIES; 
OPEC Raises Quotas but Calls for a Drop in Actual Output

BYLINE:  By PETER GREEN 

DATELINE: VIENNA, Dec. 12 

 BODY:
Facing a credibility problem and rampant overproduction by members at a time when oil prices are expected to slide, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries moved today to increase official export quotas while demanding that members rein in their cheating.
 OPEC said that it would raise official export quotas to 23 million barrels a day from the current 21.7 million barrels, while asking members to cut actual production by 7 percent, or 1.7 million barrels a day. 
 OPEC's credibility has eroded over the last few months because its members have been pumping about three million barrels more a day than they agreed to. 
After a meeting of oil ministers, OPEC said that it would ask members to comply with the new quotas. But senior OPEC officials acknowledged that they had no way to enforce the planned cuts, as world oil markets are buffeted by factors beyond their control. They include the global economic slowdown, a possible war in Iraq and political unrest in Venezuela that has halted all of that country's oil deliveries.
Analysts generally praised OPEC's move as a step toward keeping prices and supply stable. In New York trading, crude oil for January delivery was up 61 cents, or 2.2 percent, at $28.01 a barrel.
"They are being pre-emptive to prevent oversupply when peak winter demand subsides," said Mike Rothman, an energy analyst with Merrill Lynch in New York. "It's a smart thing." Although the price of oil is relatively robust now, demand usually drops off in late winter.
If members comply, OPEC's actual production and its quotas would fall roughly into line, giving world markets a benchmark and ensuring that prices remain near the current world average of $24 a barrel.
Asked if OPEC members would comply, the group's president, Rilwanu Lukman of Nigeria, replied, "Inshallah," the Arabic word for "God willing."
Abdulhafid Mahmoud Zlitni, Libya's chief delegate, said OPEC would adjust output to try to keep prices at $22 to $28 a barrel.
Analysts said the length of the global economic slowdown lasts would probably be a crucial factor in determining oil production levels. 
If its members do stick to production quotas, OPEC will be able to exert considerable short-term control over the global market, analysts said. Although it produces only a third of the world's oil, OPEC producers, and particularly Saudi Arabia, are the only ones with spare production capacity, which gives them exceptional leverage over prices.
Analysts at the meeting generally agreed that cuts would initially be 500,000 to 1 million barrels a day, far short of the 1.7 million pledged. If Venezuela resumes deliveries, and if Iraqi production is not curbed by war, other producers, especially Nigeria and Algeria, could begin exceeding their quotas again.
Analysts said they did not expect war with Iraq, if it comes, to affect prices significantly.
"What is important is if the war spreads beyond Iraq's borders," said Vera de Ladoucette, director of Middle East research at Cambridge Energy Research Associates in Massachusetts. "If not, Saudi Arabia can compensate any loss of Iraqi supply, and they are happy to do it."
